Pro-Brexit bosses: beer-mat politicians
Pro-Brexit bosses: beer-mat politicians
Financial Times (London, England)
September 16, 2017 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; Pg. 26
Length: 968 words
Body
Most UK bosses who back Brexit keep their views on the subject out of the corporate domain. Not so Tim Martin. 
Beer mats and the company's in-house magazine left drinkers in JD Wetherspoon pubs in no doubt as to his stance 
on the matter.
Much of the group's results statement was devoted to the same subject. The remainder of it showed the group 
doing well; profit was up 15 per cent in the first full year since the Brexit vote. Selling cheap beer and food to Brits is 
not a business dependent on close trading links with Europe. Goods from EU suppliers could be readily substituted 
and just 5 per cent of staff are EU nationals.
Many other listed companies with Brexit-backing bosses are similarly UK-focused. The main risk they face is a 
slowdown in UK consumer spending that Mr Martin says has not happened (despite "doom-mongering" by the 
Financial Times and others). Clothing retailer Next said on Thursday that conditions were "encouraging". For those 
that do sell abroad, Europe tends to be a less important market than the US or Asia. It is just 5 per cent of revenue 
at Next and 3 per cent at Jardine Lloyd Thompson, the insurer.
Post-EU poll share price showings tell us little. Shares in Wetherspoon are up 38 per cent since June 2016 thanks 
to improved trading, while it has bought back shares and boosted its estate's quality. CMC Markets is down 45 per 
cent because of a threatened regulatory crackdown, not because of founder Peter Cruddas's views on Europe.
Longer-term performances are often impressive. Wetherspoon has returned 4,690 per cent since floating in 1992. 
Next and Hargreaves Lansdown, a financial group, have also done well. Then again, so has Ryanair, whose chief 
executive was an advocate of staying in the EU.
Pro-Brexit bosses: beer-mat politicians
Behind the scenes, business comes first. Good bosses' political views do not colour their decisions. Investors 
should keep politics out of theirs, too.
Silicon Valley investors are rebooting an old concept - the cash shell - with the aim of disrupting traditional initial 
public offerings. Venture capital firms Social Capital and Hedosophia say they have received a "tidal wave" of 
inquiries from private tech groups hoping to be smuggled on to the public markets. That may not translate into a 
successful takeover, however.
After raising $700m from a group of "curated" institutions, the firms can now use their self-named special purpose 
acquisition company, or Spac, to go shopping. Their bold target range, which includes debt, is $3bn-$20bn.
The chosen unicorn will be "acquired" by the Spac, which went public on Thursday. In practice, existing 
shareholders will retain majority ownership in the new entity, just as in a normal IPO. The pseudoacquisition will 
mean a quicker listing, however. The price will be set by negotiation rather than underwriters.
At least that is the theory. It relies on Social Capital Hedosophia valuing a company better than the market. Still, 
investors have demonstrated their desire for a unicorn: which will they get? Analysis by CB Insights lists 53 private 
tech groups valued at $2.5bn-$20bn. Of these, Spotify is already set to go public. At $20bn, Palantir and WeWork 
are probably too big. SoFi is mired in scandal. Instacart has been shell-shocked by Amazon.
Others, including Pinterest, Vice and Lyft, have all raised money recently, making them unlikely candidates. The 
investment team's bias is to the US and Europe, which removes 22 from Asia.
Social Capital already backs Slack, a conflict that makes a deal unlikely.
That leaves 17 companies headed by Dropbox, the file-storage group valued at $10bn. The Spac has two years to 
find a target or hand the money back.
The first hurdle has been vaulted - investors have signed up. Now comes the hard part. Under scrutiny, that tidal 
wave of targets, turns into an unimpressively small pool.
If Billy Beane does arrive in Barnsley, as part of a mooted £20m deal for the Championship football club, there is a 
chance that the pioneer of "Moneyball" analysis in baseball could transform the Tykes. One good season is all it 
takes to win promotion to the Premier League, the land of riches. A history of financial losses is a minor detail next 
to the gush of cash from television revenues in the distance.
Follow that money upstream, however, and the buyers and owners of football clubs might start to feel less 
confident. Its source is the worldwide sale of TV rights to screen live matches, which has kept fans paying up for 
premium packages of www.channels.TV companies no longer pay for rights based on their intrinsic value, but 
because live sport underpins the entire business model of selling expensive bundled packages of TV channels. The 
situation, which is also true for the fabulous wealth of the US sports leagues, can be expected to last only as long 
as that bundled TV proposition can be defended.
How far off is the tipping point? Football viewing figures in the UK were down last year, and while Sky TV has 
continued to grow subscriber numbers, the rate of subscriber churn has been rising. Its growth is sustained in part 
by Now TV, the online version that lets customers buy occasional access to content. Billed as a gateway to full pay-
TV, it looks a lot like a future of cheaper pay-as-you-go TV similar to what is available online.
The company has also repackaged its sports channels to let viewers buy access just to cricket, football or rugby, if 
that's their preference.
The reckoning may not come in the next round of rights negotiations, which for the Premier League begins early 
next year. At some point, though, income from TV will drop, threatening the wage structures and transfer values of 
football clubs. Whichever way you crunch the numbers, living on less money will not be a ball.
Social Capital:  ;  ;  unicorn hunting  ;
Pro-Brexit bosses: beer-mat politicians
Sports rights:  ;  ;  Beane counting  ;
Load-Date: September 15, 2017
End of Document
Where to now for a police force in crisis?
Where to now for a police force in crisis?
Sunday Business Post
September 16, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 2389 words
Byline: Michael Brennan
Highlight: Nóirín O’Sullivan’s departure has not solved any of the problems plaguing the Garda, write Michael 
Brennan and Francesca Comyn 
Body
It is a force with 13,000 gardaí, 2,000 civilians and an annual budget of €1.5 billion. But the departure of Garda 
commissioner Nóirín O’Sullivan less than halfway through her term has once again highlighted the desperate need 
to reform our policing service.
One of the simplest signs of how the force is struggling is that many gardaí driving patrol cars cannot chase 
criminals or speed to an emergency because they have not had adequate driver training. This problem has been 
highlighted for years, due to untrained gardaí being involved in several serious collisions after putting on the siren. 
But the latest Policing Authority report shows new recruits are still leaving the Garda College in Templemore without 
this ‘flashing blue light’ training.
When a new chief executive is appointed to a scandal-hit company, a common approach is to lay bare all of the 
problems immediately and then promise to fix them. O’Sullivan took a different tack, which was a mistake. She 
signalled that a wave of further problems would be coming down the track but provided no detail. That meant each 
scandal became associated with her reign when it emerged, from the falsification of 1.45 million breath tests to the 
mysterious money movements in the Garda training college.
She spoke during her time in office of “suffering” from criticism of Garda problems that she herself had helped to 
shine a light on as Commissioner. But when it came to fixing them, the recent Policing Authority report found that 
only nine out of 50 supposedly completed initiatives had been finalised satisfactorily.
“It was the cumulative effect of one mistake after another that saw the back of O’Sullivan. None of the issues 
seemed to be addressed in any meaningful way,” said one retired garda.
Where to now for a police force in crisis?
This retired garda touted maverick Ryanair chief executive Michael O’Leary as the sort of dynamic business 
mindset the force could do with at such a critical juncture. “They need someone like him to shake the job up and get 
on with it, tell it as it is and not pussyfoot around.”
O’Sullivan did not help her case by being only available to the media for brief doorsteps. She was advised internally 
to one-to-one interviews, but she did a grand total of two during almost three years in office. Her human side and 
personal story remained largely hidden. It meant that the public only saw the ‘Garda commissioner’ rather than 
‘Nóirín”. One notable exception was when she spoke publicly at a Garda conference about how she was bitten, spat 
at and assaulted on a number of occasions on duty, including one incident that resulted in a dislocated shoulder.
When O’Sullivan was appointed interim commissioner in March 2014 after the departure of Martin Callinan, she had 
two meetings with Garda whistleblower Sergeant Maurice McCabe at Garda headquarters to discuss his complaints 
about his treatment by some members of the force. She had not been involved in any of the issues he had raised 
about poor policing practices in his former Cavan-Monaghan Garda division and elsewhere. But at the start of the 
state inquiry into the matters, O’Sullivan’s legal team accused McCabe of being motivated by malice. The final 
report later found he had “acted out of genuine and legitimate concerns”. But this response instantly raised 
questions about O’Sullivan’s attitude to whistleblowers.
Alan Bailey, a former detective who had served for 39 years in the Garda, said a reformed force had to change its 
attitude to whistleblowers. “You have to accept that as a member of an organisation, if I see something wrong, I 
should be at least entitled to flag it and be listened to,” he said.
Bailey himself was involved in the investigation of the murder of two women at the Grangegorman hospital complex 
in 1997. He and another garda had opposed a poorly considered decision to charge a heroin addict called Dean 
Lyons with the murders. The charges were later dropped when another man, Mark Nash, confessed to the crime.
“I brought up issues that a man in custody charged with two murders wasn’t guilty. I know the reaction I got. There 
was nothing subtle about it. Myself and a colleague were told we were wrong,” he said.
O’Sullivan’s departure came as a surprise to her senior officers, who got word of it from her just a few hours before 
she released her retirement statement. The government had got advance warning at the highest level a few days 
earlier due to the discussions over her pension arrangements.
As this newspaper reported last week, O’Sullivan would have had to remain in office until November 25 to qualify 
for the maximum lump sum of about €300,000 and a pension of up to €100,000. That would have marked her third 
year in office − and Garda rules dictate that these payments are based on the best three years of the last ten years. 
However, the government was not going to allow this to stand in the way of an immediate exit by O’Sullivan. 
Minister for Public Expenditure Paschal Donohoe agreed to allow her seven months as interim Garda 
Commissioner to count as well, pushing her over the three-year mark.
In her departure statement, O’Sullivan namechecked the Dáil’s Public Accounts committee (PAC) as being part of 
the “unending cycle” of requests, questions and public hearings that had consumed her regular policing job.
Fianna Fáil TD Seán Fleming, the chair of the PAC, admitted that when he saw O’Sullivan and her senior 
management team there for meetings lasting up to seven hours, the thought did occur to him: “Who is catching all 
the criminals if you are in here?” In total, the PAC held five public meetings with O’Sullivan this year − most of them 
to do with the Garda College.
The PAC committee meetings revealed an extraordinary level of rancour at the top of Garda management, with 
senior officers contradicting O’Sullivan and each other about the Garda training college scandal. One source in the 
force said the Garda had shot themselves in the foot so often, they had run out of feet to shoot.
Fine Gael TD Alan Farrell, a member of the committee, said the events of the last 12 months had highlighted 
extraordinary deficiencies in middle and upper level management in the Garda.
Where to now for a police force in crisis?
“It requires a culture change as quickly as humanly possible,” he said.
However, Garda headquarters was known to be unhappy with the tone of the questioning at PAC by Sinn Féin 
deputy leader Mary Lou McDonald, and the committee’s vice chair, Labour TD Alan Kelly. Kelly, when he was 
presiding over the PAC meetings, took the unusual step of making O’Sullivan answer every question herself and 
refusing to allow her to pass them on to members of senior management. McDonald accused O’Sullivan of 
engaging in “verbal Pilates” and told her to “stick to the knitting”. That is a phrase that does mean to keep to the 
point, but it was ill-advised when dealing with the country’s first female Garda commissioner. It obviously rankled 
with O’Sullivan herself. “With respect, we are not knitting here,” she told McDonald in response.
Fleming said O’Sullivan had been a good witness during her many appearances there. But he said the process of 
getting information from the force had been slow and painful.
“There’s a lesson there to be learned for the incoming Garda commissioner, to know that public accountability is a 
fundamental part of the job. They have to understand that and not be swamped by it,” he said.
If O’Sullivan proved a disappointment to gardaí on the ground, even her strongest detractors readily accept that she 
had leadership qualities. By comparison, her interim replacement Dónall Ó Cualáin is seen as the ultimate 
caretaker manager.
He is involved, at least in a proxy way, in a Garda whistleblower controversy. When Athlone-based garda Nick 
Keogh made a protected disclosure in May 2014 alleging corruption and Garda collusion in the local heroin trade, Ó 
Cualáin was appointed to head up an internal investigation, which lasted well over a year. Keogh later filed a 
complaint with the Garda Síochána Ombudsman Commission alleging the investigation was a cover-up.
[caption id="attachment_397935" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Former Garda commissioner Noirin O’Sullivan 
Pic: Bryan Meade[/caption]
Even if Ó Cualáin is entirely vindicated, Keogh’s case is just one of many potential landmines likely to detonate at 
the Disclosures Tribunal which has a mandate to look at Garda treatment of whistleblowers.
Ó Cualáin has ruled himself out of the running for the job of commissioner. There are other senior gardaí said to be 
interested in the role who will position themselves as competent and committed to change. But the government 
appears keen to sidestep existing management in favour of positioning an outsider or civilian in the top job 
(although of course it is for the Policing Authority to nominate the successful candidate).
“I suppose the only legitimate candidate at this stage would be from outside. After the debacle with O’Sullivan’s 
predecessor we would have thought Nóirín was the great white hope,” said a mid-ranking Garda source.
One of the main barriers to appointing a commissioner from abroad is that they will be given responsibility for a key 
part of the country’s intelligence services. “There’s a lot of blasé commentary from politicians about this. No other 
country would have a foreigner in charge of national security. It would be absolutely unthinkable,” said a Garda 
source.
The Commission on the Future of Policing is looking at whether there should be a separate national security agency 
set up along the lines of Britain’s MI5 or the National Security Agency in the US. But it is not due to report until 
September next year. Fianna Fáil justice spokesman Jim O’Callaghan said he believed one possible solution would 
be for a commissioner from abroad to look after policing and for a deputy commissioner to be given responsibility 
for national security issues.
“We need to rebuild confidence in the guards. It’s a force with a fine history. But it’s been damaged by these 
issues,” he said.
For a new commissioner to succeed, there will need to be a clearout of some of the senior Garda management. 
Róisín Shortall of the Social Democrats said the concern was that the appointment of a new Garda commissioner 
would not in itself be sufficient to effect cultural change.
Where to now for a police force in crisis?
“It appears a lot of officers felt they could engage in falsifying figures with impunity. If that is how many people feel 
within the Gardaí, then there is a very deep-rooted problem in the culture,” she said. “One person will be swallowed 
up by that culture unless they are supported by other people of a like mind. In our view that means bringing in a 
whole new team.”
That would involve stripping away some, if not all, of the assistant and deputy commissioners.
But what price change? In Northern Ireland, the Patten redundancy scheme for some 5,000 former RIC police 
officers cost almost £500 million (€568 million). Given the severe pressures in housing and health, it is tricky to 
imagine the government throwing wads of money at Garda reform.
Back in the early 2000s, the Morris tribunal into Garda corruption in Donegal reported that there was a “small, but 
disproportionately influential, core of mischief-making members who will not obey orders, who will not follow 
procedures, who will not tell the truth and who have no respect for their officers”.
There are still stories today of a minority of gardaí who will not take orders, who go home early from their shifts and 
who encourage members of the public not to even bother reporting crimes. Clearly, the proper management the 
Morris tribunal called for is still lacking.
There has been talk for years of the Garda copying the army’s highly successful cadet system, so that a group of 
recruits are given specific training to be managers.
PwC has been given a €500,000 contract to carry out a cultural audit of the Garda. The thinking behind this is in line 
with that of Labour leader Brendan Howlin, who last week quoted business management guru Peter Drucker: 
“Culture eats strategy for breakfast.”
Then there is the ongoing problem of Garda visibility. “You can drive through a town in Ireland and not see a guard,” 
said one retired member of the force.
The latest Garda public attitudes survey for the second quarter of this year shows that just 36 per cent of the public 
were aware of Garda patrols in their local area. The Policing Authority have put down greater Garda visibility as a 
priority for next year’s policing plan.
It is not encouraging that the training centre of the force − the Garda College in Templemore, Co Tipperary − has 
been mired in controversy over irregular payments. Question marks also hang over the qualify of the training 
provided to new recruits.
During the boom, the Garda College was packed to the rafters with new recruits to meet the Fianna Fáil-led 
government’s promise of an extra 2,000 gardaí. Many highly qualified recruits were taken in, but there were others 
of low ability who would never have made it otherwise. These have been described as a “group of duds” who have 
been causing problems in the force for over a decade now. In a sign of just how rushed the process was, one 
probationer garda was found to have a bench warrant outstanding for his arrest for a previous public order offence. 
In the past, such a person would have never even qualified for an interview. The only option for this poorly 
performing batch of “Celtic Tiger” gardaí is urgent retraining because it will be nearly impossible to sack them.
Garda sources say student gardaí are still not getting quality training when they are sent out to small rural stations 
to learn their trade. They say the only way to do it is assign the probationers to busy city stations, where they will 
learn much faster and get better experience.
Her lucrative pension package aside, O’Sullivan’s final bow is not how anyone would wish to end a 36-year policing 
career: undone by a plethora of scandals in the force from dubious financial transactions at Templemore college to 
the disclosures tribunal and the falsification of 1.45 million breath tests.
She leaves behind a force divided both at the higher echelons and among rank and file gardaí, who are pointing the 
finger at management over bogus breath tests. But then again, the only time historically when changes have been 
made in An Garda Síochána is when it is at rock bottom.
Where to now for a police force in crisis?
Load-Date: September 16, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair chief claims court win but investors wary Airlines
Ryanair chief claims court win but investors wary; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
September 16, 2017 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 16
Length: 249 words
Byline: PEGGY HOLLINGER
Body
Michael O'Leary is nothing if not audacious. So it is entirely in character for the chief executive of Ryanair to claim 
victory after this week's ruling from the European Court of Justice, and then swiftly move on to the question of his 
mooted bid for Italy's ailing Alitalia.
The truth is rather more ambiguous, allowing unions and investors to judge that any victory could be a hollow one. 
In the end, Ryanair's insistence that its employees across Europe be obliged to take any disputes to Irish courts 
was knocked back.
The case was brought by six former Belgium-based workers who claim they have missed out on wages and 
benefits by being subject to Irish contracts. These specify that any disputes should be heard in Irish courts.
Ryanair won its argument that the home base - where crew start and end their journeys - should not be the sole 
determiner of jurisdiction for any dispute with staff.
But it lost in the sense that the court did rule that the home base and where duties are habitually performed should 
carry significant weight. As a result the case will now be heard in Belgium, not Ireland.
In investors' eyes, this judgment could open the way to new disputes in other more employee-friendly jurisdictions, 
and eventually an increase in labour costs.
Ryanair chief claims court win but investors wary Airlines
Before that happens, the Belgian court will have to decide which laws are applicable to the Ryanair case. Will they 
be Belgian or Irish? For the time being, Mr O'Leary insists that employees will continue to be hired on Irish 
contracts.
Graphic
 
Michael O'Leary, Ryanair's chief executive, claimed victory after a ruling from the ECJ in a case brought by six 
former Belgium-based workers

Group: Ryanair cancellations bode ill for its Alitalia bid
Group: Ryanair cancellations bode ill for its Alitalia bid
Associated Press Financial Wire
September 16, 2017 Saturday 1:57 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 127 words
Dateline: MILAN 
Body
MILAN (AP) - The Codacons consumer advocacy group said Ryanair's decision to cancel 2,000 flights over the 
next six weeks has put a poor light on its plans to bid for bankrupt Alitalia.
Budget carrier Ryanair has announced it would cancel up to 50 flights a day through October to improve 
punctuality. Codacons said Saturday the decision will have repercussions for "thousands and thousands of Italian 
travelers," and that passengers should be fully reimbursed or rebooked on other flights at no additional cost.
Codacons added that "in light of what happened, the air carrier does not seem the most adapted to take over 
Alitalia."
Ryanair's CEO has said the low-cost carrier would make a bid for the long-range assets of Alitalia, which filed for 
bankruptcy in May.

Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were 0.1% higher at 138.05 on the Bank of New York Mellon 
Europe ADR Index on Friday morning. 
Gainers in Continental Europe were led by voxeljet (VJET), a German three-dimensional printer manufacturer, 6.1% 
higher, followed by Sequans Communications (SQNS), a French developer of chipset solutions, up by 6.0%, Nokia 
(NOK), a technology investor,  3.2% higher and Ascendis Pharma (ASND), a Danish clinical stage 
biopharmaceutical company, up by 1.7%. 
In the U.K., Avadel (AVDL), a specialty pharmaceutical company, up by 3.9%, followed by Motif Bio Plc - Warrant 
(MTFBW), a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company, up by 2.8% and Amarin (AMRN), a biopharmaceutical 
company, 2.1% higher and British American Tobacco (BTI) up by 1.6%. 
Decliners in Continental Europe were led by CGG (CGG), a manufacturer of geophysical equipment, down by 
2.4%, followed by Grifols (GRFS), a Spanish company engaged in the healthcare sector, 2.3% lower and Forward 
Pharma (FWP), a Danish biopharmaceutical company, down by 2.1%. Materialise (MTLS), a Belgian provider of 3D 
printing software and services, down by 1.8%. 
And, in the UK, Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), a development-stage biopharmaceutical company, was down by 5.8%, 
followed by Carnival (CUK), a cruise vacation company, 3.9% lower and low-cost airline Ryanair (RYAAY), down by 
1.2% and Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP), a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company, down by 1.1%.

Ryanair suffers legal blow on crew contracts Airlines
Ryanair suffers legal blow on crew contracts; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
September 15, 2017 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;FEATURES; OFFERS; Pg. 17
Length: 461 words
Byline: PEGGY HOLLINGER ;MEHREEN KHAN
Body
Ryanair was dealt a blow in its legal battle to force employees across Europe to take disputes to the Irish courts 
after the European Court of Justice ruled that cabin crew based in other countries could pursue legal claims locally.
The ruling knocked Ryanair shares after analysts suggested it could call the lowcost carrier's employment model 
into question, leading to potentially higher labour costs. It could also open the door to claims from crew in other 
countries over terms and conditions.
Ryanair insisted, however, that there would be no change to its practice of employing staff across Europe on Irish 
contracts, which give the carrier costeffective benefits over some other EU countries in terms of productivity and 
wage levels.
While the jurisdiction was decided by yesterday's ruling, the battle now will be to decide whether Irish law will still 
apply, regardless of the jurisdiction.
This decision is at least three to four months away and then the complaint itself - from six cabin crew based in 
Belgium - will have to be decided. Eddie Wilson, the airline's chief people officer, said he did not think the ruling "will 
in any way alter our Irish contracts of employment".
"Irish legislation has adopted all EU directives on employment rights which ... in some cases, offers better 
protection than some EU countries; for example, maternity leave in Ireland is more favourable than in Belgium."
Ryanair suffers legal blow on crew contracts Airlines
Ryanair claimed it had won a victory after the court ruled that the location where staff were based was only one of 
several factors, albeit a significant one, in determining jurisdiction.
However, transport unions rejected Ryanair's claim and insisted that the ECJ's findings marked the first blow to an 
opportunistic use of more favourable labour laws.
"Ryanair's claim that this judgment supports them stretches reality beyond its breaking point. It's pure wish 
fulfilment.
The verdict is clear. They lost. Big time," said Ruwan Subasinghe, legal adviser to the International Transport 
Workers' Federation, which represents 700 transport trade unions from 150 countries.
The ECJ's decision is the latest to be taken in the sensitive area of workers' rights.
The EU's highest court, which began its early life adjudicating mainly over trade disputes, has in recent years ruled 
on everything from an employee's right to wear a hijab in the workplace to whether a plumber should consider their 
travelling hours as part of their working day.
Geert Van Calster, a professor at the Institute for European Law in Leuven, said the Ryanair ruling was not the 
"final blow" for the airline but would probably set a precedent in an area where EU governments are also becoming 
more sensitive to the rights of mobile workers.
Ryanair shares closed down 3.11 per cent at (EURO)17.47.
Load-Date: September 14, 2017
End of Document
Michael O'Leary says Ryanair will swoop with binding Alitalia offer
Michael O'Leary says Ryanair will swoop with binding Alitalia offer
City A.M.
September 15, 2017 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 12
Length: 211 words
Byline: REBECCA SMITH
Body
RYANAIR'S interest in an Alitalia takeover has taken off, with the airline saying yesterday it is in the process of 
finalising a binding offer for the Italian flag carrier.
The Irish carrier's chief executive Michael O'Leary told Reuters: "We would have to order new planes, whether 
Boeing or Airbus."
He added that Ryanair preferred to own its fleet, as opposed to lease planes like Alitalia, and that he hoped his 
airline would maintain jobs for pilot and crew, but said they would have to be on new terms in line with Ryanair's 
cost base.
A Ryanair spokesperson confirmed to City A.M. that Ryanair is involved in the process and intends to make a 
binding offer.
Alitalia was put up for sale earlier this year, after the Italian government approved its collapse into administration in 
May, following a vote by employees which rejected a rescue plan.
O'Leary also said Ryanair was not interested in a bid for Air Berlin, which filed for insolvency last month, as the 
process was not transparent, and would benefit Germany's largest airline Lufthansa.
He said he anticipated European Union competition authorities would demand substantial remedies if Lufthansa 
bought Air Berlin, with the airline likely to have to relinquish slots on German routes to preserve competition.
Michael O'Leary says Ryanair will swoop with binding Alitalia offer

Michael O'Leary says Ryanair in process of finalizing Alitalia offer
Michael O'Leary says Ryanair in process of finalizing Alitalia offer
Business World (Digest)
September 15, 2017 Friday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 164 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair is in the process of finalizing a binding offer for Alitalia, which will see it keep the brand, long-haul 
operations but changing the fleet for short-haul routes, CEO Michael O'Leary said on Thursday.
"We would have to order new planes, whether Boeing or Airbus," O'Leary told Reuters, adding that Ryanair 
preferred to own its fleet, rather than lease planes, as Alitalia does.
He said Ryanair hoped to preserve jobs for pilots and crew, although warned they would have to be on new terms 
in line with Ryanair's cost base.
He added that Ryanair was not interested in bidding for Air Berlin because the process was not transparent, 
repeating previous accusations that it was a stitch-up designed to make Lufthansa stronger.
He said he expected EU competition authorities would demand substantial remedies in the event Lufthansa buys 
Air Berlin, with the carrier likely to have to give up slots on routes within Germany to preserve competition. 
(Reuters)

Ryanair 737 diverts to East Midlands over possible shed wheel One of Ryanair 's Boeing 737-800s has been 
diverted to East Midlands airport after departing Londo....
Ryanair 737 diverts to East Midlands over possible shed wheel; One of 
Ryanair's Boeing 737-800s has been diverted to East Midlands airport after 
departing London Stansted, with initial indications that it lost a wheel on 
take-off.
Flight International
September 15, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 113 words
Body
One of Ryanair's Boeing 737-800s has been diverted to East Midlands airport after departing London Stansted, with 
initial indications that it lost a wheel on take-off.
The aircraft had been bound for Copenhagen on 15 September.
East Midlands airport's operator confirms that the aircraft had a "technical problem", but has yet to disclose further 
details.
It adds that the aircraft has landed safely.
FlightGlobal has received information from air traffic control sources that a nose-wheel was located in the vicinity of 
Stansted's runway 22.
Preliminary data, still unconfirmed, points to the aircraft involved being EI-DLV, which Flight Fleets Analyzer lists as 
an 11-year old airframe.

Ryanair cannot impose Irish law on foreign crew says EU Court
Ryanair cannot impose Irish law on foreign crew says EU Court
Business World (Digest)
September 14, 2017 Thursday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 237 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair lost an EU court battle on Thursday in which the airline had sought to continue imposing business-friendly 
Irish labour laws on cabin crew working elsewhere in Europe, in a case with implications across the low-cost airline 
sector.
The European Court of Justice in Luxembourg ruled in favour of cabin crew based at the Irish carrier's Charleroi 
airport base in Belgium. The employees took the airline to a local court, believing Belgian law would be more 
favourable to them.
Ryanair argued that Irish law applied to their Irish contracts.
"The Court points out first of all that, as regards disputes related to employment contracts, the European rules 
concerning jurisdiction are aimed at protecting the weaker party," the Luxembourg-based ECJ said in a statement.
"Those rules enable inter alia an employee to sue his employer before the courts which he regards as closest to 
this interests," it said.
The ruling will come as a relief to cabin crew in Europe who are unsure what laws apply to them.
The crew involved in the case had employment contracts drawn up under Irish law which said their work was to be 
regarded as being carried out in Ireland since they were working on Irish-registered aircraft.
But Charleroi airport in southern Belgium was designated as their base, meaning they started and ended their 
working days there and had to reside within an hour of that airport. (Reuters)
Ryanair cannot impose Irish law on foreign crew says EU Court
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: October 9, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair to change allowances
Ryanair to change allowances
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 14, 2017
Copyright 2017 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Business and Industry News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 281 words
Body
From 1 November Ryanair will change its boarding rules regarding luggage. The hold allowance will go up from 
15kg to 20kg, the industry standard (although many follow the IATA recommended 23kg), with the current hand 
carry-on bags service modified.
Only Priority Boarding customers (including Plus, Flexi Plus & Family Plus) will be allowed to bring two carry-on 
bags on the aircraft. All other (i.e. non-priority) customers can bring one smaller carry-on bag on board the aircraft, 
while their second (bigger) wheelie bag must be placed in the hold (free of charge) at the boarding gate.¬This 
seems to go against the airline,Äôs previous policy, which was to try to reduce hold baggage.
The standard check-in bag fee will be cut from ¬£35 to ¬£25 for this 20kg bag. The maximum size of cabin baggage 
remains at 55cm x 40cm x 20cm, as other airlines.¬What constitutes a small carry-on bag remains to be seen.
Ryanair put the cost at more than ,Ç¨50m a year in reduced checked bag fees and forgot to mention the reduced 
airport handling charges.

Portugal asked to review laser laws
Portugal asked to review laser laws
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 14, 2017
Copyright 2017 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Business and Industry News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 612 words
Body
Irish air accident investigators have called on the Portuguese civil aviation authority to review current legislation 
regarding the use of dangerous lasers after a Ryanair flight crew was forced to abort a landing because a pilot was 
'temporarily blinded.'¬An investigation into the incident, at Porto Airport in Portugal on September 5 2015, has 
highlighted the lack of legislation in Portugal covering the targeting of aircraft with lasers.
The probe into the incident was delegated by the Portuguese authorities to the Irish Department of Transport's Air 
Accident Investigation Unit as Ireland is the 'state of registry' for the incident aircraft.
The incident flight was a scheduled service from Lille in France to Porto Airport in Portugal. Shortly after 9 pm, the 
Boeing 737-800 was on its final approach when the co-pilot, who was the pilot flying, was distracted by a green 
laser light being shone towards the aircraft.¬ The laser was not pointing directly at the aircraft and then disappeared 
from view, leading the co-pilot to believe that it had been switched off. <br class="" /><br class="" />However, 
shortly after establishing on the final approach track, a laser was directed towards the aircraft from the same area 
but this time illuminated the cockpit. The co-pilot put his left hand up to shield his eyes.¬ The commander, who was 
acting as pilot monitoring and was unaware of the laser, looked up at that moment and her eyes were struck by the 
laser light. She sustained flash-blindness which is a temporary visual loss or impairment during and following 
exposure to a light flash of extremely high intensity. The effects may last for several seconds to a few minutes. <br 
class="" /><br class="" />As a result, flight crew coordination was compromised which led to the final descent being 
delayed and the approach becoming unstable.¬ The co-pilot reported that his vision had not been affected. The 
laser was seen operating from an area close to the centre of Porto, which he stated was a 'common occurrence'. 
<br class="" /><br class="" />While there are strict laws in Ireland that deal with the targeting of aircraft with lasers, 
it is not an offence in Portugal to illuminate an aircraft with a laser or other bright light. As a result, the investigation 
unit has made one safety recommendation, that: "The Portuguese Civil Aviation Authority should review the current 
civil aviation legislation with a view to taking account of occurrences of deliberate or reckless illumination of aircraft, 
or persons involved in the operation of aircraft, by laser light or similar." <br class="" /><br class="" />A spokesman 
for the investigation unit said: "A safety recommendation was made in our report to the Portuguese civil aviation 
authority. As per European and Air Accident Investigation Unit requirements, [we] will track response from the 
Portuguese authorities and will populate the Safety Recommendation Information System which is the European 
database for safety recommendations." www.irishexaminer.com
Portugal asked to review laser laws

Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Downgraded by HSBC Holdings plc to Reduce
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Downgraded by HSBC Holdings plc to 
Reduce
American Banking and Market News
September 14, 2017 Thursday
Copyright 2017 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 771 words
Body
Ryanair Holdings PLC logo Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was downgraded by stock analysts at 
HSBC Holdings plc from a "buy" rating to a "reduce" rating in a report released on Thursday. 
Other equities analysts have also issued research reports about the stock. BidaskClub lowered shares of Ryanair 
Holdings PLC from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Friday, August 25th. Sanford C. Bernstein 
assumed coverage on shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC in a report on Monday, June 26th. They issued an 
"underperform" rating and a $83.00 price target for the company. Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. (The) raised shares 
of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "neutral" rating to a "buy" rating and boosted their price target for the company 
from $67.56 to $109.00 in a report on Thursday, June 15th. ValuEngine  raised shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC 
from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Tuesday, June 6th. Finally, UBS AG lowered shares of Ryanair 
Holdings PLC from a "buy" rating to a "neutral" rating in a report on Friday, June 2nd. Three research analysts have 
rated the stock with a sell rating, four have issued  a hold rating and nine have assigned  a buy rating to the 
company. The stock  has an average rating of "Hold" and a consensus price target of $100.33. 
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY ) traded down 3.65% during mid-day trading on Thursday, hitting $109.93. The 
stock had a trading volume of 110,741 shares. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 1-year low of $67.56 and a 1-year high 
of $122.68.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its earnings results on Monday, July 24th. The 
transportation company reported $1.78 EPS for the quarter, topping analysts' consensus estimates of $1.48 by 
$0.30. Ryanair Holdings PLC had a net margin of 21.44% and a return on equity of 34.02%. The firm had revenue 
of $2.10 billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $2.02 billion.  Equities analysts forecast that  
Ryanair Holdings PLC will post $7.58 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC announced that its board has approved a stock repurchase plan on Tuesday, May 30th that 
authorizes the company to repurchase  outstanding  shares. This repurchase authorization authorizes the 
transportation company to purchase up to 2.3% of its shares through open market purchases. Shares repurchase 
plans are generally a sign that the company's management believes its stock is undervalued.  
A number of institutional investors and hedge funds have recently bought and sold shares of the stock. Private 
Advisor Group LLC lifted its position in  Ryanair Holdings PLC by 1.6% in the 2nd quarter. Private Advisor Group 
LLC now owns 2,461 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $275,000 after acquiring an additional 
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Downgraded by HSBC Holdings plc to Reduce
38 shares in the last quarter.  Pinnacle Associates Ltd. lifted its position in  Ryanair Holdings PLC by 0.4% in the 
2nd quarter. Pinnacle Associates Ltd. now owns 10,483 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$1,128,000 after acquiring an additional 43 shares in the last quarter.  Baldwin Investment Management LLC lifted 
its position in  Ryanair Holdings PLC by 0.5% in the 2nd quarter. Baldwin Investment Management LLC now owns 
9,095 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $979,000 after acquiring an additional 44 shares in 
the last quarter.  Financial Counselors Inc. lifted its position in  Ryanair Holdings PLC by 1.0% in the 1st quarter. 
Financial Counselors Inc. now owns 4,880 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $405,000 after 
acquiring an additional 46 shares in the last quarter.  Finally, Freestone Capital Holdings LLC lifted its position in  
Ryanair Holdings PLC by 1.9% in the 2nd quarter. Freestone Capital Holdings LLC now owns 3,881 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $418,000 after acquiring an additional 74 shares in the last quarter. 
40.13% of the stock is currently owned by institutional investors and hedge funds.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.

EasyJet in hub deal with Norwegian and Westjet Airlines
EasyJet in hub deal with Norwegian and Westjet; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
September 14, 2017 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 17
Length: 328 words
Byline: TANYA POWLEY
Body
European passengers flying long-haul to the US or South America will be able to book flights through easyJet after 
the UK airline launched a service aimed at connecting flights internationally.
It has teamed up with long-haul carriers Norwegian Air Shuttle and Canada's WestJet to allow people to book 
connecting flights on a combined ticket. EasyJet said it was in talks with other carriers to expand the service, called 
"Worldwide by easyJet".
EasyJet is rolling out the initiative at Gatwick, its largest base. It plans to expand it to Milan Malpensa, Geneva and 
Barcelona, as well as Paris Charles de Gaulle and Amsterdam Schiphol.
It comes as Ryanair, easyJet's main low-cost rival, has been working on similar plans.
Michael O'Leary, chief executive, has been vocal over his plans to offer connecting flights to long-haul operators, 
but the airline has encountered delays in signing deals. Ryanair is also in talks with Norwegian.
In May, Ryanair revealed a deal to sell flights to the US and Latin America as part of a partnership with Air Europa.
It is looking at expanding this to allow customers to connect to Air Europa long-haul flights through Madrid.
"EasyJet appears to have stolen a march on Ryanair, which has been working on similar concepts for connecting 
flights and making much noise but less progress," Gerald Khoo, analyst at Liberum, said.
EasyJet in hub deal with Norwegian and Westjet Airlines
He noted that technology, compensation liability and airport co-operation had been obstacles.
EasyJet has overcome those problems by using the GatwickConnects product launched in 2015, which helps 
passengers self-connecting from one flight to another at the airport.
The move is an attempt to compete better with traditional flag carriers such as Air France-KLM and British Airways, 
part of International Airlines Group, which rely on a traditional connecting model.
Carolyn McCall, easyJet's outgoing chief executive, said it was targeting 70m passengers who fly long-haul through 
the airports easyJet operates in.
Load-Date: September 13, 2017

Ryanair Welcomes ECJ Decision In ' Mons ' Case
Ryanair Welcomes ECJ Decision In 'Mons' Case
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
September 14, 2017 Thursday 11:22 AM GMT
Copyright 2017 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 145 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) issued a statement welcoming the decision of the 
European Court of Justice in the 'Mons' case which found in favour of the company by rejecting the CTC Union 
argument that the home base should be the sole determinant of what court jurisdiction can hear disputes on labour 
issues. The company noted that the ECJ decision does not change the status quo of Irish Contracts of Employment 
for Ryanair crew based across Europe.   Ryanair's Chief People Officer Eddie Wilson said: 'Maintaining broad 
assessment criteria ensures that the most appropriate jurisdiction should apply in cases involving international 
transport workers rather than a sole criterion approach, which would narrow the assessment and restrict movement 
and flexibility with a myriad of regulations and different crews throughout Europe.'      
Load-Date: September 14, 2017
End of Document
Mass Protests In France Against Macron Labour Law But Impact Limited
Mass Protests In France Against Macron Labour Law But Impact Limited
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
September 13, 2017 Wednesday 1:48 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 621 words
Body
 French President Emmanuel Macron's approach to his flagship labour law reforms appeared to be paying off for 
the moment as a one-day strike called by the hardline CGT union had limited impact on Tuesday.
According to the Interior Ministry, at least 223,000Â protesters nevertheless took to the streets to decry what CGT 
head Philippe Martinez described as "a law to give full power to employers."
The CGT said 500,000 people had joined some 200 protests countrywide against measures that Macron, for his 
part, argues are needed to give employers the confidence to create new jobs.
Police in Paris said they fired tear gas at some 300 masked protesters who had thrown projectiles at them. The 
Interior Ministry saidÂ 13 arrests were made across the country.
The Eiffel Tower closed its lifts andÂ top story due to strikes, allowing only access by stairs to the first floor, while 
Irish airline Ryanair Holdings PLC complained that it had had to cancel 110 flights.
Suburban trains in Paris were also disrupted, but most other transport services operated normally, with the other 
two main union groups largely shunning the CGT's call for a one-day strike.
The leader of France's largest union group, Laurent Berger of the CFDT, told France 2 television that the decrees 
unveiled by Prime Minister Edouard Philippe on August 31 were "not a good reform".
But, he argued, the union that engaged with the consultation process led by Labour Minister Muriel Penicaud had 
"succeeded in ensuring that a number of even worse steps were not taken".
The reforms to France's complex and highly protective labour code were a key campaign commitment by Macron, 
who took office in May.
He saidÂ that businesses neededÂ more flexibility in order to create jobs and reduceÂ an unemployment rate that 
has drifted between 9 and 10.5% since 2010.
Mass Protests In France Against Macron Labour Law But Impact Limited
The draft decrees announced by Philippe, and due to be formally adopted by the government on September 22,Â 
allow a greater range of working conditions to be agreed at company level rather than sector-wide.
They also allow the smallest companies to negotiate directly with staff or their chosen representatives, rather than 
with unions.
"It's not a labour law, but a law which gives full power to employers," Martinez charged in an interview with 
newspaper Le Parisien on Sunday.
Despite the limited response to the strike call, leftist leader Jean-Luc Melenchon said he was confident Macron 
could be "made to pull back."
"Mr Macron knows that this is a trial of strength and he looked for it. Now it's up to us to rise to the challenge," 
Melenchon said as he joined protests in Marseille.
Melenchon's hard-left La France Insoumise (France Unbowed), despite holding only 17 seats in the 577-strong 
National Assembly, has managed to win the limelight as Macron's most determined opponent.
It has called its own day of protest for September 23, while the CGT is planning to take to the streets again on 
September 21.
As the Paris march dispersed at the city's southern Place d'Italie, one GCT official argued that they had not 
expected that one day of protest would be enough, but it was a good start.
"There aren't just activists here," Veronique Pascalides of the union's public finance branch told dpa. "It's a very 
good day for the start back after the summer holidays."
The protests were taking place as Macron travelled to the French Caribbean to visit the islands of Saint Martin and 
Saint Barthelemy, devastated last week by Hurricane Irma.
A day ahead of the protests, the president doubled down on controversial comments on Friday describing 
opponents of the reform as "idlers."
The phrase referred to "all those who think that we can do nothing, that we have that luxury," he told reporters.
By Pol O Gradaigh, dpa
Load-Date: October 18, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair to change allowances
Ryanair to change allowances
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 13, 2017

Body
From 1 November Ryanair will change its boarding rules regarding luggage. The hold allowance will go up from 
15kg to 20kg, the industry standard (although many follow the IATA recommended 23kg), with the current hand 
carry-on bags service modified.

while their second (bigger) wheelie bag must be placed in the hold (free of charge) at the boarding gate.¬This 
seems to go against the airline,Äôs previous policy, which was to try to reduce hold baggage.

remains at 55cm x 40cm x 20cm, as other airlines.¬What constitutes a small carry-on bag remains to be seen.

news sources. Accern ranks coverage of public companies on a scale of negative one to positive one, with scores 
closest to one being the most favorable.

average is $101.38. The stock has a market cap of $28.16 billion, a PE ratio of 16.99 and a beta of 0.61.  Ryanair

company reported $1.78 EPS for the quarter, beating the Zacks' consensus estimate of $1.48 by $0.30. The 
business had revenue of $2.10 billion during the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $2.02 billion.

Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
September 12, 2017 Tuesday 12:41 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 422 words
Body
       By Andrew McCathie, dpa   BERLIN (dpa-AFX) - Air Berlin passengers faced fresh chaos on Tuesday after the 
beleaguered German airline cancelled 100 flights due to a surge in the number of pilots reporting sick.   The reason 
for the cancellations is 'an extraordinary number of sick reports in the cockpit,' said a spokesman for Germany's 
second-biggest airline, which last month filed for insolvency.     Air Berlin has asked passengers to check the status 
of their flight on the airline's website prior to their arrival at the airport after it said it was cancelling 100 of its 
scheduled 750 flights for Tuesday. 
 About 200 of the 1,500 pilots due to fly on Tuesday had called in sick, the airline said.  'Today is a day that the 
existence of Air Berlin is threatened,' wrote Air Berlin chief operations officer Oliver Iffert in an internal memo seen 
by dpa.   Calling it a 'pilot revolt,' the daily Bild reported that the reason for the jump in the number of pilots claiming 
to be sick was a dispute over their possible transition from the insolvent airline to a potential new buyer.  However, 
the pilots' union, Vereinigung Cockpit, denied the report, saying: 'At no point did the VC call for (pilots) to report ill.'   
Air Berlin said it would offer affected passengers the 'best alternative travel' options.  The airline announced on 
Monday that it had slashed a series of international flights as a result of the need to reduce its long-haul operations 
as part of insolvency proceedings.    This included flights to the Caribbean from the western German city of 
Dusseldorf to September 24.  The German government was forced last month to provide the airline  with a bridging 
loan of 150 million euros (180 million dollars) to help it to continue operating.  Potential buyers have until September 
15 to lodge offers for the struggling carrier, with Germany's biggest airline Lufthansa among bidders seeking to 
acquire parts of Air Berlin.  German businessman Hans Rudolf Wohrl this week also unveiled a 500-million-euro bid 
for Air Berlin, which ran up a loss last year of about 782 million euros and has debts totalling nearly 1.2 billion 
euros.   Air Berlin has operated at a loss every year since 2008, except for 2012, when it sold off its frequent flyer 
programme.  In the meantime, budget airline Ryanair stepped up its campaign on Tuesday to take on Lufthansa in 
its home base of Frankfurt with the Irish carrier announcing 34 new flights from Germany's biggest airport from the 
middle of next year.   Copyright dpa    
Load-Date: September 12, 2017
Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
End of Document
Ryanair Makes Addl. $300 Mln Investment In Frankfurt
Ryanair Makes Addl. $300 Mln Investment In Frankfurt
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
September 12, 2017 Tuesday 11:39 AM GMT
Copyright 2017 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 266 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Irish no-frills airline Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) Tuesday announced additional 
$300 million investment in Frankfurt. The company announced 35 new routes. 
 The company announced an additional three based aircraft worth $300 million, to bring it to a total of 10, worth $1 
billion, at Frankfurt Main airport.  The Frankfurt summer 2018 schedule includes 38 Frankfurt Main routes and 43 
Frankfurt Hahn routes which will deliver over 4.7 million customers per annum through Ryanair's two Frankfurt 
airports next year. This includes 34 new Frankfurt Main routes and 1 new Frankfurt Hahn routes.  The company 
said that German consumers and visitors can book their holidays as far out as October 2018, on even lower fares, 
and enjoy the latest 'Always Getting Better' improvements.  Ryanair will continue to connect Frankfurt with major 
business centres on high frequency, low fare services including Dublin, Madrid and London, on the lowest lower 
fares.  Ryanair's David O'Brien said, 'We are pleased to announce an additional three based aircraft at Frankfurt 
Main to bring it to a total of 10 and an investment of $1billion. We have also launched our Frankfurt summer 2018 
schedule with a total of 81 (35 new) routes to/from both Frankfurt Main and Frankfurt Hahn, which will deliver over 
4.7m customers through the two airports this year.'  The company further said that, as part of Frankfurt summer 
2018 schedule, it is releasing seats for sale from just \xA414.99 for travel in October and November which are 
available for booking until midnight September 14.

Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Given Average Recommendation of "Buy" by Analysts
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Given Average Recommendation of "Buy" 
by Analysts
American Banking and Market News
September 12, 2017 Tuesday
Copyright 2017 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 725 words
Body
Ryanair Holdings PLC logo Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have been assigned an average 
rating of "Buy" from the sixteen ratings firms that are currently  covering the stock,            MarketBeat  reports. Two 
analysts have rated the stock with a sell recommendation, four have assigned  a hold recommendation and ten 
have given a buy recommendation to  the company. The average 12-month price target among brokerages that 
have covered the stock in the last year is $100.33.  
A number of research analysts recently issued reports on the company. BidaskClub downgraded Ryanair Holdings 
PLC from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Friday, August 25th. HSBC Holdings plc upgraded 
Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, July 25th. Sanford C. 
Bernstein assumed coverage on Ryanair Holdings PLC in a research note on Monday, June 26th. They set an 
"underperform" rating and a $83.00 price objective for the company. Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. (The) upgraded 
Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "neutral" rating to a "buy" rating and boosted their price objective for the company 
from $67.56 to $109.00 in a research note on Thursday, June 15th. Finally, ValuEngine  upgraded Ryanair Holdings 
PLC from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, June 6th.  
Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ RYAAY ) opened at 116.31 on Tuesday. The stock has a market 
capitalization of $28.08 billion, a P/E ratio of 16.94 and a beta of 0.61. The stock has a 50 day moving average of 
$115.29 and a 200-day moving average of $101.28. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a one year low of $67.56 and a one 
year high of $122.68.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 24th. The 
transportation company reported $1.78 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the Zacks' consensus 
estimate of $1.48 by $0.30. The company had revenue of $2.10 billion during the quarter, compared to the 
consensus estimate of $2.02 billion. Ryanair Holdings PLC had a return on equity of 34.02% and a net margin of 
21.44%.  Equities analysts forecast that  Ryanair Holdings PLC will post $7.58 earnings per share for the current 
year.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC announced that its Board of Directors has initiated a stock buyback program on Tuesday, 
May 30th that permits the company to buyback  outstanding  shares. This buyback authorization permits the 
transportation company to purchase up to 2.3% of its shares through open market purchases. Shares buyback 
programs are generally a sign that the company's board of directors believes its shares are undervalued.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Given Average Recommendation of "Buy" by Analysts
Institutional investors and hedge funds have recently modified their holdings of the company. Quantbot 
Technologies LP purchased a new stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings PLC during the 1st quarter worth 
approximately $106,000.  Oregon Public Employees Retirement Fund purchased a new stake in shares of  Ryanair 
Holdings PLC during the 2nd quarter worth approximately $108,000.  Mountain Capital Investment Advisors Inc 
purchased a new stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings PLC during the 2nd quarter worth approximately $112,000.  
FNY Partners Fund LP purchased a new stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings PLC during the 1st quarter worth 
approximately $156,000.  Finally, PNC Financial Services Group Inc. raised its holdings in shares of  Ryanair 
Holdings PLC by 5.3% during the 1st quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. now owns 1,941 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $160,000 after acquiring an additional 98 shares in the last quarter. 40.13% 
of the stock is currently owned by institutional investors and hedge funds.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.    
Analyst Recommendations for Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY)

Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 12, 2017 Tuesday 8:24 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 456 words
Byline: Andrew McCathie in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Air Berlin passengers faced fresh chaos on Tuesday after the beleaguered German airline cancelled 100 flights due 
to a surge in the number of pilots reporting sick.
The reason for the cancellations is "an extraordinary number of sick reports in the cockpit," said a spokesman for 
Germany's second-biggest airline, which last month filed for insolvency.
Air Berlin has asked passengers to check the status of their flight on the airline's website prior to their arrival at the 
airport after it said it was cancelling 100 of its scheduled 750 flights for Tuesday.
About 200 of the 1,500 pilots due to fly on Tuesday had called in sick, the airline said.
"Today is a day that the existence of Air Berlin is threatened," wrote Air Berlin chief operations officer Oliver Iffert in 
an internal memo seen by dpa.
In another internal memo seen by dpa, the company's board said that 149 captains and first officers had already 
called in sick for Wednesday.
A spokesman for the airline confirmed that cancellations are expected Wednesday.
Calling it a "pilot revolt," the daily Bild reported that the reason for the jump in the number of pilots claiming to be 
sick was a dispute over their possible transition from the insolvent airline to a potential new buyer.
However, the pilots' union, Vereinigung Cockpit, denied the report, saying: "At no point did the VC call for (pilots) to 
report ill."
Air Berlin said it would offer affected passengers the "best alternative travel" options.
Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
The airline announced on Monday that it had slashed a series of international flights as a result of the need to 
reduce its long-haul operations as part of insolvency proceedings.
This included flights to the Caribbean from the western German city of Dusseldorf to September 24.
The German government was forced last month to provide the airline with a bridging loan of 150 million euros (180 
million dollars) to help it to continue operating.
Potential buyers have until September 15 to lodge offers for the struggling carrier, with Germany's biggest airline 
Lufthansa among bidders seeking to acquire parts of Air Berlin.
German businessman Hans Rudolf Wohrl this week also unveiled a 500-million-euro bid for Air Berlin, which ran up 
a loss last year of about 782 million euros and has debts totalling nearly 1.2 billion euros.
Air Berlin has operated at a loss every year since 2008, except for 2012, when it sold off its frequent flyer 
programme.
In the meantime, budget airline Ryanair stepped up its campaign on Tuesday to take on Lufthansa in its home base 
of Frankfurt with the Irish carrier announcing 34 new flights from Germany's biggest airport from the middle of next 
year.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Anindita Ramaswamy, +49 30 2852-31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 13, 2017
End of Document

Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots

Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
September 12, 2017 Tuesday 8:25 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 458 words
Body
       By Andrew McCathie, dpa   BERLIN (dpa-AFX) - Air Berlin passengers faced fresh chaos on Tuesday after the 
beleaguered German airline cancelled 100 flights due to a surge in the number of pilots reporting sick.  The reason 
for the cancellations is 'an extraordinary number of sick reports in the cockpit,' said a spokesman for Germany's 
second-biggest airline, which last month filed for insolvency.  Air Berlin has asked passengers to check the status of 
their flight on the airline's website prior to their arrival at the airport after it said it was cancelling 100 of its scheduled 
750 flights for Tuesday. 
 About 200 of the 1,500 pilots due to fly on Tuesday had called in sick, the airline said.  'Today is a day that the 
existence of Air Berlin is threatened,' wrote Air Berlin chief operations officer Oliver Iffert in an internal memo seen 
by dpa.  In another internal memo seen by dpa, the company's board said that 149 captains and first officers had 
already called in sick for Wednesday.  A spokesman for the airline confirmed that cancellations are expected 
Wednesday.  Calling it a 'pilot revolt,' the daily Bild reported that the reason for the jump in the number of pilots 
claiming to be sick was a dispute over their possible transition from the insolvent airline to a potential new buyer.  
However, the pilots' union, Vereinigung Cockpit, denied the report, saying: 'At no point did the VC call for (pilots) to 
report ill.'  Air Berlin said it would offer affected passengers the 'best alternative travel' options.  The airline 
announced on Monday that it had slashed a series of international flights as a result of the need to reduce its long-
haul operations as part of insolvency proceedings.  This included flights to the Caribbean from the western German 
city of Dusseldorf to September 24.  The German government was forced last month to provide the airline  with a 
bridging loan of 150 million euros (180 million dollars) to help it to continue operating.  Potential buyers have until 
September 15 to lodge offers for the struggling carrier, with Germany's biggest airline Lufthansa among bidders 
seeking to acquire parts of Air Berlin.  German businessman Hans Rudolf Wohrl this week also unveiled a 500-
million-euro bid for Air Berlin, which ran up a loss last year of about 782 million euros and has debts totalling nearly 
1.2 billion euros.  Air Berlin has operated at a loss every year since 2008, except for 2012, when it sold off its 
frequent flyer programme.  In the meantime, budget airline Ryanair stepped up its campaign on Tuesday to take on 
Lufthansa in its home base of Frankfurt with the Irish carrier announcing 34 new flights from Germany's biggest 
airport from the middle of next year.   Copyright dpa    
Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots

Mass protests against Macron labour law but strike impact limited
Mass protests against Macron labour law but strike impact limited
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 12, 2017 Tuesday 9:16 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 629 words
Byline: Pol O Gradaigh in Paris
Dateline: Paris (dpa) - 
Body
French President Emmanuel Macron's approach to his flagship labour law reforms appeared to be paying off for the 
moment as a one-day strike called by the hardline CGT union had limited impact on Tuesday.
According to the Interior Ministry, at least 223,000 protesters nevertheless took to the streets to decry what CGT 
head Philippe Martinez described as "a law to give full power to employers."
The CGT said 500,000 people had joined some 200 protests countrywide against measures that Macron, for his 
part, argues are needed to give employers the confidence to create new jobs.
Police in Paris said they fired tear gas at some 300 masked protesters who had thrown projectiles at them. The 
Interior Ministry said 13 arrests were made across the country.
The Eiffel Tower closed its lifts and top story due to strikes, allowing only access by stairs to the first floor, while 
Irish airline Ryanair complained that it had had to cancel 110 flights.
Suburban trains in Paris were also disrupted, but most other transport services operated normally, with the other 
two main union groups largely shunning the CGT's call for a one-day strike.
The leader of France's largest union group, Laurent Berger of the CFDT, told France 2 television that the decrees 
unveiled by Prime Minister Edouard Philippe on August 31 were "not a good reform."
But, he argued, the union that engaged with the consultation process led by Labour Minister Muriel Penicaud had 
"succeeded in ensuring that a number of even worse steps were not taken."
The reforms to France's complex and highly protective labour code were a key campaign commitment by Macron, 
who took office in May.
Mass protests against Macron labour law but strike impact limited
He said that businesses needed more flexibility in order to create jobs and reduce an unemployment rate that has 
drifted between 9 and 10.5 per cent since 2010.
The draft decrees announced by Philippe, and due to be formally adopted by the government on September 
22, allow a greater range of working conditions to be agreed at company level rather than sector-wide.
They also allow the smallest companies to negotiate directly with staff or their chosen representatives, rather than 
with unions.
"It's not a labour law, but a law which gives full power to employers," Martinez charged in an interview with 
newspaper Le Parisien on Sunday.
Despite the limited response to the strike call, leftist leader Jean-Luc Melenchon said he was confident Macron 
could be "made to pull back."
"Mr Macron knows that this is a trial of strength and he looked for it. Now it's up to us to rise to the challenge," 
Melenchon said as he joined protests in Marseille.
Melenchon's hard-left La France Insoumise (France Unbowed), despite holding only 17 seats in the 577-strong 
National Assembly, has managed to win the limelight as Macron's most determined opponent.
It has called its own day of protest for September 23, while the CGT is planning to take to the streets again on 
September 21.
As the Paris march dispersed at the city's southern Place d'Italie, one GCT official argued that they had not 
expected that one day of protest would be enough, but it was a good start.
"There aren't just activists here," Veronique Pascalides of the union's public finance branch told dpa. "It's a very 
good day for the start back after the summer holidays."
The protests were taking place as Macron travelled to the French Caribbean to visit the islands of Saint Martin and 
Saint Barthelemy, devastated last week by Hurricane Irma.
A day ahead of the protests, the president doubled down on controversial comments on Friday describing 
opponents of the reform as "idlers."
The phrase referred to "all those who think that we can do nothing, that we have that luxury," he told reporters.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, +49 30 285231472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 13, 2017
End of Document
Macron tactics pay off as protests against French labour law limited
Macron tactics pay off as protests against French labour law limited
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 12, 2017 Tuesday 8:55 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 633 words
Byline: Pol O Gradaigh in Paris
Dateline: Paris (dpa) - 
Body
President Emmanuel Macron's approach to his flagship labour law reforms appeared to be paying off for the 
moment as a one-day strike called by the hardline CGT union had limited impact on Tuesday.
Tens of thousands nevertheless took to the streets to decry what CGT head Philippe Martinez described as "a law 
to give full power to employers."
The CGT claimed 500,000 people had joined some 200 protests across the country against measures that Macron, 
for his part, argues are needed to give employers the confidence to create new jobs.
In Paris, police estimated the crowd at 24,000, while public broadcaster Franceinfo quoted the CGT as saying 
60,000 took part.
Police said they fired tear gas at some 300 masked protesters who had thrown projectiles at them, and made four 
arrests.
The Eiffel Tower closed its lifts and top story due to strikes, allowing only access by stairs to the first floor, while 
Irish airline Ryanair complained that it had had to cancel 110 flights.
Suburban trains in Paris were also disrupted, but most other transport services operated normally, with the other 
two main union groups largely shunning the CGT's call for a one-day strike.
The leader of France's largest union group, Laurent Berger of the CFDT, told France 2 television that the decrees 
unveiled by Prime Minister Edouard Philippe on August 31 were "not a good reform."
But, he argued, the union that engaged with the consultation process led by Labour Minister Muriel Penicaud had 
"succeeded in ensuring that a number of even worse steps were not taken."
Macron tactics pay off as protests against French labour law limited
The reforms to France's complex and highly protective labour code were a key campaign commitment by Macron, 
who took office in May.
He said that businesses needed more flexibility in order to create jobs and reduce an unemployment rate that has 
drifted between 9 and 10.5 per cent since 2010.
The draft decrees announced by Philippe, and due to be formally adopted by the government on September 
22, allow a greater range of working conditions to be agreed at company level rather than sector-wide.
They also allow the smallest companies to negotiate directly with staff or their chosen representatives, rather than 
with unions.
"It's not a labour law, but a law which gives full power to employers," Martinez charged in an interview with 
newspaper Le Parisien on Sunday.
Despite the limited turnout, Jean-Luc Melenchon, leader of the hard-left La France Insoumise (France Unbowed) 
party said he was confident Macron could be "made to pull back."
"Mr Macron knows that this is a trial of strength and he looked for it. Now it's up to us to rise to the challenge," 
Melenchon said as he joined protests in Marseille.
La France Insoumise, despite holding only 17 seats in the 577-strong National Assembly, has managed to win the 
limelight as Macron's most determined opponent.
It has called its own day of protest for September 23, while the CGT is planning to take to the streets again on 
September 21.
As the Paris march dispersed at the city's southern Place d'Italie, one GCT official argued that they had not 
expected that one day of protest would be enough, but it was a good start.
"There aren't just activists here," Veronique Pascalides of the union's public finance branch told dpa. "It's a very 
good day for the start back after the summer holidays."
The protests were taking place as Macron travelled to the French Caribbean to visit the islands of Saint Martin and 
Saint Barthelemy, devastated last week by Hurricane Irma.
A day ahead of the protests, the president doubled down on controversial comments on Friday describing 
opponents of the reform as "idlers."
The phrase referred to "all those who think that we can do nothing, that we have that luxury," he told reporters.
