THIS WEEK in Brexit: Blame, animosity creep into negotiations
THIS WEEK in Brexit: Blame, animosity creep into negotiations
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 1, 2017 Friday 5:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 542 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London and Naveena Kottoor in Brussels
Dateline: London/Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
EU and British officials have held perhaps their most disappointing round of talks so far, ending four days of 
meetings with no sign of progress, recriminations on both sides, and little prospect of a smooth resolution to the 
negotiations.
- William Hague, a former leader of British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party, warned that he 
expected "BIG BUST-UPS" during the months of negotiations until Britain officially leaves the European Union in 
March 2019.
Hague told the BBC that May's negotiating position had been weakened by her poor performance in a snap general 
election in June, when the Conservatives lost their majority in parliament. "We'll end up having to PAY MORE," he 
said. "We'll pay a bigger price for leaving, I think, because of the uncertainties of the election result."
- May was occupied for most of the week with a trade-focused visit to JAPAN, one of several major economies her 
government has targeted for expanded post-Brexit trade and investment. She promised to work to "unblock 
remaining barriers to trade and take steps to build the closest, freest trading relationship between the UK and Japan 
after Brexit."
May told reporters in Japan that she was "NOT A QUITTER" and would lead the Conservatives into another 
election in 2022, despite the pressure that has mounted on her over the June election campaign and criticisms of 
her Brexit policies.
- Michael O'LEARY, the colourful, pro-EU chief executive of budget airline Ryanair, accused May of "swanning 
around Japan drinking tea and sake" instead of handling the Brexit negotiations. "I fail to see what she's doing in 
Japan for three days at the moment, why she's not in Brussels or in Frankfurt or in Paris, which is where these 
negotiations need to take place," O'Leary told Sky News.
THIS WEEK in Brexit: Blame, animosity creep into negotiations
- Meanwhile in Brussels, top negotiators from the EU and Britain met for their third official round of negotiations. But 
as the week progressed the tone among EU officials started sounding increasingly IRRITATED.
- On Monday, before heading into his first meeting the EU's chief negotiator Michel BARNIER said he was 
"concerned." "We must start negotiating seriously," he said pointing to a tight timetable.
- On Tuesday Barnier's boss, Jean-Claude JUNCKER, sounded unimpressed by the position papers put forward by 
the British government in recent weeks. "I did read with the requisite attention all the papers produced by the 
majesty's government and none of those are actually satisfactory," Juncker said.
- At Thursday's closing press conference Barnier did not try very hard to mask his FRUSTRATION with his British 
counterparts. The two sides "did not make any decisive progress," he said.
Barnier warned Britain that, given the STALEMATE on all major issues, discussions on a future trade and economic 
relationship between the EU and Britain were unlikely to go ahead in October as hoped by the British government.
- British Brexit Secretary David DAVIS acknowledged "significant differences to be bridged," especially over a 
financial settlement on what Britain owes the bloc, adding that his government had a duty to its taxpayers to 
interrogate any final financial payment rigorously.
Editorial contactsEditing by: William Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 2, 2017
End of Document
Latam 2017: Flybondi seeks more mid-life 737s on lease
Latam 2017: Flybondi seeks more mid-life 737s on lease
AirFinance Journal
September 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 262 words
Byline: Laura Mueller
Body
Argentina&acute;s first ultra low-cost cost carrier, Flybondi, is looking to secure two additional Boeing 737-800 
leases by the end of the week, following huge interest in the start-up airline.
“We have been overwhelmed with interest from lessors and there is not a week that goes by that some leasing 
company doesn’t come by to talk to us,” said Julian Cook, chief executive officer of Flybondi, at Airfinance Journal’s 
Latin American Aviation Finance event in Rio. ”We have secured three aircraft with SMBC Aviation Capital already 
and we hope to sign another two at this conference.”
Cook, the former CEO of Swiss airline Flybaboo, says the carrier has been offered “brand new aircraft at very 
attractive lease rates” but has chosen to opt for eight-to-12-year-old aircraft instead. “It is unusual to be offered new 
aircraft as a start-up, so we reviewed the deal and decided to stick with mid-life aircraft.”
Flybondi wants to operate 10 Boeing 737-800 fleet by the end of 2018.
It has raised $75 million of additional start-up capital and has been granted 85 routes by the Argentinian 
government, which include 43 domestic and 42 international destinations.
The company plans to start its operations in the fourth quarter of 2017 with 737-800s configured with 189 seats. By 
2021 it is targeting a fleet of 30 aircraft.
Investors in Flybondi include Cartesian Capital , Yamasa, Michael Cawley (former COO at Ryanair), Michael Powell 
(former CFO at Wizz Air), as well as other European and Argentinian private investors.
Load-Date: October 2, 2017
End of Document
Mass sick day threatens Air Berlin sale
Mass sick day threatens Air Berlin sale
AirFinance Journal
September 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 252 words
Byline: alex derber
Body
Air Berlin pilots have jeopardised a potential sale of the insolvent carrier by taking sick days en masse, the airline’s 
management has said.
The German airline was forced to cancel 100 out of 750 flights yesterday when 200 of its 1,500 pilots called in sick 
either during crew briefing or on the way to the aircraft.
Air Berlin chief executive officer Thomas Winkelmann accused the pilots of “playing with fire”.
“Today [12 September) has cost us several million euros. We are currently conducting final talks with potential 
investors. It is essential that operations be stable in order for these negotiations to go well. That is the only way to 
secure as many jobs as possible.”
Pilots union Vereinigung Cockpit expressed surprise at the walkout, which it said it did not call for, and requested 
those pilots not genuinely sick to return to duty.
Several airlines, including Lufthansa, Easyjet and Ryanair, have expressed interest in buying parts of Airberlin’s 
operations and the deadline for investors’ offers is this Friday (15 September).
However, Frank Kebekus, Air Berlin’s chief representative, said that further walkouts could cause the airline to 
cease operations and any restructuring efforts.
“Today’s [12 September’s] events seriously endanger the entire insolvency proceedings under self-administration,” 
Kebekus said. AirBerlin’s creditor’s committee aims to make concrete decisions about its restructuring by 21 
September.
Load-Date: October 2, 2017
End of Document
Easyjet offers transatlantic connections via Gatwick
Easyjet offers transatlantic connections via Gatwick
AirFinance Journal
September 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 329 words
Byline: alex derber
Body
Easyjet is tapping into the long-haul, low-cost market by offering connecting services to transatlantic Norwegian and 
Westjet flights through London Gatwick airport.
Users of its new ‘Worldwide by easyJet’ service will be able to book both the Easyjet and partner airline portions of 
a flight on the Easyjet website.
Connecting flights will be separated by at least 2.5 hours to give passengers time to transfer, and although Easyjet 
won’t hold back flights for connecting travellers, those who miss flights will be transferred to the next available 
service. "The way we have designed Worldwide by easyJet means that we can profitably access a major new pool 
of customers without undermining easyJet’s operating model and punctuality,” says Peter Duffy, Easyjet’s chief 
commercial officer.   Although Easyjet bills the move as “the first global airline connections service by a European 
low fares airline”, rival Ryanair sells 20 Air Europa long-haul routes from Madrid via its own website.   The low-cost 
carrier suffered a pre-tax loss of &pound;212 million ($281 million) in the first half of the year, after which it said it 
would seek to develop additional revenue streams by “exploring new distribution channels, partner agreements and 
structures such as connectivity”.   At Gatwick it had already identified 200,000 passengers who self-connected to 
other airlines each year.
“Many of our guests already self-connect between WestJet and easyJet flights, and this new booking tool will make 
it easier than ever before to travel throughout Europe from Canada and back,” says Ed Sims, WestJet’s executive 
vice-president, commercial. Easyjet wants to expand its connecting service to other airlines at other hubs such as 
Milan Malpensa, Geneva, Amsterdam, Paris Charles De Gaulle and Barcelona.   Scottish regional carrier Loganair 
is already signed up to offer onward travel from Scottish airports.
Load-Date: October 2, 2017
End of Document
Hard to see all the Max variants surviving: Plueger
Hard to see all the Max variants surviving: Plueger
AirFinance Journal
September 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 385 words
Byline: Jack Dutton
Body
John Plueger, chief executive of ALC, does not see spacein the market for all of Boeing’s 737 Max variants – the 
Max 7, 8, 9, 10 and 200.
“It's hard to see all of those variants surviving,” he says in an interview with Airfinance Journal. “Certainly, the Max 8 
will, it’s the absolute bread and butter airplane, fabulous, one of our mainstay airplanes.”
Plueger adds: “But I think the tough part is that the Max 200, which so far, a pretty isolated airplane. It's a Ryanair 
airplane.”
Ryanair ordered 100 Max 200s with options for a further 100 aircraft in September 2014.
However, Plueger says “the real question is between the 9 and the 10” variants.
Boeing launched the Max 10 at the 2017 Paris air show, garnering 240 commitments from more than 10 customers.
Although he congratulates Boeing on launching of the programme, Plueger says he is not yet convinced by it.
“When an airplane gets launched, there’s also a lot of incentives provided by the airframer to get it launched. Those 
incentives have been spread around. We’re waiting to see how many more customers come along in the non-
launch phase.”
He adds: “We are mainly concerned about whether the Max 9 and Max 10 ultimately in the market place whether 
both models will survive. A lot of the fundamental issues we’ve had before the launch are still there. Having said 
that, it’s a successful launch and we will react to what we see our airline customers needing and wanting.”
He adds that should the programme gain further momentum, ALC would be happy to make an order, but notes the 
strong success of the A321neo. The US lessor has 55 A321LRs on order.
Other lessors have been vociferous about the Max programme. For example, a white paper issued by Avolon in 
mid-August said that Boeing had been “too reactive” with the 737 Max programme and made too many variants of 
the aircraft type.
Hard to see all the Max variants surviving: Plueger
Plueger adds that despite the summer insolvencies of Air Berlin and Alitalia, he has no big concerns about the 
health of the industry.
He says that IATAtraffic continues to be very strong and those figures do not include some of the large low-cost 
carriers, including Ryanair and Southwest, Airlines, so are actually conservative traffic figures.

Brexit and airlines: above the clouds; Twitter: @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Brexit and airlines: above the clouds; Twitter: @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Financial Times (London, England)
September 1, 2017 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 12
Length: 318 words
Body
The hero in the film The Terminal spent a lot of time in an airport, unable to enter the country or leave it. Those 
monitoring the UK's interminable Brexit negotiations may sympathise. Hard to go forward, even trickier to go back. 
One area of conflict, though, may get more attention sooner: air travel within the EU. Expect a compromise, given 
the high stakes.
The market focuses on three factors: European traffic rights, ownership rules and sterling. The last, which directly 
hits sales and profits, has already registered. Sterling's tradeweighted rate has dropped 15 per cent since last 
summer's referendum, hurting easyJet in particular.
The other two may not have sunk in.
An open skies agreement enables UK-registered airlines to fly to, from and within Europe. Technically, leaving the 
EU means quitting the agreement - and without a replacement treaty, warns Ryanair's Michael O'Leary, flights 
between the UK and EU could be grounded. That seems far-fetched. Other countries would object; almost 70m UK 
passengers fly to Spain annually, a fifth of its EU air traffic, says Frontier Economics. Cutting off the UK might not 
suit Air France-KLM either. The Dutch half profits from UK passengers transferring through Amsterdam's airport.
EU rules require airlines flying within Europe to be European www.owned.No problem now, but troublesome once 
UK investors no longer count as "European". Ryanair thinks it can manage any shortfall by buying stock back from 
US or UK investors, while Stelios Haji-Ioannou, a big shareholder in easyJet (and its new Austriaregistered 
European subsidiary), has dual UK and Cypriot nationality. But neither they nor British Airways owner IAG can be 
certain there will be no issues.
Brexit and airlines: above the clouds; Twitter: @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Still, for all Mr O'Leary's warnings, it is hard to believe that either airlines or governments want cessation of UK-EU 
traffic. Expect more soothing noises about air travel in the months ahead.
Load-Date: August 31, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair launches Back To School Seat Sale
Ryanair launches Back To School Seat Sale
Business World (Digest)
September 01, 2017 Friday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved

Length: 155 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Ryanair yesterday launched a huge seat sale across its network, with 20% off up to 2 million seats for travel from 
November to January, allowing customers to book their winter getaway on the lowest fares.   Discounted seats are 
available right across Ryanair’s network – the biggest in Europe – covering 33 countries and over 1,800 routes. The 
offer will end at midnight (24:00hrs) on Sunday, 3rd September.   Commenting on the offer, Ryanair’s Kenny 
Jacobs said, "Parents everywhere are sad/relieved/overjoyed to see their children heading back to school this 
week, and to congratulate themselves for surviving a summer with their little bundles of joy/terror around the house, 
it’s the perfect time to be planning a winter break – with or without the kids! We’ve launched a massive seat sale, 
with 20% off up to 2 million seats for travel from November 1st – December 15th and from January 8th – 31st."

Ryanair bases more aircraft in Frankfurt
Ryanair bases more aircraft in Frankfurt
AirFinance Journal
September 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 131 words
Byline: Alex Derber
Body
Ryanair is to invest an extra $300 million in airports serving Germany’s financial hub of Frankfurt.
Almost all of the new money will go into Frankfurt Main airport, where the Dublin-based carrier will base an 
additional three aircraft, while Ryanair will also launch a new route from Frankfurt Hahn.
Next summer Ryanair will have 10 aircraft based at Main and five at Hahn.
Frankfurt is one of several European cities vying for a piece of London’s financial services market in the wake of the 
UK’s decision to leave the European Union.
Ryanair has warned it will move some or all of its UK-based aircraft to continental Europe from April 2019 unless 
there is certainty about the legal basis for the operation of flights between the UK and the European Union by 
autumn 2018.

Millar to leave Stellwagen
AirFinance Journal
September 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 160 words
Byline: Olivier Bonnassies
Body
Former Ryanair CFO Howard Millar is to leave Stellwagen Capital, a subsidiary of Aviation Finance Company 
(AFC).
Millar was appointed chief operating officer of Stellwagen Group, the holding company of AFC and Seraph Aviation 
Management, and chief executive of Stellwagen Capital, in May 2016.
Stellwagen has appointed Scott Cormanto the role of chief executive officer of Stellwagen Capital, effective 
immediately.
David Butler has also joined as chief operating officer of the group, effective 1 October, 2017.
Prior to joining the Group as part of the ECN Capital transaction, Corman served as an executive managing 
director, leading the firm’s expansion into structured finance services in both the rail and aircraftmarkets. He 
previously spent 13 years as head of the transportation asset finance team at Credit Suisse in New York.
Butler previously spent more than a decade at Digicel, a provider of mobile services, enterprise solutions and cloud 
computing.

Ryanair to bid to operate 90 Alitalia planes
Ryanair to bid to operate 90 Alitalia planes
Business World (Digest)
August 31, 2017 Thursday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: EU
Length: 290 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair will bid to operate 90 planes under the Alitalia brand and using existing staff as part of the Italian airline's 
restructuring, Chief Executive Michael O'Leary said today.
Ryanair has until Oct. 2 to make a binding bid for all or part of the Italian carrier, which has been put under special 
administration for the second time in less than a decade.
"We will be submitting an offer for the 90 jet aircraft, with their pilots, cabin crew, routes etc," O'Leary told journalists 
at a press briefing in London.
Ryanair would operate the 90 leased planes using existing staff, but the offer would be dependent on some 
redundancies, changes to staff conditions and renegotiation of the leases, he said.
As Ryanair exclusively uses Boeing planes, Alitalia staff would be required to maintain the 90 Airbus planes, he 
said. Ryanair, which only currently operates short-haul routes, would also take on long-haul routes under the deal, 
O'Leary said.
"I think one of the aspects of Alitalia that is really attractive is the long haul fleet. There is the capacity to grow very 
strongly," he said.
Ryanair would be interested in bidding for the whole of Alitalia, which has around 120 planes, but such a deal would 
likely be blocked by regulators as it would leave Ryanair in control of over 50% of the Italian market, O'Leary said.
"We'd be very willing to buy Alitalia. But I suspect... given we're the number one airline in Italy we'd be blocked 
under EU competition rules," he said.
Ryanair to bid to operate 90 Alitalia planes
Ryanair is one of around 10 parties that has expressed an interest in a bid for all or part of the carrier.
O'Leary said Alitalia would likely be broken up whoever buys it and that any takeover would include competition 
remedies. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: October 8, 2017

Ryanair boss slams May for 'drinking tea and sake' amid Brexit talks
Ryanair boss slams May for 'drinking tea and sake' amid Brexit talks
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 31, 2017 Thursday 11:28 AM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 236 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Outspoken Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary on Thursday accused British Prime Minister Theresa May of 
"swanning around Japan drinking tea and sake" instead of handling her country's Brexit negotiations in Europe.
"I fail to see what she's doing in Japan for three days at the moment, why she's not in Brussels or in Frankfurt or in 
Paris, which is where these negotiations need to take place," the head of the Ireland-based budget airline told Sky 
News.
"She's just come back from three weeks' holidays in the Swiss Alps," he told the broadcaster.
"Now, everybody is entitled to their holidays, but there's a crisis coming down the road here in the UK economy in 
the next 12 months.
"Brexit is going to be a disaster for the UK economy, and she needs to be over there negotiating, or at least 
removing these roadblocks, not swanning around Japan drinking tea and sake."
O'Leary said he felt the Brexit negotiations, which are continuing in Brussels this week, were "going nowhere."
"They are a bit of a shambles, and they need a bit of leadership," he said.
"From an aviation perspective, the real challenge for us is, because there's no fallback in aviation - we're not 
covered by WTO rules - there is going to be a cessation of flights from March 2019 if she doesn't get her finger out 
and get a deal done in the next 12 months."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, +49 30 285231472, <international@dpa.com;

       LONDON (dpa-AFX) - Outspoken Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary on Thursday accused British Prime

negotiations in Europe.  'I fail to see what she's doing in Japan for three days at the moment, why she's not in

 'She's just come back from three weeks' holidays in the Swiss Alps,' he told the broadcaster.  'Now, everybody is 
entitled to their holidays, but there's a crisis coming down the road here in the UK economy in the next 12 months.    
'Brexit is going to be a disaster for the UK economy, and she needs to be over there negotiating, or at least 
removing these roadblocks, not swanning around Japan drinking tea and sake.'  O'Leary said he felt the Brexit

Ryanair to bid for Alitalia 's jets: O'Leary Ryanair intends to make a firm bid to acquire Alitalia 's fleet of jets, 
chief executive Michael O'Leary has indica....
Ryanair to bid for Alitalia's jets: O'Leary; Ryanair intends to make a firm bid 
to acquire Alitalia's fleet of jets, chief executive Michael O'Leary has 
indicated.
Flight International
August 31, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 452 words
Body
Ryanair intends to make a firm bid to acquire Alitalia's fleet of jets, chief executive Michael O'Leary has indicated.
Speaking at a press conference in London today, O'Leary said he intended to make a bid for some 90 Alitalia jets 
by the first week of October, which brings the next phase of the Italian carrier's sale process.
"We would be willing to take on both the short-haul and the long-haul [fleet]," O'Leary says. "One of the aspects of 
Alitalia that is really attractive is the long-haul fleet, which has the capacity to grow very strongly."
He says that all-Boeing operator Ryanair would not have a problem with adding Airbus aircraft and their crews and 
engineers, noting: "We bid previously for Aer Lingus three times – they have only Airbus jets. [When] you bid for an 
airline, it might have Airbus aircraft, but it also has Airbus pilots, Airbus engineers."
O'Leary adds: "We do not have the aircraft to go and replace all of Alitalia's fleet tomorrow, or in one year, or in two 
years, so we would be very willing to buy Alitalia."
Ryanair will not be bidding for the Alitalia's turboprop fleet, in which O'Leary says his airline has no interest. He 
admits that the process of acquiring the jets is "complicated" because the majority of Alitalia's fleet is leased not 
owned.
"The jets are all leased, so we would want those leases, but clearly we want the bankruptcy administrator to 
restructure the leases," he says.
Flight Fleets Analyzer data lists 103 aircraft in Alitalia's inventory. These comprise 72 Airbus A320-family jets 
(including two in storage), 14 A330s, 11 Boeing 777-200ERs and four ATR 72-500 turboprops. Just eight of the 
aircraft are owned by Alitalia: seven A320-family narrowbodies and one 777. The rest are leased.
Ryanair to bid for Alitalia 's jets: O'Leary Ryanair intends to make a firm bid to acquire Alitalia 's fleet of jets, 
chief executive Michael O'Leary has indica....
O'Leary says Ryanair would seek to continue operating the aircraft under Alitalia's "great" brand.
However, O'Leary believes the prospect of Ryanair succeeding in its bid are slim, citing the likelihood that a merger 
would be blocked under EU competition rules. He estimates that Ryanair has 35% of the Italian aviation market and 
that a merger with Alitalia would give it 55%.
O'Leary sees it as more likely that Alitalia will be "broken up" and that Ryanair will benefit in terms of air traffic rights 
and airport slots because "whoever buys them [Alitalia], there will be competition remedies".
Alitalia was put up for sale earlier this year after filing for insolvency protection. Airlines have until 15 September to 
submit an expression of interest in making a binding bid. The airline's special commissioners will then consider 
those offers and notify parties that have met the "requirements". Those shortlisted will have until 2 October to 
submit a binding offer.
Load-Date: September 1, 2017
End of Document
Market Chatter: Ryanair Will Bid to Operate 90 Planes Under Alitalia Brand
Market Chatter: Ryanair Will Bid to Operate 90 Planes Under Alitalia Brand
MT Newswires Live Briefs
August 31, 2017 Thursday 7:52 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 153 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) plans to bid to operate 90 planes under the Alitalia brand using existing staff as part of 
the Italian airline's restructuring, Reuters reported, citing comments made by CEO Michael O'Leary at an event in 
London.
The report said Ryanair has until Oct. 2 to make a binding bid for all or part of the Italian airline, which is under 
special administration.
Meanwhile, in a regulatory filing on Wednesday, Ryanair called on the German antitrust regulator, the 
Bundeskartellamt, and the European Commission to block a deal under which Deutsche Lufthansa would buy up 
insolvent Air Berlin assets. 
It said if Lufthansa gets to buy Air Berlin, it would move to a "95% monopoly" from a 68% share of the German 
market. 
"Competitor airlines will struggle to get slots in major airports such as Berlin, Hamburg, Frankfurt and Munich, 
where Lufthansa will control over 80% of peak time slots," Ryanair said.

Ryanair chief slams Air Berlin over 'stitch-up'
Ryanair chief slams Air Berlin over 'stitch-up'
City A.M.
August 31, 2017 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 172 words
Byline: MARIA SHEAHAN
Body
RYANAIR will not bid for any assets of insolvent German airline Air Berlin, its chief executive Michael O'Leary said 
yesterday, describing the process as "a stitch-up".
Air Berlin, Germany's secondlargest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection this month after shareholder Etihad 
Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.
O'Leary has complained that the insolvency process was designed to help strengthen leading German airline 
Lufthansa.
"If there was a fair and open process we would get involved but we are not getting involved in this process because 
it's a stitch-up," he told a news conference in Berlin, adding that Ryanair had not been in contact with anyone from 
the German government, Air Berlin or the administrator.
O'Leary said Ryanair had asked German and European antitrust authorities to investigate what he said was a 
"conspiracy" between Air Berlin, Lufthansa and the German government which would lead to higher prices for 
consumers.
Shares in Ryanair closed down 0.96 per cent.
Reuters Ryanair boss O'Leary

 American depository receipts of European stocks were trading 0.16% lower at 133.96 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Wednesday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company Forward Pharma (FWP), and 3D printer

company Grifols (GRFS), up 0.8%, and brewing company AB InBev (BUD), up 0.7%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by Ascendis Pharma (ASND), and 3D printer maker voxeljet (VJET),

pharmaceutical firm GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), which rose 2.7% and  1.1% respectively. They were followed by 
HSBC (HSBC), and Trinity Biotech (TRIB), which were up 0.8% each. 
The decliners in the U.K. and Ireland were led by airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), and Royal Bank of Scotland 
(RBS), which fell 2.7% and 0.9% respectively. They were followed by advertising and public relations firm WPP 
(WPPGY), off 0.7%, and oil company Royal Dutch Shell (RDS), lower 0.6%.

Ryanair calls on Germany's competition authority & EU Commission to block Lufthansa-Air Berlin takeover
Ryanair calls on Germany's competition authority & EU Commission to 
block Lufthansa-Air Berlin takeover
Business World (Digest)
August 30, 2017 Wednesday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: EU
Length: 214 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair today urged the German Bundeskartellamt, Germany's competition authority, and the EU Commission to 
block the takeover of Air Berlin by Lufthansa.
Ryanair claims this deal would allow Lufthansa to take over Air Berlin “debt free”, which they claim “will be in breach 
of all German and EU competition rules”. Ryanair says Lufthansa is a monopoly that has been supported by the 
German Government, by providing €150m of State Aid to the airline.
Ryanair has an 8% share of the German market and last year said it aims to capture a further 12% by 2021. 
Following Air Berlin's collapse, Ryanair has predicted that it will achieve that 20% market share sooner than 2021.
Ryanair also urged all Berliners to vote “Yes” on 24th Sept to keep Tegel Airport open. Michael O’Leary said, “The 
German Bundeskartellamt and the European Commission must block the anti-consumer stitch-up playing out 
between the German Government, Lufthansa and Air Berlin.  Given that the German Government is centrally 
involved in these manoeuvres (loaning €150m), the Bundeskartellamt will be afraid to impose competition rules. On 
this basis, it is vital that the European Commission takes immediate and decisive action to protect German 
consumers from a Lufthansa high fare monopoly.”
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: September 13, 2017
Ryanair calls on Germany's competition authority & EU Commission to block Lufthansa-Air Berlin takeover
End of Document
Ryanair Urges To Block Lufthansa-Air Berlin Deal
Ryanair Urges To Block Lufthansa-Air Berlin Deal
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
August 30, 2017 Wednesday 3:51 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 250 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair Holdings plc. (RYA.L, RYAAY) said it urged the German Bundeskartellamt and 
the EU Commission to block the stitch-up between the German Government, Lufthansa and Air Berlin plc. 
(AIBEF.PK) to carve up Air Berlin's assets, while excluding major competitors and ignoring both competition and 
State Aid rules, and called for immediate action to block this anti-consumer take-over.  This insolvency is being 
timed to allow Lufthansa to take over a debt-free Air Berlin (its major German competitor) which will be in breach of 
all German and EU competition rules, and this Lufthansa monopoly has been supported by the German 
Government providing \xA4150m of State Aid, so that Lufthansa can acquire Air Berlin, as Lufthansa moves from a 
68% share to a 95% monopoly, which will result in German customers and visitors suffering higher air fares. 
Competitor airlines will struggle to get slots in major airports such as Berlin, Hamburg, Frankfurt and Munich, where 
Lufthansa will control over 80% of peak time slots.   Ryanair also urged all Berliners to vote 'Yes' on 24th Sept to 
keep Tegel Airport open. The new Brandenburg Airport will have a capacity of only 27m passengers, which is less 
than Dublin (a city with one-third of Berlin's population).   With almost 33m passengers already travelling through 
Berlin's 2 existing Schonefeld and Tegel airports last year, the planned closure of Tegel will leave Berlin with less 
airport capacity than its existing traffic.

Ryanair running out of hope for Air Berlin deal
Ryanair running out of hope for Air Berlin deal
City A.M.
August 30, 2017 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 215 words
Byline: ILONA WISSENBACH
Body
RYANAIR is not hopeful that its complaint to competition authorities over plans by Lufthansa to take over parts of 
insolvent rival Air Berlin will halt the deal, its chief commercial officer said yesterday.
The Irish budget airline has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the 
insolvency process, which it described as a "conspiracy" because it believes that Lufthansa will gain a bigger share 
of the German market.
"This would not be allowed in any other European country, we have of course made a complaint to the German 
cartel office and the European Commission," David O'Brien said.
"We shall see what happens but we are not entirely hopeful."
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary said last week that the Irish group would also be interested in bidding for 
the whole of Air Berlin, but O'Brien said the Lufthansa bid would probably succeed.
Ryanair's chief marketing officer, Kenny Jacobs, said yesterday that the group is still interested in some assets 
belonging to Air Berlin, "principally the routes that we could make work well".
"We're interested in the process running the way the process should run," Jacobs added.
At least six bidders for Air Berlin's assets are reported to be preparing to submit offers by the 15 September 
deadline.
Reuters

Ryanair won't bid for Air Berlin in 'stitch-up' bankruptcy, says CEO
Ryanair won't bid for Air Berlin in 'stitch-up' bankruptcy, says CEO
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 30, 2017 Wednesday 5:48 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 163 words
Byline: Theresa Muench in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair does not plan to bid for any assets belonging to the insolvent German carrier Air Berlin, chief 
executive Michael O'Leary said on Wednesday.
"We will not get involved in this process: it's a stitch-up," O' Leary said in reference to the charge that the insolvency 
process is designed to help strengthen German airline Lufthansa.
Air Berlin filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this month after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad 
Airways, withdrew funding in response to years of financial losses.
The German government has provided the company with a temporary credit of 150 million euros (176 million 
dollars) to help it continue operating for around three more months.
German flagship carrier Lufthansa has expressed an interest in buying a large share of assets in the bankrupt 
airline. Air Berlin officials are also in talks with two other interested parties.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 31, 2017
End of Document

dpa-AFX International ProFeed
August 30, 2017 Wednesday 5:50 PM GMT

       BERLIN (dpa-AFX) - Budget airline Ryanair does not plan to bid for any assets belonging to the insolvent 
German carrier Air Berlin, chief executive Michael O'Leary said on Wednesday.  'We will not get involved in this 
process: it's a stitch-up,' O' Leary said in reference to the charge that the insolvency process is designed to help 
strengthen German airline Lufthansa.  Air Berlin filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this month after its main

German government has provided the company with a temporary credit of 150 million euros (176 million dollars) to

interest in buying a large share of assets in the bankrupt airline. Air Berlin officials are also in talks with two other

Air Berlin confirms deadline for bids Potential buyers of Air Berlin have until 15 September to submit their 
offers, the carrier has confirmed.
Air Berlin confirms deadline for bids; Potential buyers of Air Berlin have 
until 15 September to submit their offers, the carrier has confirmed.
Flight International
August 30, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 150 words
Body
Potential buyers of Air Berlin have until 15 September to submit their offers, the carrier has confirmed.
"Air Berlin will complete the investor process quickly," says the Oneworld member, which filed for insolvency earlier 
this month after shareholder Etihad signalled it was ending financial support.
Since then a number of airlines have either expressed an interest in acquiring all or part of Air Berlin or submitted a 
formal bid, including Lufthansa, Ryanair, TUI and German turnaround specialist Intro Group. EasyJet has also been 
linked with the process.
Separately, a regional court in Berlin says it will convene on 15 September to hear a complaint from Germania that 
a 150 million ($176 million) being provided to Air Berlin by the German government breaches European state-aid 
rules.
The court says Germania has called for the loan to be frozen until the European Commission gives its consent.
Load-Date: September 5, 2017

Ryanair to add five routes from Dublin next summer Ryanair has disclosed plans to operate a handful of new 
routes from Dublin next summer.
Ryanair to add five routes from Dublin next summer; Ryanair has disclosed 
plans to operate a handful of new routes from Dublin next summer.
Flight International
August 29, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 120 words
Body
Ryanair has disclosed plans to operate a handful of new routes from Dublin next summer.
The budget airline says it will fly twice a week to Marrakech, twice a day to Munich, five times a week to Naples, 
twice a week to Paphos and daily to Stuttgart from the Irish capital, starting March 2018. Ryanair is also increasing 
the frequency of its Dublin-Hamburg service.
FlightGlobal schedules data indicates that the carrier previously served Marrakech from Dublin but stopped in 
March. The Moroccan route is not operated by any other scheduled carrier.
Irish flag carrier Aer Lingus flies to Naples, Munich and Stuttgart from Dublin. Lufthansa and Transavia also operate 
the Munich route.
Dublin currently has no air link to Paphos.

Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.28% higher at 134.73 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Monday.

equipment company Edap (EDAP), which rose 10.7% and 1.8% respectively. They were followed by healthcare 
company Novo Nordisk (NVO), and biopharmaceutical company Forward Pharma (FWP), which were up 1.2% and

The decliners in continental Europe were led by CGG (CGG), a manufacturer of geophysical equipment, and 
biopharmaceutical firm Zealand Pharma (ZEAL), which fell 2.6% and 1.5% respectively. They were followed by 
VEON Com (VEON), a provider of communications services, and online hotel search platform Trivago (TRVG), 
which lost 1.2% and 0.7%.

and Verona Pharma (VRNA), which rose 4% and 0.8% respectively. They were followed by airline operator Ryanair 
(RYAAY), and Trinity Biotech (TRIB), which were up 0.8% each.
The decliners in the U.K. and Ireland were led by biopharmaceutical company Midatech Pharma (MTP), and 
construction materials supplier CRH (CRH), which fell 2.1% and 0.3% respectively. They were followed by bank 
Barclays (BCS), and oil company Royal Dutch Shell (RDS), each of which were down 0.1%.

Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have been trending somewhat positive on Monday, according to Accern. The 
research firm identifies positive and negative news coverage by reviewing more than twenty million blog and news 
sources in real-time. Accern ranks coverage of companies on a scale of -1 to 1, with scores closest to one being the 
most favorable. 
Ryanair Holdings PLC earned a news sentiment score of 0.05 on Accern's scale. Accern also gave news articles 
about the transportation company an impact score of 45.867425360137 out of 100, indicating that recent news 
coverage is somewhat unlikely to have an effect on the company's share price in the immediate future.  Here are 
some of the media stories that may have effected Accern's rankings:  Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1]) 
opened at 113.32 on Monday. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a one year low of $67.56 and a one year high of $122.68.   
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 24th. The 
transportation company reported $1.78 earnings per share for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of $1.48 
by $0.30. Ryanair Holdings PLC had a net margin of 21.44% and a return on equity of 34.02%. The company had 
revenue of $2.10 billion for the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $2.02 billion. Analysts anticipate that 
Ryanair Holdings PLC will post $7.58 EPS for the current year.  Ryanair Holdings PLC announced that its Board of 
Directors has authorized a stock repurchase program on Tuesday, May 30th that allows the company to repurchase 
outstanding shares. This repurchase authorization allows the transportation company to reacquire up to 2.3% of its 
stock through open market purchases. Stock repurchase programs are usually a sign that the company's board 
believes its stock is undervalued.  A number of brokerages have weighed in on RYAAY. UBS AG lowered shares of 
Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'buy' rating to a 'neutral' rating in a research report on Friday, June 2nd. BidaskClub 
lowered shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research report on Friday. 
ValuEngine[2] upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'hold' rating to a 'buy' rating in a research report on 
Tuesday, June 6th. HSBC Holdings plc upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'hold' rating to a 'buy' 
rating in a research report on Tuesday, July 25th. Finally, Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. (The) upgraded shares of 
Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'neutral' rating to a 'buy' rating and raised their target price for the company from 
$67.56 to $109.00 in a research report on Thursday, June 15th. Two research analysts have rated the stock with a 
sell rating, four have assigned a hold rating and ten have issued a buy rating to the company's stock. The company

Aug 27, 2017( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Ryanair Holdings PLC 
(NASDAQ: RYAAY) and SkyWest (NASDAQ:SKYW) are both transportation companies, but which is the better 
stock? We will contrast the two companies based on the strength of their dividends, valuation, risk, institutional 
ownership, analyst recommendations, earnings and profitability.  Dividends SkyWest pays an annual dividend of 
$0.32 per share and has a dividend yield of 0.9%. Ryanair Holdings PLC does not pay a dividend. 
SkyWest pays out -11.3% of its earnings in the form of a dividend.   Profitability This table compares Ryanair 
Holdings PLC and SkyWest's net margins, return on equity and return on assets. Analyst Ratings This is a 
breakdown of recent ratings for Ryanair Holdings PLC and SkyWest, as reported by MarketBeat.  Ryanair Holdings 
PLC currently has a consensus price target of $96.00, suggesting a potential downside of 15.28%. SkyWest has a 
consensus price target of $41.50, suggesting a potential upside of 21.35%. Given SkyWest's stronger consensus 
rating and higher possible upside, analysts clearly believe SkyWest is more favorable than Ryanair Holdings PLC. 
Volatility and Risk Ryanair Holdings PLC has a beta of 0.61, indicating that its share price is 39% less volatile than 
the S...00. Comparatively, SkyWest has a beta of 1.72, indicating that its share price is 72% more volatile than the 
S...00.  Institutional ...sider Ownership 38.7% of Ryanair Holdings PLC shares are owned by institutional investors. 
Comparatively, 90.3% of SkyWest shares are owned by institutional investors. 3.5% of SkyWest shares are owned 
by company insiders. Strong institutional ownership is an indication that hedge funds, large money managers and 
endowments believe a stock will outperform the market over the long term. Valuation and Earnings This table 
compares Ryanair Holdings PLC and SkyWest's revenue, earnings per share (EPS) and valuation. SkyWest has 
higher revenue and earnings than Ryanair Holdings PLC. SkyWest is trading at a lower price-to-earnings ratio than 
Ryanair Holdings PLC, indicating that it is currently the more affordable of the two stocks.  Summary SkyWest beats 
Ryanair Holdings PLC on 9 of the 14 factors compared between the two stocks. Ryanair Holdings PLC Company 
Profile Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair 
operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, 
the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and 
engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, 
Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise. Ryanair markets 
accommodation services and travel insurance through its Website. It provides hotel and accommodation services. 
Ryanair provides its own aircraft and passenger handling and ticketing services at Dublin Airport. As of June 30, 
2016, Ryanair had a principal fleet of over 350 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and offered over 2,000 scheduled short-haul 
flights per day serving approximately 200 airports throughout Europe. SkyWest Company Profile SkyWest, Inc., 
Financial Survey: Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) versus SkyWest (SKYW)
through its subsidiaries, SkyWest Airlines, Inc. (SkyWest Airlines) and ExpressJet Airlines, Inc. (ExpressJet), 
operates regional airline operations in the United States. The Company's segments include SkyWest Airlines, 
ExpressJet and SkyWest Leasing. The SkyWest Airlines segment provides regional jet service to airports primarily 
located in the Midwestern and Western United States, as well as Mexico and Canada. The ExpressJet segment 
provides regional jet service to airports primarily located in the Eastern and Midwestern United States, as well as 
Mexico, Canada and the Caribbean. The SkyWest Leasing segment includes its E175 aircraft ownership business. 
As of December 31, 2016, the Company offered scheduled passenger service with approximately 3,160 daily 
departures to destinations in the United States, Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean. The Company's flights are 
operated as Delta Connection, United Express, American Eagle or Alaska Airlines.Receive News ...tings for

Body
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ: RYAAY) and China Southern Airlines Company Limited (NYSE:ZNH) are both 
mid-cap transportation companies, but which is the superior stock? We will compare the two companies based on 
the strength of their profitability, valuation, earnings, analyst recommendations, dividends, institutional ownership 
and risk.  
Institutional and Insider Ownership
38.7% of Ryanair Holdings PLC shares are owned by institutional investors. Comparatively, 0.5% of China 
Southern Airlines Company Limited shares are owned by institutional investors. Strong institutional ownership is an 
indication that hedge funds, endowments and large money managers believe a company is poised for long-term 
growth.

the S&P 500. Comparatively, China Southern Airlines Company Limited has a beta of 1.07, meaning that its stock 
price is 7% more volatile than the S&P 500. 
Dividends
China Southern Airlines Company Limited pays an annual dividend of $0.64 per share and has a dividend yield of 
1.7%. Ryanair Holdings PLC does not pay a dividend. China Southern Airlines Company Limited has increased its 
dividend for 2 consecutive years.

Summary

About Ryanair Holdings PLC
Ryanair Holdings PLC logo Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited 
(Ryanair). Ryanair operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary 
services and engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight 
scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise. Ryanair 
markets accommodation services and travel insurance through its Website. It provides hotel and accommodation 
services. Ryanair provides its own aircraft and passenger handling and ticketing services at Dublin Airport. As of 
June 30, 2016, Ryanair had a principal fleet of over 350 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and offered over 2,000 scheduled 
short-haul flights per day serving approximately 200 airports throughout Europe. 
About China Southern Airlines Company Limited
China Southern Airlines Company Limited logo China Southern Airlines Company Limited is principally engaged in 
the operation of civil aviation, including the provision of passenger, cargo, mail delivery and other extended 
transportation services. The Company operates through two business segments, including Airline Transportation 
segment and Other segment. Airline Transportation segment consist of passenger and cargo and mail operations. 
Other segment includes hotel and tour operation, ground services, cargo handling and other miscellaneous 
services. . The Company also provides services of general aviation and aircraft maintenance. The Company acts as 
an agency of domestic and foreign airlines, and other aviation and related business, such as personal accident 
insurance and agency business.

Holdings is trading at a lower price-to-earnings ratio than Ryanair Holdings PLC, indicating that it is currently the 
more affordable of the two stocks.

Insider & Institutional Ownership
38.7% of Ryanair Holdings PLC shares are owned by institutional investors. Comparatively, 98.7% of United 
Continental Holdings shares are owned by institutional investors. 0.3% of United Continental Holdings shares are

About Ryanair Holdings PLC
Ryanair Holdings PLC logo Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited 
(Ryanair). Ryanair operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary 
services and engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight 
scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise. Ryanair 
markets accommodation services and travel insurance through its Website. It provides hotel and accommodation 
services. Ryanair provides its own aircraft and passenger handling and ticketing services at Dublin Airport. As of 
June 30, 2016, Ryanair had a principal fleet of over 350 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and offered over 2,000 scheduled 
short-haul flights per day serving approximately 200 airports throughout Europe. 
About United Continental Holdings
United Continental Holdings logo United Continental Holdings, Inc. (UAL) is a holding company and its principal 
subsidiary is United Air Lines, Inc. (United). The Company transports people and cargo through its mainline 
operations. It has global air rights in North America, Asia-Pacific, Europe, Middle East, Africa and Latin America. 
The Company, through United and its regional carriers, operates flights from its hubs at Newark Liberty 
International Airport (Newark Liberty), Chicago O'Hare International Airport (Chicago O'Hare), Denver International 
Airport (Denver), George Bush Intercontinental Airport (Houston Bush), Los Angeles International Airport (LAX), 
A.B. Won Pat International Airport (Guam), San Francisco International Airport (SFO) and Washington Dulles 
International Airport (Washington Dulles). It has contractual relationships with regional carriers to provide regional 
jet and turboprop service branded as United Express. These regional operations are an extension of the Company's 
mainline network.

F1 great Lauda mulls bid to buy back Air Berlin subsidiary Niki
F1 great Lauda mulls bid to buy back Air Berlin subsidiary Niki
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 26, 2017 Saturday 6:43 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 206 words
Byline: Albert Otti in Vienna
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Formula One legend Niki Lauda is interested in buying back the Niki airline, which he founded in 2003 and which 
has since become a daughter of insolvent German carrier Air Berlin.
"I have written a letter to Air Berlin's insolvency administrator, in which I express my interest in [Niki]," he said in an 
interview that the Austrian tabloid Kronen Zeitung published online on Saturday.
He said he would like to get the chance to look into Niki's accounts.
"Only afterwards I can decide whether it would make sense to take over Niki again," said Lauda.
The former champion racer, who serves as the Mercedes Formula One team's non-executive chairman, warned 
that Lufthansa should not be allowed to take over Air Berlin as well as Niki.
"Politicians completely forget that we need competition. A Lufthansa monopoly would be catastrophic," he said.
Air Berlin is holding takeover talks with Lufthansa, Easyjet and Ryanair, German Economic Minister Brigitte Zypries 
said Saturday in Berlin.
Lauda founded Niki in 2003. One year later, Air Berlin bought a 24-per-cent stake in his company. The German 
carrier completely took over Niki at the end of 2011.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Mark Joseph CorriganTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 27, 2017

End of Document

Body
       F1 great Lauda mulls bid to buy back Air Berlin subsidiary Niki   VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - Formula One legend Niki 
Lauda is interested in buying back the Niki airline, which he founded in 2003 and which has since become a 
daughter of insolvent German carrier Air Berlin.  'I have written a letter to Air Berlin's insolvency administrator, in 
which I express my interest in [Niki],' he said in an interview that the Austrian tabloid Kronen Zeitung published 
online on Saturday.  He said he would like to get the chance to look into Niki's accounts.  'Only afterwards I can 
decide whether it would make sense to take over Niki again,' said Lauda.  The former champion racer, who serves 
as the Mercedes Formula One team's non-executive chairman, warned that Lufthansa should not be allowed to 
take over Air Berlin as well as Niki.  'Politicians completely forget that we need competition. A Lufthansa monopoly 
would be catastrophic,' he said.  Air Berlin is holding takeover talks with Lufthansa, Easyjet and Ryanair, German 
Economic Minister Brigitte Zypries said Saturday in Berlin.  Lauda founded Niki in 2003. One year later, Air Berlin 
bought a 24-per-cent stake in his company. The German carrier completely took over Niki at the end of 2011.

A man who raised the bar
A man who raised the bar
Sunday Business Post
August 26, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1764 words
Byline: Matt Cooper
Highlight: From solicitor to chairman, James Osborne was an ebullient character never  afraid to take a risk. Matt 
Cooper remembers the former chairman  of INM 
Body
James Osborne was an unusually ebullient solicitor. Many solicitors keep a low profile, especially those who act as 
advisers to big business. Mostly, they rarely impinge on the public consciousness. Osborne may not have been a 
household name, at least to the general public, but he was a solicitor exceptionally well known in Irish business 
circles over a period of nearly 40 years; as an adviser, director and investor. His reputation was as someone never 
afraid to speak his mind, and to hold to his position, publicly or privately, no matter how powerful his adversary. It 
was something that occasionally led him into confrontation.
Osborne, aged just 68, died last week on the same island off the coast of Donegal where his father is buried. When 
I was looking for him only last month to arrange a meeting, I received a text that he was “sailing off the Fastnet at 
present. Will contact on my return in a few weeks”. That he was sailing was not a surprise. For years, he had a 
share in a 46ft cruiser called Hibernia, in which he toured much of the world. Unfortunately, we didn’t get that 
chance to meet before news of his sudden death emerged last weekend.
Osborne was great company, with many stories to tell, although he picked them carefully so as not to breach any 
confidences. He interacted with some of the biggest names in Irish business. These included figures like the late 
Don Carroll and Tony Ryan, and the still very active Larry Goodman and Michael O’Leary. He got caught right in the 
middle of the war waged between Denis O’Brien and Tony O’Reilly at Independent News & Media in the early part 
of this decade, as chairman for an ill-fated period (see panel).
He was, at various times, a director of PJ Carroll and Sons (one of Ireland’s biggest companies in the 1970s and 
1980s), Bank of Ireland, Adare, Eason, Golden Vale and many other companies, most notably Ryanair for 21 years 
until his death. Although rarely, if ever, associated with politics, he was a central figure in one of the biggest 
controversies in Charlie McCreevy’s political career, during McCreevy’s time as minister for finance.
A man who raised the bar
Osborne, in his role as chairman of Punchestown racecourse, where he had used his extensive contacts to raise 
sponsorship and expand racing at the Kildare venue, had charmed McCreevy into supplying the €13 million needed 
for an equestrian centre, which just happened to be slap bang in the middle of McCreevy’s constituency. There was 
further controversy over the supply by the state of passports to members of the billionaire Getty family in return for 
investment at Punchestown and which Osborne negotiated.
Osborne did much of the legal work as GPA raised finance and cut contracts around Wall Street, so much so that 
Ryan tried to persuade him to change jobs
That Osborne had such wealthy connections surprised few. He lived the fullest of lives, both professionally and 
personally. His legal career was remarkable. The son of an RAF pilot who went into business as a solicitor in 
Milford, Donegal, James, who was actually born in Devon in April 1949, was educated at Campbell College, Belfast, 
before returning to the Republic and Trinity College Dublin. He took an arts degree and then qualified as a solicitor 
in 1973 and joined A&L Goodbody, then one of the three main legal firms in Dublin. He made such an impression 
that he was made partner in just six years, at the age of just 29, and headed off to New York, “with one-quarter of 
the firm’s profits in a suitcase”, to set up an office for the company in Manhattan.
The big client he won – making the partnership’s investment worthwhile – was Tony Ryan’s aviation leasing 
company GPA, still in its early stages, but quickly developing a formidable reputation. Osborne did much of the 
legal work as GPA raised finance and cut contracts around Wall Street, so much so that Ryan tried to persuade him 
to change jobs.
Displaying the independence and self-confidence that was to be his hallmark, Osborne said no. Instead, a little 
more than three years after decamping to the US, he returned home in 1982, just 32 years of age, to become 
managing partner of his legal firm, a position he would hold for just over 12 years.
He wasn’t a shrinking violet in seeking new clients for his firm, causing something of a stir among more 
conservative members of the profession who tended to wait for business to approach them. His subtle aggression, 
allied with great charm, quickly meant that A&L Goodbody became the top corporate law firm in the country and 
was excellently positioned to benefit from the establishment of the IFSC, and the quick development of the 
economy that accelerated in the 1990s.
Not content with that workload, he also began to take up positions as a non-executive director at major companies. 
One of his first involvements was with Fieldcrest Ireland, an American-owned towel-making venture that came to 
Kilkenny in partnership with PJ Carroll Industries – the cigarette manufacturer that was then one of the country’s 
most significant businesses and which was trying to diversify from relying on tobacco – and with support from Bank 
of Ireland. It was a financial disaster and the business closed, costing 500 jobs and major losses for the Irish 
shareholders.
Osborne was appointed to the board of PJ Carroll in the mid-1980s, most probably at the behest of Bank of Ireland, 
which was very worried about the investments being made by the company’s overpowering chief executive Donal 
Carroll, known to everyone as Don or ‘The Don’.
Carroll had invested the company’s cashflow in salmon farms and a direct marketing company, to catastrophic 
effect. The young Osborne confronted him in the boardroom. It was particularly sore for Carroll, who had been 
appointed to the top position in the company by his uncle when aged just 29, and who was regarded as one of the 
major figures in Irish business. He was a key associate of TK Whitaker, the legendary civil servant.
“I went to war with [Carroll],” Osborne told the Irish Times in 1999. “He didn’t like me, but I told him I was doing my 
job as a director.” Osborne effected Carroll’s removal and the company was sold to the South African firm 
Rothmans; the ruthlessness of the action, even if necessary, was the talk of Irish business circles at the time and 
impressed as many as it appalled.
When Larry Goodman nearly ruined his business in 1990 through a combination of reckless gambling on the shares 
in the British companies Unigate and Berisford, and failing to recover £180 million owed by Iraq for beef he had 
A man who raised the bar
exported there, Osborne was one of the key figures involved in rescuing him from personal financial ruin after his 
beef company, Goodman International, was saved by the emergency introduction of the examinership laws.
A year later, Osborne went publicly to bat for Goodman when his company’s practices and standards were the 
subject of a damning exposé by Irish journalist Susan O’Keeffe on the British investigative TV programme World in 
Action. Osborne sat beside Goodman at a specially convened press conference at the Shelbourne Hotel the night 
after the broadcast, and was vehement in his vocal validation of his client. It was unusual to see and hear an 
adviser take such a prominent role and while he was just doing his job, it meant that for many years afterwards, 
much of the business media was not particularly well disposed to him – or him to it.
His developing interest in agribusiness – despite his admission that he knew nothing about agriculture – saw him 
take on a role as a director of Golden Vale (which was later sold to Kerry Group while he was chairman). Again he 
was highly involved in the removal of a chief executive. He proposed the motion to dismiss Jim O’Mahony in July 
1996 and organised the support at board level to get the job done, amid some resentment from Cork and Limerick 
farmers as to the ruthlessness of this posh-sounding elitist figure.
By this stage he had retired as managing partner of A&L Goodbody, although he retained an office at the firm and 
was employed as a consultant. His old connections to Tony Ryan meant that he joined Ryanair as a director in 
1995 and many believe he was essential to the successful stock market flotation of the company in 1997. He 
bought 625,000 shares at the time for just £25,000 and later sold them for over £1 million. There was to be further 
profitable trading in the shares.
He and Michael O’Leary bonded, sharing not just a love of horses, but very similar views as to how businesses 
should be run and on issues of corporate governance and probity. They shared a natural self-confidence and were 
often impatient with others who did not share their views or drive. But he liked that O’Leary was not interested in 
ostentatious displays of wealth or influence. The relationship endured until the time of Osborne’s death; Osborne 
was the senior director at Ryanair and there was never a question of him leaving the board other than at a time of 
his own choosing.
He remained very busy in recent years, partly from financial necessity, partly because he needed the intellectual 
challenge. Some of his investments are understood not to have gone well.
He had backed Fresh Mortgages in 2006, not long before the crash, along with Anglo Irish Bank’s Seán FitzPatrick. 
He was involved with fund manager Pilot View Capital, which required directors’ loans to shore it up after the 
company breached the Central Bank’s capital requirements. It had launched the highly leveraged Atlas fund at the 
peak of the boom in 2007 and incurred heavy losses afterwards. He was chairman of former Irish-listed security, 
cleaning and recruitment company Newcourt when it was put into receivership in mid-2009 by Bank of Ireland after 
failing to restructure its €36 million debt.
But he had a string of other successes to his name, among the various other companies in which he had invested. 
He also made a killing on the property market when he sold Glenbrook, a luxury Georgian mansion on two acres at 
Enniskerry village, just before the market crashed for €6.2 million, which was €2.2 million higher than the asking 
price. The buyer was Shane Ross, now a government minister.
In an Irish Times interview in May 1999, he declared that he had never had a career strategy, but knew he “didn’t 
want to be a lawyer all my life”.
A private memorial service was held for him last Wednesday, and there was then a public event at Trinity College 
last Friday afternoon. He is survived by his wife, Heather, and son and daughter from this marriage, and by his 
partner Patricia Devine and their daughter.
Load-Date: August 26, 2017
A man who raised the bar
End of Document
Isme announces the line-up for its 2017 conference
Isme announces the line-up for its 2017 conference
Sunday Business Post
August 26, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 450 words
Byline: Post Reporter
Body
Isme has announced details of its 2017 annual conference which will take place on Friday, November 3.
The conference this year will take place in a new location – the City West Hotel, Dublin – and will have 
enhancements such as breakout sessions, a workshop, panel discussions and more audience interaction.
The title of the conference is What’s Your Story? – Driving Business Growth Through Storytelling, and Isme will be 
asking businesses to look at their own story to see how it can empower them to grow their business.
Commenting on this year’s conference, Isme chief executive Neil McDonnell said: “We received a strong demand 
from last year’s delegates to expand on the idea of ‘selling your story’, so we’ve decided to theme the annual 
conference around it this year. The most successful companies manage to wrap a story around their brand, one 
that instantly communicates their message and values to the customer. We will show how SMEs can do this and be 
just as effective as the big brands.”
Minister Frances Fitzgerald will open the conference, followed by the keynote speech by Michael Cawley, chairman 
of Fáilte Ireland and former deputy chief executive of Ryanair.
Conall Ó Mórain will chair the day, which includes a storytelling workshop led by Cilian Fennell of Stillwater 
Productions.
Other highlights of the conference include John McGrane, director general of the British Irish Chamber of 
Commerce, discussing Brexit, and an interview with Siobhan O’Connor, the managing director of Codex Office 
Solutions, about her business story.
The Great Debate will close the day and includes panellists Lorcan Sirr, Councillor Mannix Flynn, Susan Hayes, Jim 
O’Leary and Tom Lyons, who will hold a discussion on the topic SMEs and New Socialism.
This year’s conference is sponsored by Zurich, Codex Office Solutions and The Sunday Business Post.
Isme announces the line-up for its 2017 conference
Siobhán Lennon, chief executive of The Sunday Business Post, said: “The Sunday Business Post tells the best Irish 
business stories every week. We believe that championing small and medium-sized enterprises is at the heart of 
what we do. We are delighted to be supporting this year’s conference.”
“Zurich, a leading pension provider to SMEs, is delighted to sponsor the conference because we believe in the 
importance to both employers and employees of having a good positive financial story to tell when they reach their 
retirement,” said Joe Creegan, head of corporate life and pensions, Zurich.
Siobhan O’Connor, managing director of Codex Office Solutions, said: “As natural storytellers, small and medium 
enterprises continue to do a great job enhancing their business through networking and communicating, and now 
more than ever this needs to continue.”

Condor among rivals circling assets of insolvent Air Berlin Airlines
Condor among rivals circling assets of insolvent Air Berlin; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
August 26, 2017 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 10
Length: 319 words
Byline: TOBIAS BUCK
Body
The assets of insolvent Air Berlin are attracting growing interest from rivals as worries grow that the carrier's demise 
might deal a blow to competition and raise prices.
Lufthansa, the German flag carrier, has made clear that it plans to bid for parts of the group and boost its already 
strong position in the German market.
However, Lufthansa is likely to face competition from airlines including Condor, a subsidiary of Thomas Cook.
Condor was expected to bid for a "high double-digit" number of medium-haul planes belonging to Air Berlin, as well 
as some long-haul planes, a person briefed on the negotiations said.
EasyJet, the UK low-cost carrier, has been tipped as a bidder for Air Berlin assets, while a consortium led by 
German businessman Hans Rudolf Wöhrl has said it wants to take over the airline in its entirety.
Air Berlin filed for insolvency this month after Etihad, the Abu Dhabibased airline and the main shareholder in Air 
Berlin, said it would no longer fund the lossmaking carrier.
Over the past six years, Air Berlin has racked up losses of about (EURO)2bn, with net debt reaching (EURO)1.2bn.
In an effort to prevent airport chaos at the height of summer, the government stepped in with a (EURO)150m credit 
line, allowing Air Berlin to stay in operation for another three months.
Condor among rivals circling assets of insolvent Air Berlin Airlines
But the move sparked anger among some rivals, with Ryanair accusing Berlin of a "set-up" to help Lufthansa gain a 
dominant position.
Lufthansa and Air Berlin have a close relationship, following an agreement last year for the latter to run 40 aircraft 
for the flag carrier's subsidiaries.
Analysts point out that a combination of the two German airlines would deal a significant blow to competition, 
especially on domestic flights.
A report by Bank of America Merrill Lynch found that a full integration of Air Berlin into Lufthansa would create an 
airline with 98 per cent of the market for flights between German cities.
Load-Date: August 25, 2017
End of Document
Germany Reportedly Says Air Berlin Requires Swift Deal As Prospects Bad
Germany Reportedly Says Air Berlin Requires Swift Deal As Prospects Bad
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
August 26, 2017 Saturday 5:12 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 135 words
Body
       BERLIN (dpa-AFX) - Air Berlin Plc (AIBEF.PK) needs a swift deal with carriers interested in buying all or part of 
the insolvent German airline because its prospects look bad, German Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries reportedly 
said.  Zypries reportedly said she was surprised by criticism of the German government's EU150 million bridging 
loan to keep Air Berlin flying, telling a news conference she expects the money to be repaid.  According to the 
reports, She said the government had created good conditions for talks on the airline's future and that there were 
'enough interested parties,' including Lufthansa, EasyJet, Ryanair and German aviation entrepreneur Hans Rudolf 
Woehrl.  Air Berlin filed for insolvency on August 15 when main shareholder Etihad Airways PJSC withdrew 
financial support.

BidaskClub Downgrades Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) to Hold
BidaskClub Downgrades Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) to Hold
American Banking and Market News
August 25, 2017 Friday
Copyright 2017 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 866 words
Body
Ryanair Holdings PLC logo Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was downgraded by equities researchers 
at            BidaskClub  from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note issued to investors on Friday. 
A number of other brokerages also recently weighed in on RYAAY. HSBC Holdings plc raised shares of Ryanair 
Holdings PLC from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, July 25th. Sanford C. Bernstein 
began coverage on shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC in a research note on Monday, June 26th. They issued an 
"underperform" rating and a $83.00 target price on the stock. Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. (The) raised shares of 
Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "neutral" rating to a "buy" rating and raised their target price for the company from 
$67.56 to $109.00 in a research note on Thursday, June 15th. ValuEngine  raised shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC 
from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, June 6th. Finally, UBS AG downgraded shares 
of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "buy" rating to a "neutral" rating in a research note on Friday, June 2nd. Two 
research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, four have given a hold rating and ten have assigned  a buy 
rating to the company's stock. The stock currently has a consensus rating of "Buy" and an average target price of 
$100.33. 
Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ RYAAY ) traded up 0.57% during mid-day trading on Friday, reaching 
$113.32. 196,435 shares of the company's stock traded hands. The stock has a market cap of $27.36 billion, a PE 
ratio of 16.44 and a beta of 0.61. The firm has a 50 day moving average price of $114.63 and a 200-day moving 
average price of $98.56. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 12 month low of $67.56 and a 12 month high of $122.68.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its earnings results on Monday, July 24th. The 
transportation company reported $1.78 earnings per share for the quarter, beating analysts' consensus estimates of 
$1.48 by $0.30. The business had revenue of $2.10 billion for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of 
$2.02 billion. Ryanair Holdings PLC had a net margin of 21.44% and a return on equity of 34.02%.  On average, 
analysts predict that  Ryanair Holdings PLC will post $7.58 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC declared that its Board of Directors has approved a stock repurchase program on Tuesday, 
May 30th that permits the company to repurchase  outstanding  shares. This repurchase authorization permits the 
transportation company to repurchase up to 2.3% of its shares through open market purchases. Shares repurchase 
programs are usually an indication that the company's leadership believes its shares are undervalued.

Ryanair Holdings PLC Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.
