Body
Aug 24, 2017( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ: RYAAY) and Copa Holdings, (NYSE:CPA) are both mid-cap industrials companies, but which is the 
superior investment? We will contrast the two businesses based on the strength of their institutional ownership, risk, 
dividends, analyst recommendations, profitability, earnings and valuation.  Analyst Recommendations This is a 
summary of recent ratings and recommmendations for Ryanair Holdings plc and Copa Holdings,, as reported by 
MarketBeat. 
 Ryanair Holdings plc currently has a consensus target price of $96.00, suggesting a potential downside of 15.61%. 
Copa Holdings, has a consensus target price of $108.80, suggesting a potential downside of 9.23%. Given Copa 
Holdings,'s stronger consensus rating and higher possible upside, analysts plainly believe Copa Holdings, is more 
favorable than Ryanair Holdings plc. Profitability This table compares Ryanair Holdings plc and Copa Holdings,'s 
net margins, return on equity and return on assets. Risk and Volatility Ryanair Holdings plc has a beta of 0.61, 
meaning that its share price is 39% less volatile than the S...00. Comparatively, Copa Holdings, has a beta of 1.8, 
meaning that its share price is 80% more volatile than the S...00.  Insider and Institutional Ownership 38.7% of 
Ryanair Holdings plc shares are held by institutional investors. Comparatively, 70.4% of Copa Holdings, shares are 
held by institutional investors. Strong institutional ownership is an indication that hedge funds, large money 
managers and endowments believe a company will outperform the market over the long term. Valuation ...rnings 
This table compares Ryanair Holdings plc and Copa Holdings,'s revenue, earnings per share (EPS) and valuation. 
Ryanair Holdings plc has higher revenue and earnings than Copa Holdings,. Copa Holdings, is trading at a lower 
price-to-earnings ratio than Ryanair Holdings plc, indicating that it is currently the more affordable of the two stocks.  
Dividends Copa Holdings, pays an annual dividend of $2.04 per share and has a dividend yield of 1.7%. Ryanair 
Holdings plc does not pay a dividend. Copa Holdings, pays out 25.8% of its earnings in the form of a dividend.  
Summary Ryanair Holdings plc beats Copa Holdings, on 8 of the 14 factors compared between the two stocks. 
Ryanair Holdings plc Company Profile Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair 
Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point 
routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various 
ancillary services and engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight 
scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise. Ryanair 
markets accommodation services and travel insurance through its Website. It provides hotel and accommodation 
services. Ryanair provides its own aircraft and passenger handling and ticketing services at Dublin Airport. As of 
June 30, 2016, Ryanair had a principal fleet of over 350 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and offered over 2,000 scheduled

Copa Holdings, S.A. is a provider of airline passenger and cargo service through its principal operating subsidiaries, 
Compania Panamena de Aviacion, S. A. (Copa Airlines) and AeroRepublica, S. A. (Copa Colombia). The Company 
operates through air transportation segment. Copa Airlines operates from its position located in the Republic of 
Panama. Copa Airlines provides international air transportation for passengers, cargo and mail, operating from its 
Panama City hub in the Republic of Panama. Copa Colombia provides service within Colombia and international 
flights from various cities in Colombia to Panama, Venezuela, Ecuador, Mexico, Cuba, Guatemala and Costa Rica. 
Copa Colombia provides domestic and international air transportation for passengers, cargo and mail with a point-
to-point route network. Its subsidiary, Oval Financial Leasing, Ltd., controls the special purpose entities that have a

Lufthansa eyes Air Berlin's Niki arm as bidders scramble
Lufthansa eyes Air Berlin's Niki arm as bidders scramble
City A.M.
August 24, 2017 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 10
Length: 162 words
Byline: VICTORIA BRYAN ; ILONA WISSENBACH
Body
LUFTHANSA has submitted a letter of interest in Air Berlin's Niki unit and other parts of the insolvent carrier, a 
source familiar with the talks said yesterday.
Air Berlin, which is being kept in the air thanks to a (EURO)150m (£138m) government loan, has been in talks with 
interested parties since last week, when it filed for insolvency after major shareholder, Gulf carrier Etihad, said it 
would no longer provide funding.
Part of Air Berlin's appeal to bidders lies in its access to take-off and landing slots at airports such as Dusseldorf, in 
Germany's most populous region.
As part of a restructuring earlier this year, Air Berlin transferred leisure routes to tourist destinations in Spain and 
Greece to its Austria-based unit Niki, founded by former F1 driver Niki Lauda. Analysts at Goodbody said buying 
Niki would strengthen Lufthansa's position against Ryanair on such routes. Lufthansa is unlikely to be able to buy 
all of Air Berlin for competition reasons.
Reuters
Load-Date: August 24, 2017
End of Document
European Shares Subdued At Midday After Tuesday's Recovery
European Shares Subdued At Midday After Tuesday's Recovery
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
August 23, 2017 Wednesday 6:18 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 260 words
Body
 European stocks were little changed in lackluster trade on Wednesday after ECB President Mario Draghi defended 
unconventional monetary policy, saying QE and forward guidance have been a success.
With geopolitical tensions running high and US President Donald Trump signaling the possible termination of the 
NAFTA treaty with Mexico and Canada, investors looked ahead to the annual Jackson Hole Economic Policy 
Symposium in Wyoming for further direction.
The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index was down about 0.2% at 375.12 in late opening deals after rising 0.8% 
the previous day.
The German DAX and the UK's FTSE were marginally lower, while France's CAC 40 was little changed with a 
positive bias.
WPP shares fell more than 12% in London after the world's largest advertising group cut its full-year sales outlook, 
citing economic uncertainty and a "rise of populism" in the UK and the US.
Provident Financial fell over 1% to extend the previous session's sell-off amid brokerage downgrades.
Vedanta Resources rallied 1.5% after its quarterly core earnings rose about 48% on higher commodity prices.
Air Berlin shares climbed 1.3% after Ryanair said it would be interested in bidding for the whole of the insolvent 
German carrier.
In economic releases, Eurozone private sector activity maintained strong growth momentum in August, 
underpinned by strong expansion in the manufacturing output, flash survey data from IHS Markit showed.
The flash composite output index rose slightly to 55.8 in August from 55.7 in July. Economists had expected the 
index to fall to 55.4.
European Shares Subdued At Midday After Tuesday's Recovery
Load-Date: August 24, 2017
End of Document
European Markets Weaken Despite Positive Economic Data
European Markets Weaken Despite Positive Economic Data
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
August 23, 2017 Wednesday 12:06 PM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 660 words
Body
 The European markets ended Wednesday's session in negative territory. 
After snapping a 3-day losing streak on Tuesday, the markets got off to a positive start this morning. However, they 
quickly slid into the red and remained there for the remainder of the session.
Economic data from Europe was positive, with private sector activity maintaining its strong growth momentum in 
August. Traders were concerned by comments made by President Donald Trump at a rally in Phoenix, Arizona, on 
Tuesday. Trump pledged to a crowd of supporters that he would build the controversial wall on the border with 
Mexico even if it meant shutting down the government.
Trump also indicated he's likely to terminate the North American Free Trade Agreement, raising concerns about the 
impact on global trade.
Monetary and regulatory policy actions and steps in supervision undertaken over the last decade have made the 
world more resilient, however, central banks must continue preparing for new challenges, European Central Bank 
President Mario Draghi said Wednesday.
"When the world changes as it did ten years ago, policies, especially monetary policy, need to be adjusted," Draghi 
said in a speech delivered to a gathering of Nobel laureates and economists in Lindau, Germany.
"Such an adjustment, never easy, requires unprejudiced, honest assessment of the new realities with clear eyes, 
unencumbered by the defense of previously held paradigms that have lost any explanatory power."
Draghi is due to speak at the upcoming economic policy symposium in Jackson Hole, Wyoming later this week. 
Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen is also slated to speak at the event on Friday.
The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index weakened by 0.50%. The Euro Stoxx 50 index of eurozone bluechip 
stocks decreased 0.49%, while the Stoxx Europe 50 index, which includes some major UK companies, lost 0.47%.
European Markets Weaken Despite Positive Economic Data
The DAX of Germany dropped 0.45% and the CAC 40 of France fell 0.32%. The FTSE 100 of the UK gained 
0.01%, but the SMI of Switzerland finished lower by 0.06%.
In Frankfurt, Air Berlin slid 0.50% after Ryanair said it would be interested in bidding for the whole of the insolvent 
German carrier.
In Paris, advertising and public relations firm Publicis Groupe dropped 3.15% after its British peer WPP cut its full-
year revenue forecast, citing economic uncertainty and a "rise of populism" in the UK and the US
In London, WPP sank 10.92% after the world's largest advertising group cut its full-year sales outlook, citing 
economic uncertainty and a "rise of populism" in the UK and the US
Vedanta Resources rallied 4.05% after its quarterly core earnings rose about 48% on higher commodity prices.
Eurozone private sector activity maintained strong growth momentum in August, underpinned by strong expansion 
in the manufacturing output, flash survey data from IHS Markit showed Wednesday.
The flash composite output index rose slightly to 55.8 in August from 55.7 in July. Meanwhile, economists had 
expected the index to fall to 55.4.
Germany's private sector activity expanded at a faster pace in August, as output growth strengthened in both the 
manufacturing and service sectors, flash survey data from IHS Markit showed Wednesday. The composite output 
index climbed to a 2-month high of 55.7 in August from 54.7 in July.
French private sector activity expanded at a marked pace in August, though the rate of growth stagnated, flash 
survey data from IHS Markit showed Wednesday. The composite output index came in at 55.6 in August, the same 
reading as in July.
New home sales in the US unexpectedly saw a substantial decrease in the month of July, according to a report 
released by the Commerce Department on Wednesday. The report said new home sales plunged by 9.4% to an 
annual rate of 571,000 in July from the revised June rate of 630,000.
The steep drop surprised economists, who had expected new home sales to inch up to a rate of 612,000 from the 
610,000 originally reported for the previous month.
Load-Date: August 24, 2017
End of Document

       BRUSSELS/FRANKFURT/PARIS (dpa-AFX) - The European markets ended Wednesday's session in negative 
territory. After snapping a 3-day losing streak on Tuesday, the markets got off to a positive start this morning. 
However, they quickly slid into the red and remained there for the remainder of the session.  Economic data from 
Europe was positive, with private sector activity maintaining its strong growth momentum in August. 
Traders were concerned by comments made by President Donald Trump at a rally in Phoenix, Arizona, on 
Tuesday. Trump pledged to a crowd of supporters that he would build the controversial wall on the border with 
Mexico even if it meant shutting down the government.  Trump also indicated he's likely to terminate the North 
American Free Trade Agreement, raising concerns about the impact on global trade.  Monetary and regulatory 
policy actions and steps in supervision undertaken over the last decade have made the world more resilient, 
however, central banks must continue preparing for new challenges, European Central Bank President Mario 
Draghi said Wednesday.   'When the world changes as it did ten years ago, policies, especially monetary policy, 
need to be adjusted,' Draghi said in a speech delivered to a gathering of Nobel laureates and economists in Lindau, 
Germany.  'Such an adjustment, never easy, requires unprejudiced, honest assessment of the new realities with 
clear eyes, unencumbered by the defense of previously held paradigms that have lost any explanatory power.'  
Draghi is due to speak at the upcoming economic policy symposium in Jackson Hole, Wyoming later this week. 
Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen is also slated to speak at the event on Friday.  The pan-European Stoxx 
Europe 600 index weakened by 0.50 percent. The Euro Stoxx 50 index of eurozone bluechip stocks decreased 0.49 
percent, while the Stoxx Europe 50 index, which includes some major U.K. companies, lost 0.47 percent.  The DAX 
of Germany dropped 0.45 percent and the CAC 40 of France fell 0.32 percent. The FTSE 100 of the U.K. gained 
0.01 percent, but the SMI of Switzerland finished lower by 0.06 percent.  In Frankfurt, Air Berlin slid 0.50 percent 
after Ryanair said it would be interested in bidding for the whole of the insolvent German carrier.  In Paris, 
advertising and public relations firm Publicis Groupe dropped 3.15 percent after its British peer WPP cut its full-year 
revenue forecast, citing economic uncertainty and a 'rise of populism' in the U.K. and the U.S.  In London, WPP 
sank 10.92 percent after the world's largest advertising group cut its full-year sales outlook, citing economic 
uncertainty and a 'rise of populism' in the U.K. and the U.S.  Vedanta Resources rallied 4.05 percent after its 
quarterly core earnings rose about 48 percent on higher commodity prices.  Eurozone private sector activity

maintained strong growth momentum in August, underpinned by strong expansion in the manufacturing output, 
flash survey data from IHS Markit showed Wednesday.  The flash composite output index rose slightly to 55.8 in 
August from 55.7 in July. Meanwhile, economists had expected the index to fall to 55.4.  Germany's private sector

 E Ryanair signals interest in Air Berlin bid; Ryanair has joined the airlines outlining preliminary interest in 
German carrier Air Berlin, which filed for inso....
 E Ryanair signals interest in Air Berlin bid; Ryanair has joined the airlines 
outlining preliminary interest in German carrier Air Berlin, which filed for 
insolvency proceedings earlier this month.
Flight International
August 23, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 322 words
Body
Ryanair has joined the airlines outlining preliminary interest in German carrier Air Berlin, which filed for insolvency 
proceedings earlier this month.
The Irish carrier confirm's comments its chief executive Michael O'Leary gave to Reuters yesterday saying the 
airline would be "happy to bid" for Air Berlin. But the airline stresses it would need greater access to Air Berlin's 
financial details to evaluate an offer for the beleaguered airline.
Ryanair has been rapidly growing its presence in the short-haul Germany. FlightGlobal schedules data for August 
shows Ryanair has lifted its Germany capacity by around two-thirds compared with two years ago.
Talks about acquisition of parts of Air Berlin are under way with Lufthansa, tour specialist TUI Group and, 
reportedly, at least one other airline.
German turnaround specialist Intro Group has also signalled its interest, while EasyJet is among others that have 
been linked with looking at the airline.
Germany's government has facilitated a 150 million ($177 million) bridging loan to continue Air Berlin's operations 
until a decision about the airline's estate has been reached.
Ryanair has sharply criticised the process and accused the government of a "conspiracy" to "carve up" Air Berlin for 
the benefit of Lufthansa.
The European Commission confirms it has received a complaint by Ryanair.
Air Berlin began insolvency proceedings earlier this month after key shareholder Etihad Airways, which owns 29% 
of the airline, pulled the plug on further investment in the ailing carrier.
 E Ryanair signals interest in Air Berlin bid; Ryanair has joined the airlines outlining preliminary interest in 
German carrier Air Berlin, which filed for inso....
A string of carriers, including Ryanair, have also shown tentative interest in another Etihad part-owned struggling 
carrier, Alitalia. Administrators in the Italian carrier have launched a sale process in pursuit of fresh investment 
generating a number of preliminary submissions of interest. The level of firm interest should become clear after the 
15 September deadline for submitting binding offers.
Load-Date: August 23, 2017
End of Document
Air Berlin / Lufthansa : terminal velocity Twitter : @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Air Berlin/Lufthansa: terminal velocity; Twitter: @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Financial Times (London, England)
August 23, 2017 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; Pg. 12
Length: 325 words
Body
Everybody is good at something. Air Berlin has shown skill at losing money, doing so at the operating level for eight 
of the past nine years. Last week, Germany's second-largest carrier filed for insolvency after its largest shareholder 
Etihad, the UAE-based carrier, halted financial support.
National champion Lufthansa looks to have the inside track on buying up Air Berlin. Already the former has bought 
planes from Air Berlin, leasing them back, thereby making the flag carrier a creditor. Instead of supporting 
competition, the German government seems to favour consolidation of the market. Great for Lufthansa holders, but 
bad news for consumers.
Air Berlin is likely to be sold in parts.
It has the largest share of passengers at one of the two Berlin airports, Tegel, favoured by business flyers, and at 
busy Düsseldorf.
Lufthansa dominates three other big airports: Frankfurt, Munich and Hamburg. A combination of the two carriers 
would mean Lufthansa controlling half of German airport slots and 90 per cent of the domestic market.
Champion indeed. It could rule the air on domestic pricing. All this upside has put some octane into Lufthansa's 
share price. Already this year, cost cutting, labour dispute settlements and better traffic have boosted its share price 
75 per cent, far ahead of the MSCI European Airlines index.
Germany is Europe's fourth-largest airline market, but one of the least profitable last year, notes consultant RDC. 
One fewer airline only decreases competition for flyers. Irish carrier Ryanair, which managed to snag some slots at 
Air Berlin / Lufthansa : terminal velocity Twitter : @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Frankfurt last year, would dearly like to challenge Lufthansa more directly. However, given Lufthansa's front-running 
position, Ryanair and rival easyJet may be lucky to get anything in the sale process.
As poor as Air Berlin has been at running its airline, Lufthansa has shown great élan by positioning itself as the 
favourite for the assets. Let its rivals display their skills as well.
Load-Date: August 22, 2017
End of Document

       BRUSSELS/FRANKFURT/PARIS (dpa-AFX) - German stocks edged lower in cautious trade on Wednesday

Ryanair boss 'very happy' to consider a swoop for Air Berlin
Ryanair boss 'very happy' to consider a swoop for Air Berlin
City A.M.
August 23, 2017 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 3
Length: 143 words
Byline: ALYS KEY
Body
THE COLOURFUL boss of Ryanair said yesterday that he would be keen to make a bid for insolvent airline Air 
Berlin, pending further information on the company's financial situation.
Speaking to Reuters, chief executive Michael O'Leary said: "We would be very happy to bid for the whole of Air 
Berlin, which is generally a short-haul, domestic, intra-EU carrier.
"But we don't know how much restructuring it will take, how much money is it losing, why is it losing so much money 
in a market where we make money."
Air Berlin filed for bankruptcy earlier this month after major shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding. The 
carrier is now in talks with a number of aviation firms over its future.
But a German official has said that it is unlikely a direct takeover by one bidder, Lufthansa, will be possible as it 
would make many domestic German routes uncompetitive.
Graphic

Avolon argues Boeing should keep tweaking Max models Irish lessor believes narrowbody line needs further 
adaption to better compete with Neo
Avolon argues Boeing should keep tweaking Max models; Irish lessor 
believes narrowbody line needs further adaption to better compete with Neo
Flight International
August 22, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: THIS WEEK
Length: 323 words
Body
Boeing should continue to adapt the 737 Max product range to help recover parity with Airbus in the single-aisle 
market, Irish lessor and major customer Avolon says in a newly published report.
A reactive product strategy forced Boeing to launch an incomplete 737 Max narrowbody family in 2011 in response 
to the market success of the re-engined A320neo, according to a 10 August “product assessment” of Boeing’s 
single-aisle line by Avolon.
After later launching a 200-seat version of the 737 Max 8 – the Max 200 – redesigning the Max 7 and launching the 
Max 10 to complement the slow-selling Max 9, the family may still not be complete, the lessor argues.
Avolon released the assessment as a “thought leadership” initiative, but has a clear financial interest in the future of 
the programme: it lists commitments for 145 737 Max aircraft, although Boeing’s orders and deliveries data shows 
that only 22 are firm orders.
As a general rule, lessors seek to dissuade aircraft manufacturers from launching too many variants within an 
aircraft family, despite the needs of some airlines for specific performance criteria.
Despite that preference, Avolon applauds the unveiling in June of the 737 Max 10, saying the 1.67m (5.5ft)-
stretched derivative of the Max 9 “strengthens” the family as a “seat-cost machine”. The lessor is similarly 
appreciative of the baseline Max 8 in the heart of the market for keeping a cash operating cost advantage over the 
A320neo.
However, Avolon voices its disappointment with the performance and design of the other three variants, and 
believes Boeing should review its strategies on these. The Max 200, it says, has gained only three customers, 
including launch operator Ryanair; the redesigned Max 7 has failed to compete on a parity basis with the A319neo; 
while the Max 10 “severely” impacts the value proposition of the smaller Max 9.
Avolon argues Boeing should keep tweaking Max models Irish lessor believes narrowbody line needs further 
adaption to better compete with Neo
Report highlights “very limited future” for next variant of single-aisle
BillyPix
Load-Date: August 24, 2017
End of Document
ANALYSIS: How Lufthansa had already targeted Air Berlin routes E Even before the Air Berlin estate is divided 
up, Lufthansa has already nabbed some of the Onewo....
ANALYSIS: How Lufthansa had already targeted Air Berlin routes;  E Even 
before the Air Berlin estate is divided up, Lufthansa has already nabbed 
some of the Oneworld carrier's prized possessions – market share on 
important routes to southern Europe.
Flight International
August 22, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 854 words
Body
Even before the Air Berlin estate is divided up, Lufthansa has already nabbed some of the Oneworld carrier's prized 
possessions – market share on important routes to southern Europe.
When Lufthansa Group started introducing 38 wet-leased Air Berlin Airbus A320-family jets to its operations, the 
additional capacity was deployed on routes vacated by Air Berlin.
At the same time, Air Berlin transferred its flights serving southern Europe (except Italy), Turkey and North Africa to 
Austrian subsidiary Niki. This was part of a restructuring effort that involves reduction of Air Berlin's fleet and a 
focus on scheduled services – in particular long-haul flights – from Dusseldorf and the German capital.
The move was, in part, driven by an intent to reduce seasonality in Air Berlin's business. But with the decision, Air 
Berlin departed the leisure market – a segment where it had established its business and brand during the 1990s, 
and which was the basis of its troubled expansion strategy later on. Air Berlin became known as the "Majorca 
Shuttle" in Germany, and opened a base on the Spanish island.
Air Berlin's Mediterranean network August 2016
Following Air Berlin's retreat from Majorca, Eurowings established a base there earlier this year. Eurowings wasn't 
the only airline that targeted the vacated market – Germania, too, opened a station in Majorca, and EasyJet set up 
a seasonal base on the Balearic island.
FlightGlobal schedules data shows that in August 2016 – before Air Berlin's fleet and network reduction plans were 
disclosed in September that year – the airline provided 26.2% of total capacity, in ASK terms, between Germany 
and Spain. Air Berlin shed almost all flights to Spain – bar a route from Dusseldorf to Barcelona – in line with the 
ANALYSIS: How Lufthansa had already targeted Air Berlin routes E Even before the Air Berlin estate is divided 
up, Lufthansa has already nabbed some of the Onewo....
transfer of leisure operations to Niki. But Niki continued operating some 70.4% of Air Berlin's former capacity. In 
August 2017, Niki provided 18.8% of ASK between the two countries.
Overall capacity between Germany and Spain slightly declined during the period.
Meanwhile, Eurowings more than tripled capacity on the routes in question. That growth represents, in part, a 
transfer of capacity from Germanwings to Eurowings, as the former unit's operations are being gradually reduced 
and crewmembers migrate to Lufthansa's mainline. However, Eurowings and Germanwings' combined capacity 
share on routes to Spain still grew 2.4 percentage points to 10.5%.
Lufthansa's mainline separately raised capacity on its routes to the Mediterranean country from Frankfurt and 
Munich, with the carrier's share of overall ASKs rising from 9.2% to 10.2%. Eurowings operates from Munich today, 
but not from Frankfurt.
Other airlines, too, increased capacity in the market segment. Ryanair raised ASKs 21%, with its capacity share 
growing from 12% to 14.7%. Norwegian nearly doubled capacity as part of an effort that included launching flights 
to Spain from Dusseldorf and Hannover. Germania increased ASKs by a third and started operations from 
Nuremberg – a city previously served by Air Berlin.
Air Berlin's European network August 2017
On many routes, Niki replaced Air Berlin with no or few changes, while Eurowings flights succeeded those of 
Germanwings. Niki reduced capacity on several services. Its route between Berlin and Ibiza is a typical example: 
Niki reinstated about two-thirds of Air Berlin's vacated capacity. But on other routes – for example on flights to Las 
Palmas from Cologne and Munich – the Austrian subsidiary added capacity compared with previous Air Berlin 
operations.
There are also vacated Air Berlin routes – particularly from smaller regional airports – that Eurowings has started to 
operate without competition from Niki. Examples include Eurowings' flights to Majorca from Dresden and 
Friedrichshafen.
Eurowings has not replaced Air Berlin (yet), because Niki still operates the majority of its parent's former routes to 
Spain. But Lufthansa has already manoeuvred its budget division to an advanced position in Air Berlin's old leisure 
market – ironically with aircraft and crew wet-leased from the Oneworld carrier – and Eurowings can further expand 
its presence when Air Berlin's remaining business is divided up under the insolvency proceedings.
Niki's role as a custodian of Air Berlin's former leisure routes is relevant – particularly in view of a previous, failed 
attempt to spin the Vienna-based subsidiary off into a separate company. Before Air Berlin transferred routes and 
aircraft to Niki earlier this year, the plan was to merge the Austrian division with tourist specialist TUI Group's 
German-based flight operations to form a new European leisure carrier. TUI and Air Berlin shareholder Etihad 
Airways were set to have stakes in the new business. But the parties disclosed in June a decision to abandon the 
plan. Niki remained an Air Berlin subsidiary – and thus is now up for sale.
And among Air Berlin's assets are routes to another, large market that has so far been spared by the carrier's 
network rejig with Niki, namely Italy. Air Berlin continued operating flights to that market in co-operation with fellow 
Etihad partner Alitalia.
Load-Date: August 23, 2017
End of Document

Market Chatter: Ryanair Would Be Interested in Bidding for Insolvent Air 
Berlin
MT Newswires Live Briefs

Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) would be interested in bidding for the whole of insolvent German airline Air Berlin, 
Reuters reported, citing CEO Michael O'Leary.
The report cited O'Leary as saying its interest would be condition on access to more data on the airline's finances.

Air Berlin files for insolvency
Air Berlin files for insolvency
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
August 21, 2017
Copyright 2017 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Business and Industry News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 456 words
Body
The news should not come as a surprise to many as the Berlin-based carrier had been struggling financially for 
some time already.¬Bloomberg reports that Air Berlin has had to file for insolvency after Etihad, its biggest investor, 
ended financial support.¬Air Berlin had posted net losses in eight of the previous nine years. The German 
government has agreed to keep Air Berlin operational with a Euros 150 million bridge loan for the time being. 
National airline Lufthansa says it is ,Äúsupporting the restricting efforts of the airline jointly with the German 
government.,Äù
,ÄúLufthansa is already in negotiations with the Air Berlin Group to take over parts of Air Berlin. Lufthansa intends 
to conclude these negotiations successfully in due course.,Äù
For its part, Etihad says: ,ÄúThis development is extremely disappointing for all parties especially as Etihad has 
provided¬extensive¬to Air Berlin for its previous liquidity challenges and restructuring efforts over the past six 
years.,Äù
,ÄúAs a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer¬funding¬that would further increase our financial exposure. We 
remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties.We expect Air Berlin operations to continue 
during administration.,Äù
There is a doubt if these¬proceedings go smoothly so or not. Aviation consultant John Strickland says there could 
be problems. He says ,ÄúAir Berlin,Äôs insolvency will be a battle royal. Lufthansa will want control of the market 
capacity while Ryanair will cry foul on market competition grounds.,Äù
If all goes according to plan one would expect Air Berlin to operate its existing network for the time being. But 
changes can be expected once the busy summer period has ended.It is likely that some Air Berlin services will be 
merged with Eurowings, Lufthansa,Äôs budget subsidiary, a few may be taken over by Lufthansa Group airlines 
while others may disappear altogether.
Air Berlin,Äôs CEO Thomas Winkelmann has tweeted a statement on @airberlin to say that its schedules will 
,Äúcontinue as planned and our valid schedule remains valid,Äù.

from across the globe with Frequent Flyer Destinations Magazine, AirGuideOnline, AirGuide Destination Travel

Co. Can raised its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 4.0% during the second quarter, 
according to its most recent disclosure with the SEC. The institutional investor owned 25,800 shares of the 
transportation company's stock after buying an additional 998 shares during the period. 
Great West Life Assurance Co. Can's holdings in Ryanair Holdings PLC were worth $2,770,000 as of its most 
recent filing with the SEC.  Other hedge funds have also bought and sold shares of the company. BlackRock Inc. 
boosted its stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 2,988.0% in the first quarter. BlackRock Inc. now owns 1,306,028 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $108,374,000 after buying an additional 1,263,734 shares in 
the last quarter. JPMorgan Chase .... boosted its stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 32.9% in the first quarter.

after buying an additional 411,479 shares in the last quarter. UBS Asset Management Americas Inc. boosted its 
stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 21.4% in the first quarter. UBS Asset Management Americas Inc. now owns 
1,178,231 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $97,770,000 after buying an additional 207,777 
shares in the last quarter. Janus Capital Management LLC boosted its stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 6.3% in 
the first quarter. Janus Capital Management LLC now owns 3,297,367 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $273,610,000 after buying an additional 195,986 shares in the last quarter. Finally, American Century 
Companies Inc. boosted its stake in Ryanair Holdings PLC by 18.9% in the first quarter. American Century 
Companies Inc. now owns 1,226,359 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $101,763,000 after 
buying an additional 194,570 shares in the last quarter. 38.72% of the stock is owned by institutional investors and 
hedge funds.  Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ RYAAY[1]) opened at 115.10 on Monday. Ryanair Holdings PLC 
has a one year low of $67.56 and a one year high of $122.68.   Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last 
released its earnings results on Monday, July 24th. The transportation company reported $1.78 earnings per share 
for the quarter, topping analysts' consensus estimates of $1.48 by $0.30. The firm had revenue of $2.10 billion 
during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $2.02 billion. Ryanair Holdings PLC had a return on 
equity of 34.02% and a net margin of 21.44%. Equities analysts forecast that Ryanair Holdings PLC will post $7.58 
EPS for the current fiscal year.  Ryanair Holdings PLC announced that its Board of Directors has approved a share 
repurchase plan on Tuesday, May 30th that authorizes the company to buyback shares. This buyback authorization 
authorizes the transportation company to reacquire up to 2.3% of its stock through open market purchases. Stock 
buyback plans are often a sign that the company's board believes its shares are undervalued.

SkyWest ( SKYW ) versus Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Head to Head Comparison
SkyWest (SKYW) versus Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Head to Head 
Comparison
American Banking and Market News
August 20, 2017 Sunday
Copyright 2017 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 767 words
Body
SkyWest (NASDAQ: SKYW) and Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) are both transportation companies, but 
which is the better investment? We will contrast the two businesses based on the strength of their profitability, 
dividends, institutional ownership, risk, valuation, analyst recommendations and earnings.

provided by MarketBeat.com.

SkyWest presently has a consensus price target of $41.50, indicating a potential upside of 20.29%. Ryanair 
Holdings PLC has a consensus price target of $96.00, indicating a potential downside of 16.59%. Given SkyWest's 
stronger consensus rating and  higher possible upside, research analysts plainly believe SkyWest is more favorable 
than Ryanair Holdings PLC. 
Institutional and Insider Ownership
90.3% of SkyWest shares are held by institutional investors. Comparatively, 38.7% of Ryanair Holdings PLC shares 
are held by institutional investors. 3.5% of SkyWest shares are held by insiders. Strong institutional ownership is an 
indication that large money managers, hedge funds and endowments believe a stock will outperform the market 
over the long term.

Summary

About SkyWest
SkyWest logo SkyWest, Inc., through its subsidiaries, SkyWest Airlines, Inc. (SkyWest Airlines) and ExpressJet 
Airlines, Inc. (ExpressJet), operates regional airline operations in the United States. The Company's segments 
include SkyWest Airlines, ExpressJet and SkyWest Leasing. The SkyWest Airlines segment provides regional jet 
service to airports primarily located in the Midwestern and Western United States, as well as Mexico and Canada. 
The ExpressJet segment provides regional jet service to airports primarily located in the Eastern and Midwestern 
United States, as well as Mexico, Canada and the Caribbean. The SkyWest Leasing segment includes its E175 
aircraft ownership business. As of December 31, 2016, the Company offered scheduled passenger service with 
approximately 3,160 daily departures to destinations in the United States, Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean. The 
Company's flights are operated as Delta Connection, United Express, American Eagle or Alaska Airlines. 
About Ryanair Holdings PLC
Ryanair Holdings PLC logo Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited 
(Ryanair). Ryanair operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary 
services and engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight 
scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise. Ryanair 
markets accommodation services and travel insurance through its Website. It provides hotel and accommodation 
services. Ryanair provides its own aircraft and passenger handling and ticketing services at Dublin Airport. As of 
June 30, 2016, Ryanair had a principal fleet of over 350 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and offered over 2,000 scheduled 
short-haul flights per day serving approximately 200 airports throughout Europe.

Copa Holdings, (NYSE: CPA) and Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) are both mid-cap transportation 
companies, but which is the superior business? We will compare the two businesses based on the strength of their 
risk, profitability, dividends, institutional ownership, valuation, analyst recommendations and earnings.

endowments and large money managers believe a company will outperform the market over the long term. 
Dividends

About Copa Holdings,
Copa Holdings, logo Copa Holdings, S.A. is a provider of airline passenger and cargo service through its principal 
operating subsidiaries, Compania Panamena de Aviacion, S. A. (Copa Airlines) and AeroRepublica, S. A. (Copa 
Colombia). The Company operates through air transportation segment. Copa Airlines operates from its position 
located in the Republic of Panama. Copa Airlines provides international air transportation for passengers, cargo and 
mail, operating from its Panama City hub in the Republic of Panama. Copa Colombia provides service within 
Colombia and international flights from various cities in Colombia to Panama, Venezuela, Ecuador, Mexico, Cuba, 
Guatemala and Costa Rica. Copa Colombia provides domestic and international air transportation for passengers, 
cargo and mail with a point-to-point route network. Its subsidiary, Oval Financial Leasing, Ltd., controls the special 
purpose entities that have a beneficial interest in the majority of its fleet. 
About Ryanair Holdings PLC
Ryanair Holdings PLC logo Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited 
(Ryanair). Ryanair operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary 
services and engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight 
scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise. Ryanair 
markets accommodation services and travel insurance through its Website. It provides hotel and accommodation 
services. Ryanair provides its own aircraft and passenger handling and ticketing services at Dublin Airport. As of 
June 30, 2016, Ryanair had a principal fleet of over 350 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and offered over 2,000 scheduled 
short-haul flights per day serving approximately 200 airports throughout Europe.

were worth $538,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.

Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY[2]) opened at 115.10 on Friday. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 12-month low of 
$67.56 and a 12-month high of $122.68.   Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly 
earnings results on Monday, July 24th. The transportation company reported $1.78 earnings per share (EPS) for

share for the current year.  Ryanair Holdings PLC announced that its board has initiated a share buyback plan on 
Tuesday, May 30th that allows the company to buyback outstanding shares. This buyback authorization allows the 
transportation company to reacquire up to 2.3% of its shares through open market purchases. Shares buyback 
plans are typically an indication that the company's leadership believes its shares are undervalued.

James Osborne 1949-2017
James Osborne 1949-2017
Sunday Business Post
August 19, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 407 words
Byline: Hugh O'Connell
Body
Tributes have been paid to the highly-respected businessman and lawyer James Osborne who died suddenly last 
Thursday. He was 68.
Osborne was a long-standing director of Ryanair, the chairman of the bookseller Eason and former managing 
partner at A&L Goodbody solicitors where he first made his name having joined upon qualifying from Trinity College 
Dublin in 1973.
He became a managing partner in 1982 when he was just 32.
Julian Yarr, managing partner of A&L Goodbody, said Osborne was a “dear friend and colleague”, adding: “James 
made an exceptional contribution to A&L Goodbody and Irish corporate life”.
“As an individual, he was a hugely positive force and was held in the highest esteem by everyone he worked with 
through the years. We send our heartfelt condolences to his family and friends at this very sad time.”
A spokesman for Ryanair said, “The Board and people of Ryanair express their deepest sympathy to the family and 
friends of James Osborne, who served as a director of Ryanair for the past 21 years, on his untimely passing. He 
will be greatly missed by all who knew him. May he rest in peace.”
He also served as chairman of Independent News and Media (INM) between 2011 and 2012 when a battle between 
shareholders Denis O’Brien and Tony O’Reilly became increasingly fraught.
O’Brien voted Osborne off the board at INM in June 2012.
Osborne famously closed the meeting where he was forced out by saying: “And that concludes the annual general 
meeting of the not-so-Independent News and Media.”
James Osborne 1949-2017
In subsequent interview with the Sunday Independent he reflected: “I don't think I was either pro-O'Reilly or pro-
O'Brien, or anti O'Reilly or anti-O'Brien. I took a view on what needed to be done in the business and I believe that 
was the right view. It was quite difficult to persuade some of my directors that this was the right thing to do, but as to 
how independent they will be, we will wait and see.”
His corporate career saw him sit on the boards of Carrolls Holdings, Golden Vale and Adare.
He was due to convene the Eason annual general meeting next month.
“Managing director Liam Hanly, the board and the staff of Eason would like to express our gratitude to an 
exceptional friend and colleague. Our sympathies and condolences are with his family and friends at this time,” 
Eason said in a statement.
Osborne is survived by his partner Patricia Devine and their young daughter as well as two adult children from an 
earlier marriage.
Load-Date: August 19, 2017
End of Document
This sporting life: Colm Barrington
This sporting life: Colm Barrington
Sunday Business Post
August 19, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 3486 words
Byline: Barry J Whyte
Highlight: After nearly 50 years at the top of Irish business, it’s his involvement with the Olympic Council of Ireland 
that now drives the former Aer Lingus boss 
Body
Colm Barrington has almost half a century under his belt in Irish business. In 1968 he was 21 years old, fresh out of 
UCD with a Master’s degree in economics and he was offered a job with oil company BP.
He took it – it was, after all, the late 1960s, and jobs weren’t exactly in abundance – but things were slightly different 
for him. He had another job offer within two weeks: from Aer Lingus.
He decided to make the move. “Basically because Aer Lingus, to give it its due, was one of the few Irish companies 
at the time that was outward-looking, by Irish standards,” he says.
Barrington started off in the company’s economic planning group, doing route analysis, before moving to the US to 
work on the company’s hotels arm. By that time he had morphed from a young graduate to a young executive, 
married with two children who had been born in the US.
It was that young executive who ran into Tony Ryan, the founder of Ryanair, in the Pottery Bar at the Hibernia Hotel 
in Dublin.
Ryan asked him when he was coming back to Ireland to work with Guinness Peat Aviation, Ryan’s aircraft leasing 
business.
“And I said ‘Tony, you couldn’t afford me’,” he recalls. “That was a red rag to Tony, because he felt he could afford 
anybody. So, after nine months of negotiation, I came back and joined GPA and spent 13 years there.”
That company was bought out by the giant US investment firm GE Capital, soon after which Barrington left to set up 
his own aircraft leasing firm, Babcock & Brown, which was floated on the stock exchange ten years ago.
This sporting life: Colm Barrington
These days, he plies his trade as the chief executive of Fly Leasing, one of the leading companies in an 
increasingly booming aircraft finance industry in Ireland.
But Barrington is no single-industry man. He has a broad sweep of experience, from Eircom to the Dublin Airport 
Authority to his various directorships with IFG Group, Hibernia, Finnair, and his vice-presidency of the Olympic 
Council of Ireland.
He is currently chief executive at Fly Leasing. A lifelong sailor, he still holds the course record in the Round Ireland 
Yacht Race.
His success as an experienced Irish executive became something of a double-edged sword when shareholders in 
Hibernia – where he is a non-executive director – were urged by a proxy body to vote against him, arguing that he 
was spread too thinly across directorships.
And while Barrington holds his counsel on the Hibernia vote, it is contrary to his typical forthright approach.
Barrington will probably be remembered by history as the last chairman of an independent Aer Lingus. The former 
national carrier has gone from strength to strength, so it’s easy to forget just how controversial the sale was at the 
time. Not Barrington, though.
In fact, he had seen this eventuality coming from a long way off.
“Our view was that, in the long run, Aer Lingus probably had to be part of a larger group,” he says. “Because the 
role of small independent airlines in the world is receding.
“We did various studies and research on what would be the best partner of Aer Lingus, and had come to the 
conclusion some time before that IAG was the best partner for Aer Lingus.”
For Barrington and his fellow directors, through Aer Lingus, Dublin Airport could effectively become the third 
Heathrow runway, bringing people from Scotland and England through the continent and to the US.
At that time, though, IAG was not an interested bidder. Ryanair was, but Barrington was not impressed.
“First of all, the Ryanair price wasn’t ever acceptable. Secondly, Ryanair’s bid was never going to be accepted by 
European competition authority unless Ryanair did what it was proposing to do – in its third and final bid – which 
was to effectively eviscerate Aer Lingus’s European operations.
“The only way Ryanair would have got competition was effectively to close down Aer Lingus’s short-haul 
operations. So we rejected the deal on the basis that we couldn’t succeed. But we never got to reject it on the basis 
of our price, which would have been our next step.”
Why, in Barrington’s view, did Ryanair even make a bid, given that the competition issue was so significant? “I’d say 
it’s mischievous as anything else,” he deadpans.
Nevertheless, it was not an easy ride. “It was very damaging to our interests. I mean, I took over as chairman in 
October 2007, and we got our second round of bidding in November,” he says.
It meant part of the company’s attention was focused on the bid when it ought to have been focused elsewhere.
“In early 2008, we found we were entering the summer season with too much capacity on the wrong routes,” says 
Barrington. “So my own view is that the second Ryanair bid probably cost Aer Lingus and its shareholders at least 
€100 million – maybe €150 million – because it took the eye off the ball.
[caption id="attachment_395774" align="alignright" width="391"] Colm Barrington: ‘We’re a relatively small country, 
but we’re a relatively rich country’ Picture: Bryan Meade[/caption]
“So that was pretty stressful, all right. And it cost us the chief executive.”
This sporting life: Colm Barrington
Barrington declines to go any further, pleading that to do so would breach extant confidentiality agreements, but he 
is presumably referring to Dermot Mannion, who faced a great degree of shareholder unease after the first two 
Ryanair bids, and who was replaced with Christoph Mueller, who faced down a third Ryanair bid.
And so, on to the next bid: IAG.
“Literally, shortly after [getting the company’s pension problems resolved], we got a call from the head of the IAG 
saying could we talk? And then he and Willie Walsh came to Dublin, and Christoph and I met them, and they gave 
us a letter of offer.”
Barrington and his fellow directors reckoned that the intention was right, but the price was wrong, so there ensued a 
period of shadow-boxing over the price.
“The problem is, none of those valuations are ever terribly precise. There’s always a range,” he says.
To avoid the situation in which a target company is (in his words) bidding against itself, they tend to avoid giving a 
direct price. Instead, it’s all shuttle diplomacy and sotto voce indications.
“They have their investment bank, as we in Ireland have our investment bankers,” he says. “That sort of back-of-
the-room chat.”
Eventually, on the third price – which had risen from €2.30 to €2.55, compared to Ryanair’s 2012 offer of €1.30 – 
Barrington and his board concluded they had got an acceptable offer. But acceptance by the board does not mean 
the deal is over the line. It still has to go to the shareholders. And, more than most companies, Aer Lingus’s share 
register was a strange beast.
Two rival airlines had stakes, with Ryanair on around 30 per cent and Etihad sitting on a couple of per cent. The 
employees had 10 per cent. The Irish state held a portion of shares. And the rest was made up by institutional 
investors.
“We weren’t really a plc at all,” says Barrington. “We were sort of a tightly held company, like many other Irish plcs, 
which made it very difficult for the board, who had to look after the interests of the shareholders and the company 
because they were all quite different.”
And then there was the politics.
“The unions thought having a government shareholder would help their position, in terms of negotiations 
commitments with them. And the government, in my seven years of experience of being there, actually behaved 
very responsibly and never put undue pressure on the airline, in terms of industrial relations issues. They obviously 
heard their opinion on things like services in and out of Shannon and so on, but they always behaved very, very 
properly.”
All of which produced a stress of its own, not least when Barrington and his chief executive Stephen Kavanagh – 
who had replaced Mueller in early 2015 – came before the Oireachtas Public Accounts Committee to explain the 
rationale for the sale. Barrington’s distaste is still palpable today.
“It wasn’t gruelling,” he says. “It was pathetic, rather than gruelling. You could answer the questions easily. But the 
questions weren’t to point. They weren’t on why Aer Lingus should be doing this, why is it good for Aer Lingus, good 
for its employees, good for its shareholders, good for the company, you know. It was all to do with very limited 
sectional things.”
As with all flag carriers, it was part emotional decision, part commercial, and it’s clear that Barrington felt it was the 
best way for Aer Lingus to survive in a changing market.
“In some ways, it was a pang of regret,” he says. “In some ways it was sort of a pang of satisfaction.”
This sporting life: Colm Barrington
Today, Aer Lingus is going from strength to strength as a partly independent business within the wider IAG group. 
Meanwhile, its one-time rival, Ryanair, is surging ahead in no uncertain terms.
One could forgive Barrington for having some lingering resentment over the mega-aggressive approach that 
Ryanair and its chief executive, Michael O’Leary, took during its failed efforts to buy Aer Lingus. Perhaps 
unsurprisingly, Barrington is quite complimentary of O’Leary and his airline – if a little pointed, too.
“I’ve travelled Ryanair recently. And I must say, the service is not bad at all. The staff are much more pleasant than 
they used to be. They still [have] the yellow [colour scheme]; it’s a bit jarring. And the horns still go off [when a plane 
lands]. But I think it’s a bit better.”
Indeed, he’s positively glowing in his compliments for O’Leary, who has virtually single-handedly built Ryanair into a 
European airline powerhouse.
[caption id="attachment_395775" align="alignright" width="1024"] Tony Ryan, former owner and founder of Ryanair, 
hired Barrington for Guinness Peat Aviation in 1979[/caption]
The joke about Ryanair, Barrington says, referring to a conversation he once had with another airline chief 
executive, was that while most airlines make the most money from their last passenger, Ryanair works to make 
sure it doesn’t get the last passenger.
But while that’s the joke, the evidence doesn’t bear it out. “If you read their load factors these days, they are in the 
90 per cent range in January, February and early March. I mean, they’re doing remarkably well,” Barrington says.
And the future is secure, too, he says, arguing that there’ll be no post-O’Leary crisis in Ryanair in the way there was 
a post-Jobs crisis in Apple.
“Companies need different people at different times,” he says. “Ryanair needed Michael when it was actually 
scrabbling to get the payroll every week. Now it’s an up-and-running organisation that keeps the systems going and 
then keeps a very tight rein on the costs,” he says.
O’Leary has helped to bring in a whole new generation of executives such as Kenny Jacobs who could, Barrington 
believes, easily do the job as well as him.
The question now is one of where Ryanair builds its growth. Having missed out on picking up Aer Lingus’s 
transatlantic network at a snip, will the airline ever really start flying to the US?
“The reasons for not going transatlantic are bullshit,” says Barrington. “They say they can’t get appropriate aircraft 
without advice. It’s nonsense. I mean, my business is aircraft leasing, and there are plenty of wide body aircraft if 
that’s what they want.
“I think it’s very difficult to be truly low-cost on the Atlantic because so much of your expense is your aircraft and 
your fuel and your points at the end, whereas on short haul you can keep your staff costs lower, and your airport 
costs lower, or at a more significant part of your total cost.
“I’m not saying it doesn’t work, it just doesn’t work as well on long-haul as it does on short-haul.”
And, of course, O’Leary is no fool – he’s not going to throw away money if he’s not guaranteed a profit.
“He’s so far away from being a fool it’s unbelievable,” says Barrington. “He may act one, but he’s certainly not a 
fool.”
Last year, Barrington was elected first vice-president – that is to say, one of the two vice-presidents – of the 
Olympic Council of Ireland.
This sporting life: Colm Barrington
“I’ve been absolutely disgusted with the way we were treated by the Olympic Council of Ireland,” he says, attributing 
it to the fact that Richard Burrows, who is a sailor, ran against Pat Hickey for the post of OCI president some years 
ago.It meant that when Hickey stepped down, Barrington saw a chance to sweep a new broom through the OCI 
board.“I wouldn’t have had time to become president, even if I had wanted to. So I gave my full support to Sarah 
Keane, and we got a team of candidates together and we put in effectively a block candidacy. And we all got 
elected. The 11 of us who went up got elected by pretty significant majorities.”
The question now is how to clean out Irish sport’s own version of the Augean Stables.Barrington is understandably 
keen not to focus unduly on the Moran report or the arrest of Pat Hickey in Rio and the ensuing coverage of the 
Brazilian ticket touting investigation. There were other problems, he points out, and bigger problems for the OCI’s 
management.
“There was huge publicity over the tickets, but it was a relatively minor issue. Taking the case of sailing: the 
Olympic village was about an hour and a half commute from the sailing centre. We said to the OCI: ‘We can’t have 
our young people commuting backwards and forwards. How could anyone have the chance to be successful while 
doing that commute every day?’ So we needed accommodation by the sailing centre. The OCI said: ‘Sorry, you’re 
on your own on that.’ So it cost us €24,000 to hire apartments near the sailing centre.
“Then there were logistics, getting the boats and equipment out. The OCI said: ‘They’re leaving on July 7.’ We said: 
‘Sorry, we need our kids on the water on July 1.’ So we had to pay another twenty-something grand.“On 
accreditations, we tried to [get them for] our team management, our coaches, our athletes, our doctors, our physio. 
The OCI said: ‘Sorry, we can only have so many accreditations’.”
[caption id="attachment_395778" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Pat Hickey, former OCI president[/caption]
The fallout from Rio continues to bedevil the preparations for Tokyo 2020.“I mean, Rio is costing a fortune,” says 
Barrington. “I signed off yesterday on over €100,000 of legal bills related to one of the old board, for the advice that 
this person recieved for the Moran Tribunal [the inquiry into the ticket touting affair]. Over €100,000 we’ve had to 
pay.
“As I said to somebody the other day: ‘We don’t even know where the cupboards are, let alone what skeletons are 
in them yet.’ So that’s going nowhere, and it’s cost us a fortune.”
Meanwhile, they have to continue the business of preparing their athletes for Tokyo.“I think we’ve got 12 
scholarships for young athletes who are competing now for the next Olympics,” he says. “These all come from the 
Olympic International Committee, which is unbelievable. They have more than 600 people. I don’t know what their 
budget is, hundreds of millions. And they give us a good grant every year, and they provide other scholarships and 
what they call Olympic solidarity grants and things. So we’re now really focused on getting all of those we can and 
passing them along.”
Such funding is vital for them right now, because as Barrington puts it: “Sponsorship’s an issue for us now because 
we’re somewhat toxic until we get the whole Rio thing sorted. But we’ll work on that over the next year.”Barrington 
is unabashed in his hunger for medals.“We’re a relatively small country, but we’re a relatively rich country. We’re 
sports-mad, but we’re sports-diverse. We’ve got hurling, football, rugby, Gaelic football, hurling, horseracing, 
cycling, tennis, cricket, hockey. We play every sport in the world. Whereas countries like Denmark are much more 
focused.”
This can mean that Ireland’s athletic and Olympic success is somewhat constrained. Barrington, typically, is more 
blunt. “Our success [rate] in the Olympics is awful. We got two silver medals in the last Olympics. I think we’re the 
65th country on the Olympics medals tables.”
I point out that by other metrics – say, personal bests by Irish athletes – the trend line is actually rising. That cuts no 
ice with Barrington.“The personal best I don’t regard as being a good measure. It’s good for the athlete, but it 
doesn’t help the country as such. You know, okay, it’s great that someone can go to the Olympics and achieve their 
personal best. But that personal best isn’t as good enough as 20 other athletes.”
This sporting life: Colm Barrington
But isn’t it a sign of real development?“It’s a good level of achievement. But, again, I’ve always been an 
internationalist. An example: Annalise Murphy getting her silver medal has had a hugely positive impact on young 
people in Ireland, and particularly girls.”He acknowledges he’s being somewhat reductive, and that plenty of world-
class Irish athletes have never won a medal. They are still Olympians of the first class, he says, but medals are the 
goal.
“You know, I was a sailor and I never got to the Olympic Games,” he says. “So I fully understand that. But on the 
other hand, you know, there are people out there who are the best in the world, and we should be trying to get 
some of the best in the world and helping them get there.
So how many medals can Ireland realistically win?“I would certainly hope they would be getting up into double 
figures if we do things right over the next three or four Olympic cycles.”
 
In his nearly 50 years in Irish business, Barrington has seen it all: mergers, acquisitions, recessions, Tiger 
economies and all sorts of government prescriptions to fix or improve the economy. It gives him a good perspective 
on what Ireland’s been through over the last decade.
“We never should have guaranteed that bank debt. The government should not have paid off that bank debt. That 
was bondholders, who made bad decisions,” he says, pointing out that he had money on deposit with Anglo Irish 
Bank in 2002, but withdrew it because he felt they were “a one-trick pony”.
“If I, as an ignorant person, could do that 15 years ago, how come a German bondholder couldn’t do it? And why 
am I now being forced to pay higher taxes to pay that?”
He acknowledges that while the bank bailout remains a serious contributor to Ireland’s current problems, it’s partly 
ancient history. What can be done now?
“I think we’ve done reasonably well, considering the levels of debt and considering where we were in 2008 and 
2009,” he says. “But we’ve got to stay competitive, and if we start going now trying to get back to where we were in 
2004, in terms of payroll and so on, we just can’t afford it.
“I don’t believe we had a period of austerity. I believe we had a period of reality. We were just over the top. I think 
we’ve got to retain reality for the timebeing and stay competitive.
“I really think we have a serious issue. We have too much debt, we can’t be flathúileach in our expenditure while we 
have that debt. We’ve got to get our current account into order. And if we’d had our current account in order before, 
then we could have told everyone to go bugger off.
“But because we needed to continue to borrow it, we had to go along with it. And, y’know, if you’re not living within 
your means, then you’re in trouble.”
Sponsorship’s an issue for [the OCI] now because we’re somewhat toxic until we get the whole Rio thing sorted. 
But we’ll work on that over the next year
Is it possible for Ireland to do that, really? Will we always effectively be a client state of other countries and of other 
corporations?
“Well, small countries can be self-sufficient,” says Barrington. “We’re coming from a bad place. We’ve had 50 years 
of economic stagnation so it’s only in relatively recent times [that the economy has been strong].
“We don’t have an industrial infrastructure like Switzerland that’s been built over decades. But we are building up 
pretty good industry in Ireland now. But we mustn’t kill the golden goose before the golden debt is paid off.”
Unsurprisingly for a lifelong businessman, he believes efficiency is the key.
This sporting life: Colm Barrington
“My big thing is efficiency. Because if you’re efficient, you can afford to pay people now. But if you’re inefficient, you 
can’t afford to pay people. So I’m a believer in efficiency and having a relatively good compensation.”
Efficiency, in corporate terms, means cutting costs and jobs.
“Or growing the business into them,” says Barrington. “But, again, people shouldn’t be so concerned in this day and 
age – particularly now the way the economy is going – about being got rid of, because there are other opportunities 
out there.
“So if you work these things properly, and you know people aren’t so narrowly focused that they think they can only 
work as, let’s say, a porter in the Mater Hospital. There are actually other jobs out there, and they may actually offer 
them better jobs and better pay, you know, if they get their minds open to doing it.”
Still, efficiency in national terms is a lot more complex and indeed emotionally charged. The state isn’t a commercial 
business, I point out.
“I know,” Barrington says. “That’s the problem.”
Load-Date: August 19, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair fury as Lufthansa sizes up Air Berlin assets Airlines
Ryanair fury as Lufthansa sizes up Air Berlin assets; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
August 19, 2017 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 11
Length: 249 words
Byline: TANYA POWLEY
Body
Air Berlin became the second large European airline to go bankrupt this summer after it was forced to file for 
insolvency on Tuesday when its biggest shareholder pulled its funding.
Germany's second-largest carrier was saved from a full collapse after Berlin stepped in with a (EURO)150m loan to 
keep the airline flying through the busy summer months while it negotiated the sale of parts of the business to 
Lufthansa and one other airline.
The move was triggered when Etihad, the Abu Dhabibased airline that owns 29 per cent of Air Berlin, decided not to 
pump in any more money after providing a series of cash injections over the past six years to keep it afloat.
Air Berlin's insolvency comes just four months after Alitalia, the Italian carrier, entered administration after its 
employees rejected a restructuring plan and Etihad, which also owns a significant stake in Alitalia, said it would 
provide no more funding.
Air Berlin has been under pressure after racking up losses of about (EURO)2bn over the past six years. The 
situation has worsened as Etihad has faced its own challenges, forcing it to unravel its strategy of buying minority 
stakes in airlines to drive traffic to its hub in the Gulf. Etihad made losses of $1.9bn in 2016.
Air Berlin's collapse has sparked a fierce battle over the rights to prime German take-off and landing slots, with 
Ryanair, Europe's biggest low-cost airline, branding a state bailout of the airline as a "conspiracy" to protect national 
carrier Lufthansa.
Ryanair fury as Lufthansa sizes up Air Berlin assets Airlines
Graphic
 
Air Berlin's collapse was triggered when Etihad, the Abu Dhabi-based airline that owns 29 per cent of the German 
carrier, decided not to pump in any more money

LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Barcelona And Trump Worries See Stocks End Lower
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Barcelona And Trump Worries See Stocks End 
Lower
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
August 18, 2017 Friday 12:14 PM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 1051 words
Body
 Stocks ended lower on Friday, as further troubles with US President Donald Trump's administration and two 
terrorist attacks in Spain led to a major risk-off sentiment among investors. 
The FTSE 100 index closed down 1.0%, or 72.46 points, at 7,315.41. The blue-chip index ended the week up 0.2%. 
The FTSE 250 ended down 0.8%, or 156.42 points, at 19,616.66, and up 0.5% for the week as a whole. The AIM 
All-Share closed down 0.3%, or 2.66 points, at 999.66, up 1.0% for the week. 
The BATS UK 100 ended down 0.9% at 12,453.19, the BATS 250 closed down 0.8% at 17,826.03, and the BATS 
Small Companies ended 0.3% lower at 12,158.79.
The number of people killed in two terrorist attacks in Spain rose to 14, after a woman died from injuries sustained 
in a car-ramming incident in Cambrils, emergency services said Friday. Thirteen people were killed in Barcelona 
when a van rammed into people in the pedestrian area of Las Ramblas, a tourist hotspot in the centre of town. More 
than 100 others were injured.
The Islamic State group said via its affiliated Amaq news agency that its "soldiers" were responsible for the attack.
Travel and tourism-related stocks were hit in the wake of the terrorist attack, and whilst they regained some ground 
throughout the day, still ended among the worst performers. 
International Consolidated Airlines Group closed as the worst performer, down 3.1%. IAG, which owns British 
Airways and Aer Lingus, has high exposure to Spain via Iberia and Vueling, a low-cost airline based in Barcelona. 
IAG also owns Level, a low-cost long-haul airline, also based in the Catalan capital.
Irish carrier Ryanair Holdings closed down 1.5%, whilst peer easyJet ended down 0.7%. Hotel operator 
InterContinental Hotels Group closed down 1.6%.
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Barcelona And Trump Worries See Stocks End Lower
Across the pond, US House of Representatives Leader Nancy Pelosi led a call by Democratic lawmakers to remove 
Confederate statues on display in the halls of Congress. The Democrats rejected President Donald Trump's 
criticism of the removal of "beautiful" Confederate statues.
The heated nationwide debate over the removal of monuments to the Confederacy reached Capitol Hill Thursday 
when Pelosi called on House Speaker Paul Ryan to start the process for removing memorials for leaders of the 
Confederacy. The removal of a statue of Robert E Lee had led to deadly clashes between white nationalists and 
protesting crowds in Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend.
Trump had drawn fire for not speaking out forcefully enough against white supremacists in the wake of violence at 
the rally in Charlottesville that left one woman dead. 
Eight members of the President's American Manufacturing Council - including the chief executives of Dow 
Chemical, Intel, Merck, 3M, Johnson &amp; Johnson and United Technologies - have resigned since Sunday over 
the issue, while all members of the Strategic &amp; Policy Forum agreed to quit the group Wednesday. 
This has led to ongoing concerns among investors about Trump's ability to implement his pro-business agenda. 
Upon his inauguration as US president, Trump initially said he would ramp up infrastructure spending in the US. 
Among the blue-chip decliners in London were equipment rental company Ashtead, closing down 2.8%, and 
building materials group CRH, closing down 1.8%. Both companies have significant exposure to the US 
construction market. 
"Trump's decision to disband the advisory council on infrastructure has put a dent in their share prices. Both stocks 
were given a boost by the election of Trump as he pledged to ramp up spending on infrastructure, but now traders 
are getting out of their positions on the back of recent developments," said IG Group analyst David Madden.
At the other end of the large-cap index, Randgold Resources ended as the best performer, up 1.7%, as the sell-off 
in equities led to a rise in the gold price, with investors moving back to 'safe-haven' assets. Fellow gold miner 
Acacia Mining was the best mid-cap performer, closing up 6.5%.
The precious metal was quoted at USD1,289.67 an ounce against USD1,284.32 a the London equities close on 
Thursday. Gold hit an intraday high of USD1,300.70, a level it has not seen since November 2016.
"The decline in global equities has helped the demand for gold as it is deemed to be a safe haven asset. On risk-off 
days is it not surprising to see funds flow out of stocks and into gold. The dip in the US dollar today also helped the 
metal. It is interesting that gold took out the June high of USD1,296, because this could be the start of a leg higher. 
After all, traders are not worried about an interest rate hike from the Fed in the next few months," Madden said. 
In Paris the CAC 40 ended down 0.6%, while the DAX 30 in Frankfurt ended down 0.3%. 
On a light day in the global economic calendar, the pound was quoted at USD1.2846 at the London equities close 
Friday, compared to USD1.2884 at the same time on Thursday. The euro stood at USD1.1740 at the European 
equities close, against USD1.1741 the prior day.
Stocks in New York were mixed at the London equities close. The DJIA was down 0.2%, the S&amp;P 500 index 
was flat and the Nasdaq Composite up 0.2%.
"Markets have extended their losses this afternoon in the UK and Europe, but in the US declines have slowed 
markedly, while this year's most crowded trade, the Nasdaq, is actually eking out some gains. The classic 
symptoms of August markets have been seen – lack of news, an abundance of rumour, and low volumes. Given 
that the previous three weeks had been some of the most quiet in the post-war history of the S&amp;P 500, it is not 
surprising to see volatility that would, in 2016, have been considered run of the mill, being the occasion for 
heightened nervousness, if not outright panic," said IG analyst Chris Beauchamp.
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Barcelona And Trump Worries See Stocks End Lower
Brent oil was a touch higher and was quoted at USD51.75 a barrel at the close on Friday, from USD50.67 at the 
same time the prior day. 
In the economic calendar on Monday, Rightmove house prices are released at midnight, while the UK public sector 
net borrowing data are at 0930 BST. In the US, the Chicago Federal Reserve national activity index is at 1330 BST. 
In a thin UK corporate calendar, there are interim results from TBC Bank Group, Headlam Group, and Global Ports 
Holding.

LONDON MARKET OPEN: Travel Stocks Tumble After Barcelona Attacks
LONDON MARKET OPEN: Travel Stocks Tumble After Barcelona Attacks
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
August 18, 2017 Friday 3:38 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 576 words
Body
 Stocks in London were lower on Friday morning, with tourism-related stocks heavily hit as investors digest the 
news of a terrorist attack in Barcelona late Thursday.
International Consolidated Airlines Group was down 3.2%, while easyJet was 3.1% lower, the worst two blue-chip 
performers in early trade. 
IAG - the owner of British Airways and Irish airline Aer Lingus - also owns Spanish carriers Iberia and Vueling, a 
low-cost airline based in Barcelona. IAG also owns Level, a low-cost long-haul airline, also based in the Spanish 
city. 
InterContinental Hotels Group was down 1.4%, while cruise operator Carnival was down 1.2%.
FTSE 250-listed air carrier Wizz Air Holdings was down 1.7%, while fellow mid-cap travel operator Thomas Cook 
was down 1.9%. Ryanair Holdings was down 2.2%.
Transport firm National Express Group was the worst mid-cap performer, down 2.7%. 
A van crashed into a crowd of people in Las Ramblas, on one of Barcelona's busiest thoroughfares, with local 
media reporting at least 13 people had been killed in what police said was a terrorist attack.
Two people had already been arrested. Spanish police have arrested a third suspect after the deadly van attack in 
Barcelona, newspaper El Pais reported Friday, citing the Catalan interior ministry.
It is not known whether the driver of the van was the latest person arrested, as this person is still believed on the 
run.
Hours after the attack on the Las Ramblas, police said they had killed five suspects who tried to mow down 
pedestrians in the town of Cambrils.
LONDON MARKET OPEN: Travel Stocks Tumble After Barcelona Attacks
The FTSE 100 index was down 0.6%, or 46.33 points at 7,341.54. The mid-cap FTSE 250 index was down 0.4% at 
19,693.20, and the AIM All-Share index was down 0.1% at 1,002.32.
The BATS UK 100 index was down 0.7% at 12,474.36. The BATS 250 was down 0.5% at 18,872.84. The BATS 
Small Companies was marginally lower at 12,185.46.
In mainland Europe, the CAC 40 index in Paris and the DAX 30 in Frankfurt were down 1.1% and 0.9%, 
respectively. 
In Asia, the Japanese Nikkei 225 index ended down 1.2%. In China, the Shanghai Composite closed flat, while the 
Hang Seng index in Hong Kong was down 0.9%.
Gold was quoted at USD1,294.02 an ounce early Friday compared to USD1,284.32 an ounce at the London 
equities close on Thursday. Gold miners Fresnillo and Randgold Resources were benefiting from the higher price, 
up 1.5% and 1.0%, respectively.
RSA Insurance was another gainer in the FTSE 100 index, up 1.2%, after RBC Capital upgraded the firm to 
Outperform from Sector Perform.
In the economic calendar on Friday, eurozone current account and construction output are at 1000 BST. In the US, 
the Michigan consumer sentiment index is at 1500 BST, while the Baker Hughes oil rig count at 1800 BST.
Already out, German producer prices rose at the slowest pace so far this year in July, data from Destatis showed.
Producer prices for industrial products advanced 2.3% year-on-year in July, slightly weaker than the 2.4% increase 
seen in June. This was the weakest since December, when prices gained 1%. Economists had forecast 2.2% 
annual increase.
Month-on-month, producer prices gained 0.2% after staying flat in June. Prices were forecast to remain unchanged 
in July.
Prices of all main industrial groups increased from the previous year in July. Prices of non-durable consumer goods 
increased 3.7% and prices of intermediate goods grew 3%. Energy prices moved up 1.9% and that of durable 
consumer goods and capital goods increased 1.1%, each.
