What you’re in today might not be what you’re doing in five years
What you’re in today might not be what you’re doing in five years
Sunday Business Post
August 5, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1827 words
Byline: Leanna Byrne
Highlight: For Nicola Byrne, founder of 11890 directory enquiries, any business setback is nothing more than a 
reason to clamber back up on the horse again 
Body
CV: Nicola Byrne
Role: chief executive and founder of 11890 and Cloud90
Age: 46
Family: three children, and partnered with Conor
Hobbies: singing
Favourite film: Independence Day, directed by Roland Emmerich
‘You don’t realise how much you’ve done until you’ve done it,” says Nicola Byrne, in a tone of complete conviction.
The chief executive and founder of 11890 directory enquiries and Cloud90, a social media analytics company, is 
sitting in a dimly-lit basement on Merrion Square, the headquarters of the Irish Exporters Association (IEA), where 
she has recently been installed as president. She says that upstairs is a lot nicer, but she is not fussed.
The following hour feels like a motivational talk, a story of reaching dead ends, changing directions and starting 
again. For Byrne, getting back on one’s horse is an art form – a mere shrug of the shoulders. Sure, she’s hit the 
rocks with her companies, but so what?
“I was recently talking to this lovely girl whose business had gone kaput. I was laughing at her, going: ‘What are you 
sitting there feeling sorry for yourself for? You’re not going from one failure to the other, you’re just getting better at 
it’,” says Byrne.
What you’re in today might not be what you’re doing in five years
“If my business fails, it’s not that I’m not good at running a business, it’s that the market turns and that’s what 
happens. The world keeps moving and what you’re in today might not be what you’re doing in five years.
“We’re not all lucky enough to work solidly in a business that doesn’t change. There are very few industries that are 
untouched. There are some that have thrived. Sometimes you’re just at the wrong side of the curve.”
Her first company, Stenic Media, sold advertisements for the back of travel ticket wallets. At its height, it put top 
brands like Jaguar and Rolex on tickets for Aer Lingus, Ryanair, Irish Ferries and Stena Line. Then, in the wake of 
9/11, travel volume plummeted, airline industry losses soared and advertising was slashed.
So Byrne moved on to 11890, which was a success – until the internet came along. Another readjustment was 
necessary and, in 2014, the business launched a social media tracking service called Cloud90.
“I think the important thing I’ve learned along the way is that failing isn’t a bad thing. Most of these guys who made 
billions are frauds. They get lucky building a technology company and they’re going around claiming all the credit 
for it. It was luck and circumstance. They didn’t have any more talent than anybody else,” says Byrne.
“The guy who comes in to talk down to you is the guy who’s got absolutely nothing behind it. He’s got no skills and 
he couldn’t repeat it to save his life. He couldn’t pass on any tips to you because he got lucky, so he can’t explain 
it.”
If it all turns sour, Byrne says that she has a full taxi licence to fall back on.
“I did it as a backup for my dad. Now I just go in and renew it every year. If all else fails, I’m going back to taxi 
driving,” she says.
Byrne was born in Cabra and raised in Portmarnock, and her father is one of her biggest influences. He claims to 
have had 17 different jobs, starting off as a pattern cutter.
“He’s been a shop owner, a taxi man and a salesman in Johnston Mooney & O’Brien. He always did what it took to 
survive,” says Byrne.
“There was no ego, there were no preconceptions, he just did what it took. He would go out at 7am and I wouldn’t 
see him till 9pm. He worked really hard, and we always had enough to get by.”
Her mother was a furrier, preparing and dealing in furs, which allowed Byrne and her brother and sister to frequently 
don mock fur hats and coats.
Byrne attended St Marnock’s National School and Portmarnock Community School. As she describes it, her 
schooling years were the equivalent of “trying to fit a square peg in a really round hole”.
“Everyone learns differently, and I learned quickly. But I learned from listening, not that anyone would believe that 
with the amount I talk. Not everyone keeps up with the same speed. I would find it awfully frustrating. I would think: 
‘The answer is this, obviously.’ You just realise you’re different. You don’t fit,” says Byrne.
Byrne failed her Leaving Certificate on her first attempt. But she repeated, and went on to study for a Fás course in 
freight forwarding and customs clearance.
Her first job was as an export clerk at Gateaux, one of Ireland’s largest cake manufacturers owned by Lyons 
Holdings. Her next jobs were at Jacob’s Biscuits, Evian, 98FM, AC Nielsen and Bank of Ireland. While she was 
working for the last of those companies, the idea for Stenics Media struck her.
“I had been doing a lot of travelling, and every time I flew with an international airline, I got a ticket wallet with an ad 
on it. Aer Lingus, I realised, didn’t have any ads. My dad was doing some work for the chairman of Aer Lingus, and I 
said: ‘Can you ask him if I can have a meeting?’” says Byrne.
What you’re in today might not be what you’re doing in five years
At the tender age of 27, she convinced David Brunworth, the then commercial director for Aer Lingus, to give her a 
contract to sell advertising for the airline. This led her to securing contracts with Ryanair, Irish Ferries and Stena 
Line.
“A huge amount of people came on board and said: ‘If you can have theirs, you can have all of ours.’ I got them all,” 
says Byrne.
Stenics Media then won the business for the Eircom telephone book, as well as An Post. At the weekends, up to 70 
people would have been posting stickers on telephone boxes all across the country with the ads that her company 
sold.
The company still exists, but is considerably smaller than it was at its height.
In 2006, Byrne founded 11890. The idea for the company came to her when she was on holiday with her family in 
Blackpool. Her brother was working in telecoms at the time, and started talking about how the market was 
deregulating and how profitable it was. Byrne jumped in.
It started with business-to-business and signed up the likes of KPMG, An Post and AIB. It eventually grew to two 
call centres, one in Dublin and one in Galway.
Six years later, however, the internet had caught up and directory enquiries were something to scroll through, not to 
phone for.
But Byrne had another idea: if the internet was stealing her lunch, why shouldn’t she dine out on the internet?
If all else fails, I’m going back to taxi driving . . . I did it as a backup for my dad
Three years ago, 11890 launched Cloud90, a service that tracks social media messages and relays them to a 
dashboard at the customer’s offices.
Crisis management is a key market for the service, whose aim is to put businesses in a better position to respond 
quickly.
“We read the internet live and collect the risks. We read every single post issued by the bank, about the bank, and 
from the bank. We read every single one, and criteria it for a risk and content and sentiment,” says Byrne.
“We have an automated service and we just stream it in. People in marketing departments are supposedly reading 
this stream of data, but the bigger guys who are using it for the last four years have recognised the risks are too 
great.
“In a large organisation, everyone has the power to see the data simultaneously, but nobody is analysing it in one 
place; everyone is working off emotional data and instinct. What I discovered is that it’s flawed, enormously.”
This time, it was Ulster Bank which took a leap of faith with Byrne. Once built, the software notified the bank about a 
bank raid on one occasion. “A guy on the street took a picture with the cops and robbers everywhere and the 
caption was: ‘It looks like we have a bank raid.’ I got the alert in a minute and a half. Head office then knew that this 
was going on. It was their first notice of it happening,” says Byrne.
She finds the whole world of social media to be fascinating. How people act, speak with and document their lives on 
this new tool is almost mesmerising when the data is perused.
“You have the regular agitators that complain about everything,” Byrne says. “They’re like children and they have no 
filter between them and the keyboard. As a child, you learn to articulate yourself, and then as an adult, you regulate 
that, realising that you can’t just say anything that comes into your head. The internet and the power of the 
individual phone have removed those rules again, and people think it’s okay to go out and say whatever they think – 
What you’re in today might not be what you’re doing in five years
and it’s not. They’re fools who have an opinion, and they think their opinion matters more than everyone else,” says 
Byrne.
“We’ve lost the ability to discern fact and fiction. They have become so blurred you can’t tell any more. The kids 
today are going to have a real problem working out which is which. If they were left to their own devices, they would 
think the world is ending and we’re all going to hell in a handcart. We’re just not.”
Byrne’s hypothesis is that social media is just a set of new languages that humans have yet to grasp. “You can 
think of the internet as sets of rules being born, with millions of new languages. There are Twitter rules, Google 
rules, Facebook rules,” she says.
Cloud90 has been a success. Today, the company employs 53 and has also developed another online reputation 
management tool called RiskEye. It is even in talks with BT in Britain to kickstart its scaling across the Irish sea.
Byrne’s latest challenge is her 18-month presidency of the Irish Exporters Association, for which Ireland’s existential 
threat du jour is Brexit.
“The one thing that Europe gave us is solid secure political platform to trade,” says Byrne.
“Trade keeps everyone out of poverty. Choosing not to want to trade with somebody is the most bizarre thing I’ve 
ever seen. The history of the world is where trade is open, everybody wins. Where trade isn’t open, everybody dies. 
I just can’t understand why you would have such a policy not to want to trade with your nearest partner.”
More than ever, she says, Ireland needs to grow its exports. It is the only way the country will survive.
“The government needs to be more aware that our food exports are important, but when these food exports get big 
enough they open planta in other countries. It stops being an export, it’s then a local product. So Kerrygold has 
plants in the US and it’s a global company and registered in Ireland, and it still pays all its taxes here in Ireland, so 
that’s fantastic. We just need ten of them,” says Byrne.
Challenges at work are not enough, however. One of Byrne’s defining characteristics is that she is a restless soul, 
taking up challenges outside office hours too.
“I’ve taken up piano lessons,” she says enthusiastically. “I went on my own to the classes on the first night, and she 
asked us to sing Twinkle Twinkle Little Star in tune, and I thought: ‘Good luck with that.’ We spent about an hour 
and a half on it, and I came back home and could just about repeat it to the neighbour, Cathy.
“She asked could she come too, so for two and a half years we’ve been going. We can sing eight songs now in 
tune. We’re not natural talents, but at least we’re giving it a go.”
Load-Date: August 5, 2017
End of Document
Rome sets out conditions for Alitalia bid process Airlines
Rome sets out conditions for Alitalia bid process; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
August 5, 2017 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 13
Length: 256 words
Byline: JAMES POLITI
Body
Italian-appointed commissioners set out the key conditions this week for tabling bids in the public tender for the 
country's collapsed airline Alitalia.
The Italian government is hoping to avoid the break-up of the flag carrier by insisting that it will give preference to 
bids for the entire company.
The conditions are designed to prevent would-be buyers trying to carve off lucrative routes or valuable assets, such 
as key buildings owned by Alitalia, from participating. Over the past two months, the commissioners have sounded 
out the market and received non-binding offers from at least 10 carriers, including Ryanair, Etihad and easyJet.
The airline collapsed in May, bringing three years of investment by Etihad, the UAE carrier, to a bitter end.
The group, which has been run by three commissioners since it collapsed, is demanding bids for the whole 
company, or failing that, separate bids for its aviation business, including maintenance, and its ground handling 
business.
The deadline for the public tender for binding offers is October 2. The process is being managed by bankers at 
Rothschild.
In an email to the Financial Times, Luigi Gubitosi, one of three state-appointed commissioners running Alitalia, 
expressed confidence that a buyer would be found.
Rome sets out conditions for Alitalia bid process Airlines
Groups such as Ryanair and easyJet have shown interest since Alitalia opened up its data room. But there are 
some doubts that anyone will want to take ownership of the airline given its legacy of lossmaking, high-cost 
structure, and struggles with unions and its employees.
Graphic
 
Commissioners appointed to run Italy's collapsed flag carrier will give preference to bids for the whole group to 
prevent would-be buyers carving off lucrative assets
Load-Date: August 4, 2017

Ryanair Holdings PLC Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings PLC logo Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited 
(Ryanair). Ryanair operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary 
services and engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight 
scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise. Ryanair 
markets accommodation services and travel insurance through its Website. It provides hotel and accommodation 
services. Ryanair provides its own aircraft and passenger handling and ticketing services at Dublin Airport. As of 
June 30, 2016, Ryanair had a principal fleet of over 350 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and offered over 2,000 scheduled 
short-haul flights per day serving approximately 200 airports throughout Europe. 
Copa Holdings, Company Profile
Copa Holdings, logo Copa Holdings, S.A. is a provider of airline passenger and cargo service through its principal 
operating subsidiaries, Compania Panamena de Aviacion, S. A. (Copa Airlines) and AeroRepublica, S. A. (Copa 
Colombia). The Company operates through air transportation segment. Copa Airlines operates from its position 
located in the Republic of Panama. Copa Airlines provides international air transportation for passengers, cargo and 
mail, operating from its Panama City hub in the Republic of Panama. Copa Colombia provides service within 
Colombia and international flights from various cities in Colombia to Panama, Venezuela, Ecuador, Mexico, Cuba, 
Guatemala and Costa Rica. Copa Colombia provides domestic and international air transportation for passengers, 
cargo and mail with a point-to-point route network. Its subsidiary, Oval Financial Leasing, Ltd., controls the special 
purpose entities that have a beneficial interest in the majority of its fleet.    
Load-Date: August 4, 2017
End of Document
TOP NEWS: easyJet Reports July Rise In Passenger Numbers, Load Factor
TOP NEWS: easyJet Reports July Rise In Passenger Numbers, Load Factor
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
August 4, 2017 Friday 2:54 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 136 words
Body
 Low-cost airline easyJet PLC said on Friday it carried more passengers in July compared to a year earlier and 
increased its load factor year-on-year.
easyJet said it carried 8.2 million passengers in July, up 8.9% from 7.5 million a year before. On a 12 month rolling 
basis, passengers were up 8.9% to 78.8 million compared to 72.3 million.
Load factor also improved in July, up 1.1 percentage points to 96.8%, from 95.8% a year ago.
This followed rises in July passenger traffic and capacity reported on Thursday by International Consolidated 
Airlines Group SA, which owns British Airways, Spanish carriers Iberia and Vueling, and Irish airline Aer Lingus. 
On Wednesday, easyJet's budget airline peers Ryanair Holdings PLC and Wizz Air Holdings PLC both also 
reported a rise in passenger numbers year-on-year in July.
Load-Date: August 5, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair : Brits face 'real' threat to European holidays in summer 2019
Ryanair: Brits face 'real' threat to European holidays in summer 2019
City A.M.
August 3, 2017 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 6
Length: 179 words
Byline: CATHERINE NEILAN
Body
RYANAIR boss Michael O'Leary yesterday warned of a "real and distinct" threat that flights from the UK to the EU 
could be grounded from April 2019, meaning there will be "no holidays" that summer.
O'Leary yesterday gave transport secretary Chris Grayling a briefing note saying the aviation industry had a hard 
deadline of September 2018 for an open skies agreement to be reached.
"Otherwise we will have to start cancelling flights, or taking them off sale," he told reporters.
This would be "deeply damaging for UK tourism, traffic and tens of thousands of jobs at UK airports, within British 
tourism and the UK economy for as long as such catastrophic disruption would persist," the document said.
But it was "highly unlikely" that the UK would be able to negotiate an agreement in time, given "a distinct and 
noticeable lobbying effort by French and German airlines", such as Lufthansa and Air France. They were calling for 
the EU27 to agree terms "so onerous" the UK would be unable to accept them without rowing back on certain "red 
lines", like ECJ jurisdiction, O'Leary said.
Graphic
 
Ryanair yesterday warned of cancelled summer holidays in 2019 due to Brexit
Ryanair : Brits face 'real' threat to European holidays in summer 2019
Load-Date: April 1, 2020
End of Document
UK Government Urged To Pressure EU Over "Shameful" Airport Queues
UK Government Urged To Pressure EU Over "Shameful" Airport Queues
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
August 2, 2017 Wednesday 1:24 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 709 words
Body
 The UK government has been urged to use "whatever influence it can" to pressure European Union states to 
adequately staff their airports after British holidaymakers faced chaos at passport controls.
Tourists arriving in some popular destinations have been met with "shameful" immigration lines hundreds of metres 
long - some having to wait for up to four hours - as staff carry out tighter counter-terror checks, according to one 
lobby group.
Experts have warned that travellers heading to some popular European destinations this summer may face 
increasing disruption as the new measures are rolled out.
Airlines UK, an industry body representing UK-registered carriers, said it had warned the Department for Transport 
about the problem in May, although they were told by ministers the issue had eased.
Tim Alderslade, the body's chief executive, said: "Clearly the situation has changed markedly as we enter peak 
holiday season, and it is now up to the UK government to work with industry to use whatever influence it can within 
the EU to persuade Schengen Member States to resource their border operations properly."
New European Union rules introduced following terror attacks in Paris and Brussels require countries to carry out 
more stringent checks on travellers entering and leaving the Schengen area, which allows passport-free movement 
across much of the EU.
The change means the details of passengers from non-Schengen countries, such as the UK, are run through 
databases to alert authorities if they are known to pose a threat.
However Alderslade said attempts to improve resources at border controls had "failed to happen thus far".
He added: "It is passengers and consumers - many of whom are from the UK - who are suffering as a 
consequence."
Pictures on social media in recent days have shown long lines of passengers in crowded terminals.
UK Government Urged To Pressure EU Over "Shameful" Airport Queues
Lobby group Airlines For Europe (A4E) said passengers arriving at airports in Spain, Portugal, France, Italy and 
Belgium are being forced to endure long waits to get through immigration.
The group, which represents carriers including easyJet PLC, Ryanair Holdings PLC and British Airways' parent 
International Consolidated Airlines Group SA, claimed some passengers are missing their flights because of the 
issue.
A4E managing director Thomas Reynaert said passengers had been left "devastated".
He said: "Travellers face long lines and can't get on their flights. Queuing for up to four hours has been the top 
record these days.
"Airports like Madrid, Palma de Mallorca, Lisbon, Lyon, Paris-Orly, Milan or Brussels are producing shameful 
pictures of devastated passengers in front of immigration booths, in lines stretching hundreds of metres.
"At some airports, flight delays have increased by 300% compared to last year."
A4E warned the situation could worsen in the coming weeks as the new regulations have not yet been fully 
implemented. The six-month period to put the enhanced checks in place ends on October 7.
A spokeswoman for travel trade organisation Abta said: "New, stricter passport checks are resulting in longer 
queues at some airports, including Palma, which is already busy due to a significant increase in passenger 
numbers.
"Tour operators will ensure that customers get to the airport in plenty of time so that they are not in danger of 
missing their flights.
"However, independent travellers will need to check the situation with their airlines and, where necessary, ensure 
they factor these longer queuing times into their travel plans when flying in and out of the airport.
"It is also extremely important that border control check points are sufficiently resourced so that queuing times are 
kept to a minimum."
Travellers at Barcelona's El Prat airport have faced further disruption in the past week amid unofficial strike action 
by security staff.
Aceta, the association of Spanish air transport companies, said some airlines had to delay flights because many of 
their passengers could not board on time.
The firm said since July 24 around 1,000 passengers had not made their flights.
One Briton tweeted on Tuesday: "22 people were not allowed on flight home from Barcelona airport yesterday 
afternoon. Plane left most empty. Security queue."
By Press Association Reporters
source: Press Association
Load-Date: August 3, 2017
End of Document
Rome to favour bids for all of Alitalia Airlines ; Commissioners set out sale conditions that seek to avoid asset 
carve-up
Rome to favour bids for all of Alitalia; Airlines ; Commissioners set out sale 
conditions that seek to avoid asset carve-up
Financial Times (London, England)
August 2, 2017 Wednesday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 12
Length: 518 words
Byline: JAMES POLITI ; TANYA POWLEY
Body
The Italian government is hoping to avoid the break-up of Alitalia by insisting it will give preference to bids for the 
entire company at the launch of the final stage of its sale out of bankruptcy.
The state-appointed commissioners running the airline yesterday set out the key conditions for tabling bids in the 
upcoming public tender. They specify offers for all of Alitalia, or separate bids for the airline operations, which 
includes maintenance, and for its airport ground handling activities. Such conditions are designed to prevent would-
be buyers trying to carve off lucrative routes or valuable assets, such as key buildings owned by Alitalia, from 
participating. The conditions state that if two offers are equal, preference will be given to the one for the whole 
airline.
Alitalia has been run by three commissioners since it collapsed in May, bringing three years of investment by 
Etihad, the UAE carrier, to a bitter end.
During the past two months, the commissioners have sounded out the market, and have received non-binding 
offers from at least 10 carriers, including Ryanair, Etihad and easyJet. Based on the interest so far, there is growing 
confidence inside Alitalia of a successful sale. The fate of the carrier, which has been beset with problems for 
decades, is being watched closely across the airline industry, particularly in Europe and the Middle East.
Rome to favour bids for all of Alitalia Airlines ; Commissioners set out sale conditions that seek to avoid asset 
carve-up
The Italian government agreed to pump (EURO)600m in taxpayer funds into Alitalia to keep it afloat for six months, 
with the goal of selling the whole airline by the end of the year.
Luigi Gubitosi, one of the commissioners, said in an emailed statement yesterday: "We think Alitalia has great 
untapped potential - and from the market interest, we aren't the only ones." He added: "This potential is even 
greater if the company remains whole."
Alitalia's financial troubles were caused from a combination of competition from low-cost carriers and its own high 
cost base. One of the big questions hanging over the sale is whether buyers - particularly for the whole carrier - will 
be willing to take on this legacy.
Andrew Lobbenberg, an aviation analyst at HSBC, said: "People coming in with fresh capital would want to see 
meaningful change. There's no evidence of acceptance of that reality."
But Mr Gubitosi, who has broad powers to transform the airline, said its financial position was already improving 
and revenues growing.
The sale, managed by bankers at Rothschild, will be open to bidders of all nationalities and consortiums. Private 
equity firms are also expected to participate. Binding offers are due in October, followed by a period of negotiation 
until November. Alitalia faces liquidation if it does not find a buyer for the whole company or its main components. 
Chris Tarry, an aviation consultant, said: "I'm afraid there's a great disappointment ahead. The brand is important in 
Italy and you can see how that brand can continue but you need a completely different approach to the operating 
model."
'People coming in with fresh capital would want to see meaningful change. There's no evidence of acceptance of 
that reality'
Load-Date: April 1, 2020
End of Document

carve-up

Ryanair launches 'Thanks a Billion' seat sale
Ryanair launches 'Thanks a Billion' seat sale
Business World (Digest)
August 02, 2017 Wednesday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 192 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Ryanair has today launched a “Thanks A Billion” seat sale to mark carrying its one billionth customer.   July was a 
record month for Ryanair, as it became the first European airline to carry over 12m customers in a single month, 
with July’s traffic growing 11% to 12.6m customers.    Ryanair is thanking the one billion customers who have made 
it Europe’s biggest airline by offering 20% off 1 million seats across its European network for travel between 13 
November and 15 December. The seat sale fares are available for booking now until midnight (24:00hrs) on 
Wednesday (2 Aug).   Speaking today, Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, Kenny Jacobs said, "To celebrate 
welcoming our billionth customer since our first flight in 1985, Ryanair is slashing fares across our European 
network in our ‘Thanks A Billion’ seat sale. There has never been a better time to book a low fare getaway with 20% 
off over 1 million seats across our entire European network for travel in November and December. This amazing 
offer will end at midnight on Wednesday, August 2nd, so customers should log on quickly and bag a bargain break 
today."
Source: www.businessworld.ie

O'Leary jets in for crunch Brexit talks
O'Leary jets in for crunch Brexit talks
City A.M.
August 2, 2017 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 1
Length: 121 words
Byline: TRACEY BOLES AND CATHERINE NEILAN
Body
RYANAIR boss Michael O'Leary jets in for key talks with transport secretary Chris Grayling today as concerns 
mount over airlines' flight rights post Brexit.
From March 2019, the UK no longer automatically has the same flight permissions as an EU member, meaning the 
right of its carriers to fly to the EU and beyond will have to be renegotiated.
The aviation industry has warned repeatedly that flights from the UK could be disrupted and even grounded if a new 
legal framework is not agreed by then. The situation has become increasingly urgent because the industry and its 
regulators have to finalise flight timetables many months in advance.
"We are committed to getting the right deal for Britain," a government spokesperson said.
Load-Date: April 1, 2020
End of Document
Jeju profit soars as fleet expands
Jeju profit soars as fleet expands
AirFinance Journal
August 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 259 words
Byline: Laura Mueller
Body
South Korean low-cost carrier Jeju Air is due to add another Boeing 737-800 (MSN 36814) as part of plans to grow 
its fleet to 32 aircraft by year end.
The 2009-built aircraft is currently on lease to Norwegian by FPG Amentum, according to Airfinance Journal’s Fleet 
Tracker.
Jeju Air operates 29 leased aircraft and indicates in its second-quarter earnings release that it plans to add three 
more units by the end of 2017.
It will then add six more aircraft each year until 2020.
Jeju Air’s second-quarter net profit jumped to 15.1 billion won ($14 million) from 4.6 billion won a year earlier. 
Revenue improved 41%, to 228 billion won, over the same period.
"In the second and fourth quarters when demand is relatively lower than the other two quarters, we focused on 
attracting customers with lower ticket prices. Route diversification also helped, offsetting lower demand on Chinese 
routes amid a diplomatic row with Beijing," the airline says.
Operating profit also soared to 16.2 billion won from 600 million won during the year-earlier period, marking the 
carrier’s 12th consecutive operating profit.
In April Jeju Air took delivery of the final 737-800 from a lease agreement with SMBC Aviation Capital.
The aircraft, MSN 37543, is a 2009-vintage aircraft that was previously operated by Ryanair, according to Airfinance 
Journal's Fleet Tracker.
Dublin-based SMBC Aviation Capital announced a four-aircraft agreement last November.
The first aircraft, MSN 35018, delivered in December. MSNs 37540 and 37541 were delivered in February and 
March
Load-Date: August 28, 2017
Jeju profit soars as fleet expands
End of Document
Air Berlin at risk of bond default
Air Berlin at risk of bond default
AirFinance Journal
August 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 355 words
Byline: Michael Allen
Body
Air Berlin is at risk of defaulting on more than &euro;600 million equivalent of bonds, including &euro;130 million of 
convertible bonds, after the carrier filed for insolvency, GlobalCapital reports.
The sister publication of Airfinance Journal saysit is unclear what will happen to Air Berlin’s bonds, which include a 
Sfr100m 2019, a &euro;170 million 2019, and a &euro;225 million 2018.
The fate of other debt issues also hangs in the balance, with structured notes issued by Etihad vehicles EA 
Partners I and II, which are backed by stakes in its airline partners, slumping in Tuesday’s (15 August) trading.
These bonds have already been hit by a standstill on another Etihad partner, Alitalia, earlier this year.
Etihad’s decision to pull the plug came after it helped Air Berlin in February to refinance its &euro;140 million 6% 
convertible bonds that were puttable in March, through an exchange offer that was shunned by the bond holders.
HSBC led the exchange offer, designed to delay the put by eight months, giving Air Berlin time to implement its 
restructuring efforts without risking default.
At the time, Air Berlin received agreements from its bondholders to exchange just &euro;41.3 million of the existing 
bonds into a new &euro;125 million 2019 convertible paying 8.5%. Etihad accounted for &euro;40 million of that 
commitment.
Simultaneously, Air Berlin sold new convertible notes hoping to raise &euro;85 million and managed to find enough 
demand for &euro;83.7 million, which came from Etihad and other institutional investors.
HSBC itself participated by buying &euro;53.7 million of the new bonds and entered into a total return swap for the 
same amount with Etihad.
Shares in Air Berlin have lost more than half their value since Monday, giving the company a market capitalisation 
of &euro;43 million.
Airfinance Journal has been reporting in detail on Air Berlin’s insolvency. Read more here:
Ryanair slams Lufthansa ‘conspiracy’ to take over Air Berlin
Air Berlin at risk of bond default
Lessors shift Air Berlin A320s to Cambodia
GECAS most exposed to Air Berlin
AerCap’s Air Berlin exposure is manageable: analyst
Load-Date: September 4, 2017
End of Document
Lufthansa eyes rump of Air Berlin
Lufthansa eyes rump of Air Berlin
AirFinance Journal
August 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 255 words
Byline: Alex Derber
Body
Lufthansa wants to take about 90 of insolvent Air Berlin’s 140 aircraft and absorb them into its Eurowings brand, 
German media has reported.
The Sueddeutsche Zeitung says that, according to sources within Lufthansa, the German flag carrier is eyeing most 
of Air Berlin’s widebody aircraft, about 40 short- and medium-range aircraft and the 38 aircraft that Lufthansa is 
already leasing from Air Berlin.
Air Berlin’s fleet includes 41 Airbus A320-family aircraft, nine Boeing 737-family aircraft, 18 A330s and four 
turboprops, according to Airfinance Journal’s Fleet Tracker.
That count excludes the 20 narrowbodies operated by Air Berlin subsidiary Niki and the 38 aircraft on lease to 
Lufthansa.
Today Ryanair CEO Michael O’Leary told Reuters that his company was interested in bidding for the whole of Air 
Berlin, although he questioned what would be left “by the time Lufthansa completes the discussions".
It was widely reported that only Lufthansa was present at a first round of formal talks on the Air Berlin sale on 
Friday.
However, Easyjet is also thought to be in the running for some of Air Berlin’s operations.
Yesterday, the Rheinische Post claimed the British budget carrier was making a play for more than half of Air 
Berlin’s slots at Duesseldorf Airport.
These were mainly for domestic German routes and certain others to European destinations where Air Berlin was in 
direct competition with Eurowings and which might spark antitrust concerns were Lufthansa to acquire them.
Load-Date: October 2, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair slams Lufthansa "~conspiracy' to take over Air Berlin
Ryanair slams Lufthansa "~conspiracy' to take over Air Berlin
AirFinance Journal
August 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 213 words
Byline: Alex Derber
Body
Ryanair has protested to German and European competition authorities about what it describes as an “obvious 
conspiracy” to allow Lufthansa to take over bankrupt Air Berlin.
“This manufactured insolvency is clearly being set up to allow Lufthansa to take over a debt-free Air Berlin which 
will be in breach of all known German and EU competition rules,” says Ryanair in a statement.
The Dublin-based low-cost carrier also accuses the German government of aiding the creation of a Lufthansa 
“monopoly” by extending &euro;150 million of temporary state aid to Air Berlin, which filed for bankruptcy yesterday 
after main shareholder Etihad pulled support.
Furthermore, Ryanair says that the German government, Lufthansa and Air Berlin are manoeuvring to “carve up” 
the latter’s assets “while excluding major competitors and ignoring both EU competition and State Aid rules”.
The Irish carrier also appealed directly to the European Commission to intercede, as it alleges that the German 
antitrust authority, the Bundeskartellamt, “is likely to struggle to get out of bed” to tackle the issue.
Ryanair has traditionally struggled to gain as much market share in Germany as it has in other large European 
nations.
Load-Date: September 4, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair interested in buying Air Berlin
Ryanair interested in buying Air Berlin
AirFinance Journal
August 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 276 words
Byline: Michael Allen
Body
Ryanair is interested in bidding for the whole of Air Berlin, but needs access to more data on the airline’s finances, 
Ryanair’s chief executive has told Reuters.
"We would be very happy to bid for the whole of Air Berlin, which is generally a short-haul, domestic, intra-EU 
carrier," O'Leary told the newswire by telephone.
"But we don't know how much restructuring it will take, how much money is it losing, why is it losing so much money 
in a market where we make money," he added.
O'Leary told Reuters that Ryanair needed information on Air Berlin's leases, employment contracts and terms with 
airports before it could determine how much restructuring would be required.
O'Leary has also complained that the Air Berlin insolvency process is a "stitch-up" to help strengthen Lufthansa, 
which he worries will swoop for the rump of Air Berlin before other buyers are given an opportunity.
Ryanair, which bought budget carrier Buzz from KLM in 2003, is keen to play a role in future changes to the 
European airline industry.
For instance, the Irish carrier has signalled interest in insolvent Alitalia, if the Italian airline can be restructured.
"We are clearly going to play a role in the consolidation of the European airline industry, given that we're the biggest 
airline in Europe," O'Leary said.
He predicted that in five years' time there would be only four or five airline groups in Europe: Ryanair, Lufthansa, Air 
France-KLM, British Airways parent IAG and possibly Easyjet.
"Everything will all get consolidated into four or five big groups. It's always hard to predict the demise of an 
individual airline but that's what happens," he told Reuters.
Load-Date: October 2, 2017
Ryanair interested in buying Air Berlin
End of Document
Italy 's troubled Alitalia puts call out for binding purchase offers
Italy's troubled Alitalia puts call out for binding purchase offers
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 1, 2017 Tuesday 1:37 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 192 words
Byline: Lena Klimkeit in Rome
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Italy's troubled airline Alitalia on Tuesday got the word out in multiple newspapers and online on Tuesday that it has 
started looking for binding purchase offers from interested buyers.
The airline, which filed for insolvency in May, is soliciting offers from August 7 to September 15, though they would 
be welcome until October 2 at the latest.
Those interested can make an offer either for the entire airline, or only for the air operations or the ground services, 
Alitalia said.
However, the Italian government would give preference to a complete sale offer, according to Ansa news agency.
The deadline for non-binding offers for the airline expired in July.
Low-cost European carrier Ryanair was one of several companies that had expressed an interest and had made a 
non-binding offer for Alitalia's assets, said Ryanair financial head Neil Sorahan in July.
Alitalia has not turned a profit since 2002 and has been on the brink of collapse three times in the past 10 years. 
Privatized in 2008, it has since lost more than 2.5 billion euros (2.95 billion dollars).
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 2, 2017
Italy 's troubled Alitalia puts call out for binding purchase offers
End of Document
Italy 's troubled Alitalia puts call out for binding purchase offers
Italy's troubled Alitalia puts call out for binding purchase offers
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
August 1, 2017 Tuesday 1:38 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 186 words
Body
       ROME (dpa-AFX) - Italy's troubled airline Alitalia on Tuesday got the word out in multiple newspapers and 
online on Tuesday that it has started looking for binding purchase offers from interested buyers.  The airline, which 
filed for insolvency in May, is soliciting offers from August 7 to September 15, though they would be welcome until 
October 2 at the latest.   Those interested can make an offer either for the entire airline, or only for the air 
operations or the ground services, Alitalia said.   However, the Italian government would give preference to a 
complete sale offer, according to Ansa news agency.  The deadline for non-binding offers for the airline expired in 
July.   Low-cost European carrier Ryanair was one of several companies that had expressed an interest and had 
made a non-binding offer for Alitalia's assets, said Ryanair financial head Neil Sorahan in July.  Alitalia has not 
turned a profit since 2002 and has been on the brink of collapse three times in the past 10 years. Privatized in 2008, 
it has since lost more than 2.5 billion euros (2.95 billion dollars).   Copyright dpa

Ryanair outlines fleet plans for standalone Polish unit
Ryanair outlines fleet plans for standalone Polish unit
AirFinance Journal
August 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 131 words
Byline: Alex Derber
Body
Irish airline Ryanair plans to launch a Warsaw, Poland-based charter carrier next summer.
Ryanair Sun will initially have five Boeing 737-800s, a fleet that Ryanair intends to grow to 15 aircraft by summer 
2019.
It is still undecided whether the aircraft will come from Ryanair’s existing fleet or from its delivery stream, a 
spokesperson for the low-cost carrier tells Airfinance Journal.
Operating as a standalone business unit with a Polish air operator’s certificate, the new carrier will offer charter 
flights to and from Poland from summer 2018.
“Ryanair Sun will deliver best in class charter services, at the lowest cost to Polish tour operators,” the airline says 
in a statement.
Recruitment is underway for senior management of the business unit, Ryanair says.
Load-Date: August 28, 2017
End of Document
Air Berlin's $179m loan on schedule, says Germany
Air Berlin's $179m loan on schedule, says Germany
AirFinance Journal
August 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 199 words
Byline: Jack Dutton
Body
A government bridge loan to pay insolvent Air Berlin has not yet been paid but the process of providing the debt is 
on schedule, according to a spokesperson for Germany's economy ministry.
"There are a few technical details but the credit is there and everything is progressing according to the timetable," 
the spokeswoman told reporters at a government news conference in Berlin.
The government has agreed a &euro;150 million ($179 million) loan to ensure that flights continue for three months 
and to secure the positions of the airline's 7,200 employees in Germany.
The airline filed for bankruptcy earlier in August after Etihad Airways, its second-largest stakeholder, withdrew 
funding after years of losses. The airline is now being split up among investors, with bids due in mid-September, 
according to Reuters.
Easyjet, Ryanair, Lufthansa and TUI are all reportedly interested in trying to acquire some of Air Berlin’s fleet. 
Reuters reports that Lufthansa is looking for around a dozen of Air Berlin’s 17 long-haul aircraft that fly transatlantic 
routes.
Air Berlin has 17 Airbus A330s, 10 of which are on lease from AerCap, according to Airfinance Journal’s Fleet 
Tracker.
Load-Date: October 2, 2017
End of Document
Virgin alliance flies in face of low-cost carriers Airlines. Joint ventures ; Tie-up with Air France - KLM aims to 
create a formidable force on transatlantic ma....
Virgin alliance flies in face of low-cost carriers; Airlines. Joint ventures ; Tie-
up with Air France-KLM aims to create a formidable force on transatlantic 
market
Financial Times (London, England)
July 31, 2017 Monday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 14
Length: 937 words
Byline: TANYA POWLEY
Body
One of the aviation industry's most colourful wagers has been reignited. In 2012, Willie Walsh, chief executive of 
International Airlines Group, which owns British Airways, bet Sir Richard Branson a "knee in the groin" that the 
Virgin Atlantic brand would disappear within five years, after US airline Delta Air Lines bought a 49 per cent stake in 
the British carrier.
On Thursday Sir Richard reminded Mr Walsh of the bet as he revealed a deal that he believes will safeguard the 
Virgin Atlantic brand in the face of growing transatlantic competition, despite it meaning he will lose majority control 
of the airline he founded in 1984.
In a wide-ranging shake-up of the airline industry, Air France-KLM will buy a 31 per cent stake in Virgin Atlantic from 
Sir Richard's Virgin Group for about £220m, taking Sir Richard's stake in the airline from 51 per cent to 20 per cent.
In a letter to staff on Thursday, Sir Richard wrote: "Well Willie, that fiveyear point is up this December. And Virgin 
Atlantic is still flying strong!" The partnership deal, unveiled on Thursday, also sees Air France-KLM, Virgin Atlantic 
and Delta Air Lines sign a provisional agreement to create a single global joint venture. It involves Delta and China 
Eastern - in which Delta holds a stake - each acquiring a 10 per cent share of Air France-KLM, which will raise 
(EURO)751m in new capital for the Franco-Dutch carrier.
Virgin alliance flies in face of low-cost carriers Airlines. Joint ventures ; Tie-up with Air France - KLM aims to 
create a formidable force on transatlantic ma....
The goal of the deals between the four airlines is to create a formidable force on the lucrative transatlantic market, 
where competition is heating up due to the emergence of low-cost airlines Norwegian Air Shuttle and WestJet.
The single-partnership deal replaces two overlapping transatlantic joint ventures - one between Delta, Air France-
KLM and Alitalia and another between Delta and Virgin Atlantic.
Robin Byde, analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald, believes the new tie-up is going to be a "competitive threat", noting that 
there will be more pressure on yields, service quality and frequencies in the north Atlantic.
According to data from CAPA Centre for Aviation and OAG, the merger of the two transatlantic joint ventures will 
see the new alliance increase its share of seats between Europe and North America to 25 per cent, coming close to 
the largest alliance, Star, led by Lufthansa and United Airlines, which has a 27.9 per cent share of the market.
Oneworld alliance, which is made up of BA and American Airlines, has a 20.2 per cent share, based on data for 
summer 2017.
The shake-up comes in the midst of growing consolidation in the European market. Ryanair, easyJet and Etihad are 
among several airlines to have made a non-binding offer for Alitalia, the struggling Italian carrier that entered 
administration in May. Air Berlin, which has failed to make a profit for years, is also seeking buyers.
"There's always been code-shares, alliances and joint ventures between airlines, but I think you are seeing an 
acceleration of that. If you look at the US carriers, they are far more consolidated than the European market, so you 
are bound to see more in Europe," says Mr Byde.
The focus on joint ventures and minority stakes is largely down to the difficulty in doing full-scale cross-border 
mergers because of rules restricting foreign ownership.
Creating a stronger joint venture on the transatlantic network has become a more pressing issue in recent years.
Low-cost rivals such as Norwegian and WestJet have been successful in launching low fares between Europe and 
the US. IAG has responded by launching its own low-cost long-haul airline, Level, in June.
"Until recently, everyone thought the transatlantic market was stitched up between the three big joint ventures. But 
suddenly you've got all these lowcost guys and everyone became a lot less secure of their position," says Andrew 
Charlton, a Geneva-based aviation analyst.
On Friday, American Airlines, which has a joint venture with BA on transatlantic routes, highlighted the tough 
environment at its results presentation, noting that "the overall environment remains challenged as low-cost carriers 
grow substantially".
While many believe the new single joint venture is a sensible move, some are sceptical about the benefits. Gerald 
Khoo, analyst at Liberum, notes that airlines taking strategic minority stakes in other airlines is "a strategy with an 
alarmingly high failure rate".
"Bringing Virgin Atlantic into the transatlantic joint venture ought to be positive, but we struggle to see how buying a 
stake is either necessary or desirable," says Mr Khoo. "The most recent and enthusiastic practitioner, Etihad, has 
recently written off $808m for its failed investments in Air Berlin and Alitalia. Admittedly, Delta and Air France-KLM 
may be able to exercise significant influence with a combined 80 per cent shareholding."
Chris Tarry, an aviation consultant, believes Air France-KLM's purchase of a stake in Virgin Atlantic is a "massive 
diversion" from the Franco-Dutch carrier's core problems. "It's been a serial under-performer. Taking a stake in 
another airline is not going to change that," he says.
Virgin alliance flies in face of low-cost carriers Airlines. Joint ventures ; Tie-up with Air France - KLM aims to 
create a formidable force on transatlantic ma....
Earlier this year Air France-KLM promised to cut costs and boost passenger capacity in an effort to "regain the 
offensive" in the long-haul market. Last year Jean-Marc Janaillac, its chief executive, told the FT that if the company 
did not become more competitive it would "end up like Alitalia", the struggling Italian flag carrier.
But Delta's move to take a 10 per cent stake in Air France-KLM, which also gives it a board seat, may be helpful in 
boosting the Franco-Dutch airline's fortunes.
Additional reporting by Michael Stothard and Patti Waldmeir
Graphic
 
The partnership deal sees Air France-KLM, Virgin Atlantic and Delta Air Lines sign a provisional agreement to 
create a single global joint venture Iain Sarjeant / Alamy
Load-Date: April 1, 2020
End of Document
Virgin alliance flies in face of low-cost carriers Airlines. Joint ventures ; Tie-up with Air France - KLM aims to 
create a formidable force on transatlantic ma....
Virgin alliance flies in face of low-cost carriers; Airlines. Joint ventures ; Tie-
up with Air France-KLM aims to create a formidable force on transatlantic 
market

another airline is not going to change that," he says.
Virgin alliance flies in face of low-cost carriers Airlines. Joint ventures ; Tie-up with Air France - KLM aims to 
create a formidable force on transatlantic ma....

boosting the Franco-Dutch airline's fortunes.

On Friday, American Airlines, which has a joint venture with BA on transatlantic routes, highlighted the tough 
environment at its results presentation, noting that "the overall environment remains challenged as low-cost carriers 
grow substantially".
While many believe the new single joint venture is a sensible move, some are sceptical about the benefits. Gerald 
Khoo, analyst at Liberum, notes that airlines taking strategic minority stakes in other airlines is "a strategy with an 
alarmingly high failure rate".
"Bringing Virgin Atlantic into the transatlantic joint venture ought to be positive, but we struggle to see how buying a 
stake is either necessary or desirable," says Mr Khoo. "The most recent and enthusiastic practitioner, Etihad, has 
recently written off $808m for its failed investments in Air Berlin and Alitalia. Admittedly, Delta and Air France-KLM 
may be able to exercise significant influence with a combined 80 per cent shareholding."
Chris Tarry, an aviation consultant, believes Air France-KLM's purchase of a stake in Virgin Atlantic is a "massive 
diversion" from the Franco-Dutch carrier's core problems. "It's been a serial under-performer. Taking a stake in 
another airline is not going to change that," he says.
Virgin alliance flies in face of low-cost carriers Airlines. Joint ventures ; Tie-up with Air France - KLM aims to 
create a formidable force on transatlantic ma....
Earlier this year Air France-KLM promised to cut costs and boost passenger capacity in an effort to "regain the 
offensive" in the long-haul market. Last year Jean-Marc Janaillac, its chief executive, told the FT that if the company 
did not become more competitive it would "end up like Alitalia", the struggling Italian flag carrier.
But Delta's move to take a 10 per cent stake in Air France-KLM, which also gives it a board seat, may be helpful in 
boosting the Franco-Dutch airline's fortunes.
Additional reporting by Michael Stothard and Patti Waldmeir
Graphic
 
The partnership deal sees Air France-KLM, Virgin Atlantic and Delta Air Lines sign a provisional agreement to 
create a single global joint venture Iain Sarjeant / Alamy
Load-Date: April 1, 2020
End of Document

Google figures still rising despite price pressure
Google figures still rising despite price pressure
Sunday Business Post
July 29, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 792 words
Byline: Conor Brophy
Highlight: Web giant's parent Alphabet easily paid an EU fine that would have crippled other multinationals
Body
In the space of a single financial quarter, Google and its parent company Alphabet have had to deal with a boycott 
from some of the world’s biggest advertisers and a multibillion-euro fine from the European Commission. But 
neither of those is the biggest issue facing the company right now.
The €2.42 billion ($2.7 billion) fine certainly took a bite out of Alphabet’s quarterly profit. Results published during 
the week showed the regulatory intervention pushed its net income down to $4.5 billion from $4.8 billion for the 
same period in 2016. There can be few greater illustrations of Google’s power and scale, however, than the fact it 
can swallow such a massive fine out of a single quarter’s income and still have plenty of change. Consider that it 
would have taken the the bulk of the combined annual profit of the two largest companies on the Irish Stock 
Exchange, CRH and Ryanair, to pay such a bill.
If the powerful hand of the EU’s competition regulator managed briefly to slow Google’s march, it’s hard to divine 
whether the boycott by advertisers of its subsidiary YouTube earlier this year had any meaningful financial impact at 
all.
Some of the biggest-spending US and international brands withheld ads from YouTube as an investigation by The 
Times revealed their spots had aired alongside inappropriate content such as hate speech videos featuring white 
supremacist and Holocaust denier David Duke.
Alphabet mustered a swift response. Senior executives were out quickly to apologise. They promised to do more to 
weed out offensive content and protect advertisers from having their brands tarred by association with it.
The results show the controversy is well behind YouTube already. Google’s total ad revenue topped $22.6 billion for 
the three months to the end of June, up from €19.1 billion in the same period last year. Apart from the headline 
figures, Alphabet publishes two key metrics on which the company tracks its performance: paid clicks and cost per 
click. Paid clicks indicates the level of engagement and the degree to which ads are effective in drumming up 
Google figures still rising despite price pressure
business across the various Google properties (including YouTube, Gmail and so on) and what the company calls 
its “network members’ properties” - literally the websites on which Google buys space for brands. Cost per click, 
then, is the average amount Google charges advertisers for each click or engagement by users.
Right now, the numbers could scarcely be better. Paid click growth was up 52 per cent year-on-year during the 
second quarter. The pace has picked up too. This time last year it stood at 28 per cent. The stats show it’s higher 
still for paid clicks on Google’s own properties, at 61 per cent. What takes a little bit of the gloss off this 
performance, though, is the stubborn trend for cost-per-click numbers to move in the opposite direction. The 
consensus forecast for the decline in cost-per-click for this recent financial quarter was 15 per cent. In the event it 
was significantly worse at 23 per cent.
The main reason for this is the ongoing shift in web traffic to mobile devices. Google, ironically, has been a 
significant enabler of the shift through its Android mobile operating system. Google dominates search on desktop 
computers but the mobile user experience is very different, based as it is largely on self-contained apps rather than 
web browsers. Google and its various subsidiaries are battling with Facebook, and others, to retain the attention 
from users it can take for granted on PCs.
That competition means the margins (reflected in the cost-per-click figures) aren’t as fat for Google in mobile 
advertising as they were in the desktop-dominated past.
Mobile click-through rates for ads are also lower, which is in no small part down to relatively poor user experience. 
In this sense, Google is the Ryanair of the online advertising world.
It is benefiting from massive volume growth and has scale on its side. Like Ryanair, it’s also trying to improve the 
user experience, with some success. So just as Ryanair can post profit growth even when average ticket prices are 
falling, Google’s bottom line is still heading rapidly in the right direction even as the average ad price is under 
pressure.
On a conference call with investors last week, Alphabet’s chief financial officer Ruth Porat batted away concerns 
about the cost-per-click conundrum. The company is focused on growing revenue “not margins”, she said. Some of 
those investors, at least, would like to see the company do both.
The 3 per cent drop in its share price following the results announcement said as much. But with advertising 
revenue rolling in at over $20 billion per quarter and (still) rising, Google has both the time and the resources to 
search for a solution.
Load-Date: July 29, 2017
End of Document

Aer Lingus owner IAG expects a double-digit rise in operating profit this year
Aer Lingus owner IAG expects a double-digit rise in operating profit this 
year
Business World (Digest)
July 28, 2017 Friday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 324 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Aer Lingus owner IAG expects a double-digit rise in operating profit this year, it said on Friday, after a strong 
second quarter despite a power outage at BA which grounded hundreds of flights.
Shares rose 3% after the results, which included a year-on-year rise in profit that analysts said beat estimates.
Previously, the airline group, which also owns British Airways, Iberia and Vueling, had said that it expected an 
improvement in profit year-on-year in 2017.
Chief Executive Willie Walsh said that the first half performance was very strong, and struck a different tone to 
competitors such as Lufthansa, Ryanair and easyJet who have warned of a downward pressure on fares hindering 
performance.
"All we can say is what we see. Clearly what we see in terms of our performance does appear to be somewhat 
different to what others are saying," Walsh told reporters.
"It may not be different to what they're seeing, but it's certainly different to what they've said. But we're calling it as 
we see it, and our first half performance was very strong."
Air France-KLM also offered more optimism on pricing when it announced results on Friday.
IAG said that non-fuel unit costs before exceptional items were up, including the financial impact of a massive 
power outage which grounded flights at Heathrow and Gatwick over a holiday weekend in May.
Aer Lingus owner IAG expects a double-digit rise in operating profit this year
But that did not detract significantly from a strong set of results, analysts said. Passenger unit revenue rose 1.5% in 
the quarter, delivering the first year-on-year increase in quarterly revenue per passenger mile flown since 2014.
Operating profit for the six months to June 30 was 975 million euros, up 37.3% compared to the previous year, 
while quarterly operating profit was 805 million euros.
Walsh said that a pact between Delta, Air France-KLM and Virgin, which was announced on Thursday, was unlikely 
to change much in the industry but that it was too early to say. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie 
Load-Date: August 14, 2017
End of Document

and set a $109.00 price objective for the company in a report on Saturday, May 6th. Two analysts have rated the 
stock with a sell rating, three have given a hold rating and eleven have issued a buy rating to the company's stock. 
Ryanair Holdings PLC has a consensus rating of 'Buy' and a consensus price target of $100.33. About Ryanair 
Holdings PLC Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair 
operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, 
the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and

European Shares Seen Up As Oil Climbs And Dollar Steadies
European Shares Seen Up As Oil Climbs And Dollar Steadies
MT Newswires Live Briefs
July 25, 2017 Tuesday 2:28 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 302 words
Body
 European stocks may open higher on Tuesday as US Treasury yields climbed, oil extended overnight gains, and 
the dollar rebounded from its lowest level in more than a year in the wake of stronger-than-expected readings on 
US factory and services activity.
Oil rose further after climbing more than 1% in the overnight session as Saudi Arabia pledged to curb exports from 
August and Nigeria agreed to curb production to rein in global oversupply.
Also, Haliburton Co's executive chairman said the US shale drilling boom would probably ease next year.
The Fed's two-day policy meeting starts later Tuesday, with investors looking for clues on whether the US central 
bank will begin reducing its bond portfolio at its September meeting.
Meanwhile, Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law and senior advisor, told Senate investigators on 
Monday he had contacts with Russian officials four times last year, but he nor anyone in the Trump campaign team 
colluded with Moscow to influence the 2016 US election.
In economic releases, investors await a key survey of business sentiment from Germany later in the day.
Asian stocks are trading mostly higher, although gains remained muted outside Australia ahead of Fed meeting.
Overnight, US stocks ended mixed as investors braced for a busy week of earnings and a meeting of the Federal 
Reserve. The Dow dropped 0.3% and the S&P 500 edged down 0.1% while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.4% to 
close at a fresh record high.
European markets hit two-week lows on Monday after Ryanair warned of increased competition and EU antitrust 
regulators said they are investigating allegations of a cartel among a group of German carmakers.
European Shares Seen Up As Oil Climbs And Dollar Steadies
The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index shed 0.2%, the German DAX slid 0.3% and the UK's FTSE 100 lost 1% 
while France's CAC 40 index edged up 0.2%.
Load-Date: July 26, 2017
End of Document
European Shares Seen Up As Oil Climbs, Dollar Steadies
European Shares Seen Up As Oil Climbs, Dollar Steadies
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
July 25, 2017 Tuesday 7:57 AM GMT
Copyright 2017 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 325 words
Body
       BRUSSELS/FRANKFURT/PARIS (dpa-AFX) - European stocks may open higher on Tuesday as U.S. Treasury 
yields climbed, oil extended overnight gains and the dollar rebounded from its lowest level in more than a year in 
the wake of stronger-than-expected readings on U.S. factory and services activity.  Oil rose further after climbing 
more than 1 percent in the overnight session as Saudi Arabia pledged to curb exports from August and Nigeria 
agreed to curb production to rein in global oversupply.   Also, Haliburton Co's executive chairman said the U.S. 
shale drilling boom would probably ease next year. 
 The Fed's two-day policy meeting starts later today, with investors looking for clues on whether the U.S. central 
bank will begin reducing its bond portfolio at its September meeting.  Meanwhile, Jared Kushner, President Donald 
Trump's son-in-law and senior advisor, told Senate investigators on Monday he had contacts with Russian officials 
four times last year, but he nor anyone in the Trump campaign team colluded with Moscow to influence the 2016 
U.S. election.  In economic releases, investors await a key survey of business sentiment from Germany later in the 
day.   Asian stocks are trading mostly higher, although gains remained muted outside Australia ahead of Fed 
meeting.   Overnight, U.S. stocks ended mixed as investors braced for a busy week of earnings and a meeting of 
the Federal Reserve. The Dow dropped 0.3 percent and the S&P 500 edged down 0.1 percent while the Nasdaq 
Composite rose 0.4 percent to close at a fresh record high.  European markets hit two-week lows on Monday after 
Ryanair warned of increased competition and EU antitrust regulators said they are investigating allegations of a 
cartel among a group of German carmakers.  The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index shed 0.2 percent, the 
German DAX slid 0.3 percent and the U.K.'s FTSE 100 lost 1 percent while France's CAC 40 index edged up 0.2 
percent.

Ryanair may cut its fares in late summer by as much as 9% from last year
Ryanair may cut its fares in late summer by as much as 9% from last year
Business World (Digest)
July 25, 2017 Tuesday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 570 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair warned rivals on Monday that it may cut its fares in late summer by as much as 9% from last year, 
triggering a share sell-off by investors concerned about the impact on profitability.
Ryanair also confirmed it was among the bidders for Alitalia but said it would only pursue a deal if the struggling 
airline was restructured and Italian government influence removed.
Europe's largest airline by passenger numbers, Ryanair has helped drive down short-haul ticket prices in Europe by 
increasing its capacity by a third, or about 30 million seats, in the past two years.
Some investors thought higher fares in the three months to the end of June were a sign that a period of heavy 
discounting may be ending. But management made clear the annual increase was just a blip due to the timing of 
Easter and that prices would fall sharply in the coming months.
"It's a competitive market out there. You're looking at fares down anywhere between 7, 8, maybe as much as 9%," , 
Chief Financial Officer Neil Sorahan told Reuters, referring to then three months to the end of September.
Annual falls are likely to average 8% in the six months to March 31, the end of Ryanair's financial year, he added.
While the average fare forecasts were unchanged from those given in May, some analysts had been expecting the 
declines to slow and Ryanair's share price was down 2.4% at 1245 GMT after earlier falling 4.5%.
"I think the market had probably priced in that the fare guidance for the winter was very conservative and now they 
are realizing that it is actually realistic," said Davy transport analyst Stephen Furlong.
Ryanair may cut its fares in late summer by as much as 9% from last year
The comments sent shares in other European airlines down on Monday, continuing falls seen last week, with 
Lufthansa , Wizz, IAG and easyJet losing between 1 and 3%.
Ryanair beat analyst expectations with profit of 397 million euros for the three months to the end of June, compared 
to a company poll average of 366 million euros, after the timing of Easter helped lift fares by 1 percent on an annual 
basis.
But its forecast that it would make a profit after tax of between 1.4 and 1.45 billion euros in its financial year was 
below the average forecast by analysts polled by Ryanair ahead of the release for a profit of 1.488 billion.
Sorohan said part of the fall in average fares was due to lower fuel prices, but much was due to over-capacity in 
Spain, Portugal and Italy as charter carriers shift capacity away from Turkey and North Africa.
Lower average fares were impacted by sterling weakness and lower fees earned for checked bags following a 
change in policy that allows passengers to carry two bags on board.
Low-cost rivals easyJet and Wizz Air have both in recent weeks warned that average fare levels would continue to 
be under pressure over the key summer period.
In a sign it is not afraid of increasing capacity into a weak market for fares, Ryanair nudged up its traffic forecast for 
the year to the end of March to 131 million passengers from an earlier forecast of 130 million.
"There are a few guys out there who look like they are starting to find life difficult," Sorahan said.
Analysts from Goodbody said Ryanair's tactics would increase pressure on carriers such as Alitalia, Air Berlin , 
Monarch and Norwegian Air Shuttle.
"The read on this is that they see demand weakening substantially and need to stimulate growth through 
aggressive pricing," they said in a note. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: August 10, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings PLC ( RYAAY ) Posts Quarterly Earnings Results, Beats Expectations By $0.30 EPS
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Posts Quarterly Earnings Results, Beats 
Expectations By $0.30 EPS
American Banking and Market News
July 25, 2017 Tuesday
Copyright 2017 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 627 words
Body
Ryanair Holdings PLC logo Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) released its quarterly earnings data on 
Monday. The transportation company reported $1.78 EPS for the quarter, beating the consensus estimate of $1.48 
by $0.30,            Morningstar.com  reports. The business had revenue of $2.10 billion for the quarter, compared to 
the consensus estimate of $2.02 billion. Ryanair Holdings PLC had a net margin of 20.01% and a return on equity 
of 33.23%.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY ) opened at 114.56 on Tuesday. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 1-year low of $67.22 
and a 1-year high of $115.97.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC declared that its board has initiated a stock repurchase plan on Tuesday, May 30th that 
permits the company to repurchase    shares. This repurchase authorization permits the transportation company to 
repurchase up to 2.3% of its stock  through open market purchases. Stock  repurchase plans are generally an 
indication that the company's board of directors believes its stock is undervalued.  
A number of institutional investors have recently bought and sold shares of RYAAY. Quantbot Technologies LP 
purchased a new position in  Ryanair Holdings PLC during the first quarter worth $106,000.  Oregon Public 
Employees Retirement Fund bought a new stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings PLC during the second quarter 
valued at approximately $108,000.  FNY Partners Fund LP bought a new stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings PLC 
during the first quarter valued at approximately $156,000.  PNC Financial Services Group Inc. raised its stake in 
shares of  Ryanair Holdings PLC by 5.3% in the first quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. now owns 1,941 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $160,000 after buying an additional 98 shares during the 
last quarter.  Finally, Private Advisor Group LLC bought a new stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings PLC during the 
first quarter valued at approximately $204,000. Hedge funds and other institutional investors own  38.72% of the 
company's stock.  
RYAAY has been the topic of several recent research reports. Sanford C. Bernstein initiated coverage on shares of 
Ryanair Holdings PLC in a report on Monday, June 26th. They issued an "underperform" rating and a $83.00 price 
objective on the stock. Zacks Investment Research  downgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "hold" 
rating to a "sell" rating in a report on Tuesday, April 11th. Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. (The) raised shares of 
Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "neutral" rating to a "buy" rating and upped their price objective for the company from 
$67.56 to $109.00 in a report on Thursday, June 15th. Citigroup Inc. downgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC 
from a "buy" rating to a "neutral" rating in a report on Wednesday, May 31st. Finally,            ValuEngine  
Ryanair Holdings PLC ( RYAAY ) Posts Quarterly Earnings Results, Beats Expectations By $0.30 EPS
downgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Wednesday, May 
24th. Two investment analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, three have given a hold rating and ten have 
issued  a buy rating to the stock. The company presently has an average rating of "Buy" and a consensus target 
price of $100.33. 
About Ryanair Holdings PLC
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.

WHAT THE OTHER PAPERS SAY THIS MORNING
WHAT THE OTHER PAPERS SAY THIS MORNING
City A.M.
July 25, 2017 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 2
Length: 429 words
Body
FINANCIAL TIMES UK MOVES TO TAKE STRAIN OFF ENERGY NETWORK BHP Billiton has hit back at activist 
investor Elliott, mounting a strong defence of its contentious fertiliser project in Canada. In a post on its Prospects 
blog, BHP said it would only proceed with the development of the Jansen potash mine if it met strict investment 
hurdles and was in the best interest of shareholders. Elliott, which has built a four per cent stake in BHP, said last 
week that it had "deep concerns" about Jansen.
BUDGET CARRIER CIRCLES ALITALIA Ryanair is one of several airlines to have made a bid for Alitalia ahead of 
the launch of a full-scale tender process for the loss-making Italian carrier in the coming weeks. Europe's biggest 
lowcost airline yesterday confirmed it had madea non-binding offer for Alitalia.
THE TIMES WE BROKE NO RULES, GRENFELL SUPPLIER SAYS The American maker of the cladding panels 
used on Grenfell Tower sought to distance itself further from the tragedy yesterday amid calls for a class-action 
lawsuit by shareholders.
POLICE CHIEF ACCUSED OF PULLING OUT OF PROTEST A police and crime commissioner has been accused 
of abusing his position because his force stopped sending officers to protect a fracking site hit by protests after he 
intervened. Arfon Jones was an anti-fracking campaigner and took part in a protest in Lancashire before being 
elected as commissioner for North Wales last year.
THE DAILY TELEGRAPH FIRST UTILITY ENTERS THE BROADBAND MARKET The UK's largest independent 
energy supplier is taking its challenge to the Big Six energy suppliers to the Big Four broadband giants by offering 
the market's lowest priced internet deal. First Utility is opening its £18.99 a month broadband deal to the wider 
market at a £270 discount to the largest broadband providers.
WHAT THE OTHER PAPERS SAY THIS MORNING
JULIUS BAER DRAWS £8.2BN IN NEW MONEY Private bank Julius Baer attracted 10.2bn Swiss francs (£8.2bn) 
in new money in the first-half of this year, its best six month period since the financial crisis almost a decade ago.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL SAMSUNG RELEASES ARTHRITIS DRUG Americans suffering from arthritis can 
now find relief from an unexpected new player in the pharmaceuticals market. Samsung Bioepis's biosimilar drug 
for rheumatoid arthritis to be marketed by Merck in US.
POLISH PRESIDENT BLOCKS TWO BILLS MEANT TO CURB COURT'S INDEPENDENCE Poland's President 
Andrzej Duda vetoed legislation passed by parliament that would have forced the entire Supreme Court into 
retirement, in a surprise move that bucked his own party and handed a victory to Poland's prodemocracy 
protesters.
