Raising a racket in Rome
Raising a racket in Rome
Sunday Business Post
July 6, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1213 words
Byline: Aileen Hickie
Highlight: A trip to the Italian Tennis Open proves the perfect Roman holiday and a fun alternative for tennis fans 
who can’t make it to Wimbledon, writes Aileen Hickie 
Body
When I told my elderly mother that I was going to the Italian Tennis Open, she wished me the best of luck and said 
she thought I would do very well. She was impressed that, having only taken up tennis through a Rusty Rackets 
programme a few years ago, I was now going to be playing with Venus Williams, Simona Halep and the like in 
Rome’s Foro Italico. I had to disappoint her. I was going to watch. Obviously.
The plan had been hatched over a few glasses of wine between friends in February of this year. Wimbledon, which 
of course everyone is glued to right now, might have seemed the perfect option, but tickets are very expensive and 
difficult to acquire, as is accommodation in London. And it rains.
Instead, Rome in May offered us a high level of competition with all the star players in beautiful surroundings, 
almost guaranteed sun and the absence of family. We figured there might also be a few cocktails served between 
matches, too.
Early planning had its advantages when it came to transportation, accommodation and tickets. The Italian Open 
started on May 10, with the finals taking place on Sunday May 21. We took the advice of other tennis fans who had 
previously been to ATP events (as they are called), and decided to book to watch the better matches in the later 
stages of the tournament, but not the expensive finals themselves. At quarter-final and semi-final stages, you get to 
see some of the biggest names take to the court and play with a real sense of purpose.
We booked our tennis tickets for Friday, May 19 and Saturday, May 20 in the Foro Italico, which meant we would 
get semi-final, centre court action while sitting in the hot Roman sun. These cost us about €250 each including 
service charges. We flew with Ryanair, going into Ciampino Airport (which is about a 30-minute drive into the city) 
on the Thursday evening. The return flights had set us back €122 each (on the Sunday), which we regarded as very 
good value.
Raising a racket in Rome
Next up was accommodation. We wanted a relatively inexpensive hotel in the centre of Rome, within walking 
distance of restaurants and shops, and one that provided something of the authentic Roman atmosphere.
We found the Hotel Piazza di Spagna on the Via Mario de’Fiori and booked two double superior rooms for three 
nights, including breakfast. This cost us €266 per person sharing in total, which we again regarded as reasonable, 
particularly as we didn’t intend spending long indoors. Our rooms were spacious and nicely decorated, if a little 
dark.
One of my travelling companions had the foresight to book dinner in a nearby restaurant for 10pm on the evening of 
our arrival, so after a quick change of clothes we were on our way.
Al 34 was just across the street from our hotel and we were quickly seated at a lovely paveside table, where we 
sipped on carafes of house white wine and hoovered up large plates of fish and pasta. The waiter politely asked us 
to leave after 1am, when all the other diners were long departed. We split the bill and paid the princely sum of €35 
each for a great evening’s dining.
Breakfast in the hotel the following morning was of the continental variety, but there was an abundance of tasty 
boiled eggs and still-warm bread rolls to go along with the delicious coffee, juice, cold meats, cheeses and fruit.
Having paid a quick visit to the Pantheon (so as not to seem like total cultural philistines), we set off for the tennis at 
11am, taking a 30-minute taxi journey. The Foro Italico, on the outskirts of the city, is a sports stadium built by 
Benito Mussolini and regarded as an architectural masterpiece of the Fascist era.
The first match was a treat between Anett Kontaveit and Simona Halep, and from this point it kept getting better. 
We sat in the glorious sunshine watching Alexander Zverev (who went on to win the tournament beating Novak 
Djokovic in the final), Rafael Nadal, Dominic Thiem, Venus Williams, Garbine Muguruza, Juan Martín del Potro and 
Djokovic.
We only managed to drag ourselves away in the mid-afternoon to quaff a few beers and eat a slice of pizza. Former 
British player Annabel Croft, a staple of Wimbledon coverage, sat at a nearby table looking serene while we 
sweated in the 38˚C heat.
Our tickets for the first match on the Saturday were for midday, which gave us the opportunity to do a little light 
shopping before taking the trip to the venue. Again, we had chosen our hotel well, being just minutes from a major 
shopping area which specialised in bright leather handmade bags. But the real ace was a vintage store called 
Lesley on the Via Vittoria: a secondhand clothes shop with luxury labels including Armani, Hermès, Prada and 
more, all with price tags reflecting their gently worn status. For €150, you could pick up beautiful designer trousers 
or shoes. The handbags were pricier, but a bargain nonetheless.
Once again, we spent the rest of the day watching the tennis in the Campo Centrale where we were awed by the 
play in the men’s semi-final between Zverev and John Isner. We were further wowed by Muguruza and Svitolina in 
the women’s semi-final, though it was a little disappointing when Muguruza retired injured. I was particularly 
downhearted, as I had decided to wear my own white tennis skirt for the day in case any player had to withdraw 
injured and I was called on to substitute. But they didn’t seem to need me.
It was close to 9pm when we returned to the hotel. Our planning had not extended to booking a restaurant for that 
evening, as we had thought we might do something spontaneous. This was a mistake: we were turned away from 
restaurant after restaurant. It was now well after 10pm and I would have eaten my own liver.
Turning a corner down a small street, we found a Mexican nightclub that also served food. We were thrilled to be 
given a table and happily ordered buckets of margaritas, large plates of nachos and enchiladas. We stayed until 
2am, knowing we had an early flight the following morning.
For tennis fans, it was the perfect Roman holiday. ■
Raising a racket in Rome
Marathon: it might seem a little extreme to train and run 26.2 miles for the sake of a little mini break. But I have 
done this three times now, and enjoyed marathon holidays in New York and London with a run thrown in. Berlin 
beckons in September, and Sports Travel International is just one company which offers the entire package of 
marathon entry, accommodation and flights.
Tennis: residential tennis holidays are also a booming business with coaching teams and tennis programmes being 
offered in four and five-star locations from the Algarve to Tenerife, Sardinia, Spain and Cyprus. Annabel Croft 
Tennis Holidays offers great packages to these destinations.
Yoga: my sister and her friends regularly rave about the benefits of a yoga retreat. Thailand seems to be the 
destination of choice for these yoga holidays, which can be booked for five days or more and often have a detox or 
weight-loss element to them too.
Cycling: cycling holidays are hugely popular at the moment, both in Ireland and abroad. You can choose from 
mountain biking in Spain, leisure cycling in Sardinia, pleasure cycling in Italy and road cycling in Andalucia. I’m not 
sure what the difference between leisure and pleasure cycling is, but it may have something to do with the size of 
the hills you have to climb.
Load-Date: July 8, 2017
End of Document

at the end of the most recent quarter.

Manchester Airport Evacuated, Bomb Disposal Unit At Scene
Manchester Airport Evacuated, Bomb Disposal Unit At Scene
International Business Times News
July 5, 2017 Wednesday 12:21 PM EST
Copyright 2017 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 518 words
Byline: Suman Varandani
Body
Jul 05, 2017( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)  UPDATE: 8:14 
a.m. EDT — The Manchester Airport issued a statement Wednesday updating passengers about the evacuation at 
Terminal 3. "Manchester Airport can confirm that our routine hold baggage screening process in Terminal 3 
identified a bag which appeared to contain suspicious item. Greater Manchester Police was immediately informed 
and all passengers were safely evacuated from the terminal while further investigations took place," authorities said 
in the statement.[1] "Officers have now determined the bad poses no threat and we are beginning to process of 
allowing colleagues and passengers back into the terminal." 
"We apologize to all passengers affected by this incident. The safety and security of our customers and employees 
will always be our number one priority. We encourage all passengers due to travel from Terminal 3 to contact their 
airline for updates." Original Story Manchester Airport's Terminal 3 was evacuated Wednesday after a "suspicious 
package" was found in the area. The airport said on its Twitter account the evacuation was only at one terminal and 
passengers were being sent to other terminals to board their planes. A bomb disposal unit arrived at the scene after 
police was alerted about the incident linked to a "potential issue with a bag." People at the airport posted photos of 
passengers waiting at the tarmac as authorities conducted the precautionary evacuation. In a statement, the airport 
said six Ryanair flights were diverted to Terminal 2, while the rest of the passengers were advised to use Terminal 
1 for their travel. The airport also said that plane's due to arrive at Terminal 3 are heading to the other two 
terminals.https://twitter.com/manairport/status/882544358574231553'Police were called at 8.50am on Wednesday 
5 July 2017 to reports of a suspicious package at Manchester Airport. Officers are responding and a precautionary 
evacuation of terminal three has taken place. Bomb disposal officers attended and a series of controlled explosions 
were carried out of the package," the Greater Manchester Police said. 'Enquiries are ongoing.' University lecturer 
Lizabeth Hannaford, who was among those evacuated, tweeted that police were expanding the security cordon and 
moving people further away from the terminal. Here are some photos and reactions posted on social media.           
https://twitter.com/KiplingSenpai/status/882531629251612672 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
https://twitter.com/QueensIceZ/status/882565586718425088

Manchester Arena on May 22 when British Muslim Salman Ramadan Abedi, 22 detonated a homemade bomb after 
a concert by singer Ariana Grande. Twenty-three people, including the bomber, were killed in the attack. The threat 
from international terrorism in the UK remains "severe" — as it has been since August 2014 — meaning an attack is 
highly likely. [ 1]:            https://twitter.com/manairport/status/882567259746643968

Ryanair June Traffic Jumps 12%; Load Factor Rises to 96%.

July 5, 2017 Wednesday 4:40 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 45 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYAAY) said Tuesday that traffic, measured as revenue passenger miles, jumped 12% in June while the 
load factor rose two percentage points to 96%. 
The carrier said improvement was due to "lower fares and the continuing success" of its customer experience 
program.

TOP NEWS SUMMARY: Worldpay Confirms Approach By Vantiv And JPMorgan
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: Worldpay Confirms Approach By Vantiv And 
JPMorgan
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
July 4, 2017 Tuesday 6:14 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 505 words
Body
 The following is a summary of top news stories Tuesday.----------COMPANIES----------Worldpay Group said it has 
received preliminary takeover approaches from both payment services provider Vantiv and financial services firm 
JPMorgan Chase Bank. The FTSE 100-listed payment processing firm noted a recent movement in its share price 
resulting from press speculation surrounding a takeover approach. "There can be no certainty either that an offer 
will be made nor as to the terms of any offer, if made," Worldpay said in a statement. Each of Vantiv and JP Morgan 
have a deadline of August 1 to confirm if they wish to make an offer for Worldpay. 
----------J Sainsbury reported growth in sales in the first quarter of its financial year as it continued launching new 
products, and said it is "well-placed to navigate the external environment". The supermarket chain said retail sales 
in the 16 weeks ended July 1 grew by 2.7% year-on-year, excluding fuel, while like-for-like sales rose by 2.3%, also 
excluding fuel. Grocery sales increased by 3.0% on the back of a 1.9% rise in transaction growth, which 
Sainsbury's said was thanks to "strong" food sales where it has invested in product innovation, such as its new 
Summer eating ranges.----------Oil field services firm Hunting said it expects to report a loss for the first half of 2017, 
due to low oil prices leading to continued weak US offshore and international drilling markets. Hunting said although 
it has benefited from an increase in onshore drilling in the US, its Well Construction and Well Intervention segments 
continue to see difficult market conditions. The firm said its outlook for the remainder of 2017 is predicated on 
"sustained US onshore drilling activity" driving trading, along with "cautious optimism for stable offshore and 
international markets". ----------Budget airlines Ryanair Holdings and Wizz Air Holdings reported growth in both the 
number of passengers carried and load factor in June year-on-year. Irish carrier Ryanair said it carried 12% more 
passengers in June to 11.8 million from 10.6 million a year earlier, as load factor increased by 2 percentage points 
to 96% from 94%. On a rolling annual basis, traffic grew by 13% to 123.8 million passengers. Central and Eastern 
European-focused airline Wizz Air said it flew 24% more customers in June to 2.5 million from 2.0 million a year 
earlier, as load factor rose by 0.6 percentage point to 92.3% from 91.7%.----------MARKETS----------London shares 
were lower mid-morning as payments processor Worldpay led the blue-chip risers. The pound was slightly lower 
against the dollar as data showed UK construction sector growth eased more than forecast in June. Markets in the 
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: Worldpay Confirms Approach By Vantiv And JPMorgan
US were closed for the Independence Day holiday.----------FTSE 100: down 0.1% at 7,370.51FTSE 250: down 0.1% 
at 19,295.31AIM ALL-SHARE: down 0.1% at 961.28

Ryanair Holdings PLC has a consensus price target of $96.00, indicating a potential downside of 12.18%. Given 
Hawaiian Holdings' higher possible upside, equities research analysts plainly believe Hawaiian Holdings is more 
favorable than Ryanair Holdings PLC. Profitability This table compares Hawaiian Holdings and Ryanair Holdings

higher revenue and earnings than Ryanair Holdings PLC. Hawaiian Holdings is trading at a lower price-to-earnings 
ratio than Ryanair Holdings PLC, indicating that it is currently the more affordable of the two stocks.  Institutional 
and Insider Ownership 90.5% of Hawaiian Holdings shares are owned by institutional investors. Comparatively, 
39.9% of Ryanair Holdings PLC shares are owned by institutional investors. 2.3% of Hawaiian Holdings shares are 
owned by insiders. Strong institutional ownership is an indication that large money managers, hedge funds and 
endowments believe a company is poised for long-term growth. Risk ...latility Hawaiian Holdings has a beta of 1.42, 
suggesting that its share price is 42% more volatile than the S...00. Comparatively, Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 
beta of 0.6, suggesting that its share price is 40% less volatile than the S...00.  About Hawaiian Holdings Hawaiian 
Holdings, Inc. is a holding company. The Company is engaged in the scheduled air transportation of passengers 
and cargo amongst the Hawaiian Islands (the Neighbor Island routes), between the Hawaiian Islands and certain 
cities in the United States (the North America routes), and between the Hawaiian Islands and the South Pacific, 
Australia, New Zealand and Asia (the International routes), collectively referred to as its Scheduled Operations. It 
offers non-stop service to Hawai'i from United States gateway cities. As of December 31, 2016, it also provided 
approximately 160 daily flights between the Hawaiian Islands. The Company operates various charter flights. As of 
December 31, 2016, the Company's fleet consisted of 20 Boeing 717-200 aircraft for the Neighbor Island routes, 
eight Boeing 767-300 aircraft, and 23 Airbus A330-200 aircraft for the North America, International, and charter 
routes. About Ryanair Holdings PLC Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair

ancillary services and engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight 
scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise. Ryanair 
markets accommodation services and travel insurance through its Website. It provides hotel and accommodation

Hawaiian Holdings has higher revenue and earnings than Ryanair Holdings PLC. Hawaiian Holdings is trading at a 
lower price-to-earnings ratio than Ryanair Holdings PLC, indicating that it is currently the more affordable of the two

Institutional and Insider Ownership
90.5% of Hawaiian Holdings shares are owned by institutional investors. Comparatively, 39.9% of Ryanair Holdings 
PLC shares are owned by institutional investors. 2.3% of Hawaiian Holdings shares are owned by insiders. Strong 
institutional ownership is an indication that large money managers, hedge funds and endowments believe a 
company is poised for long-term growth. 
Risk & Volatility Hawaiian Holdings has a beta of 1.42, suggesting that its share price is 42% more volatile than 
the S&P 500. Comparatively, Ryanair Holdings PLC has a beta of 0.6, suggesting that its share price is 40% less 
volatile than the S&P 500. 
About Hawaiian Holdings
Hawaiian Holdings logo Hawaiian Holdings, Inc. is a holding company. The Company is engaged in the scheduled 
air transportation of passengers and cargo amongst the Hawaiian Islands (the Neighbor Island routes), between the 
Hawaiian Islands and certain cities in the United States (the North America routes), and between the Hawaiian 
Islands and the South Pacific, Australia, New Zealand and Asia (the International routes), collectively referred to as 
its Scheduled Operations. It offers non-stop service to Hawai'i from United States gateway cities. As of December 
31, 2016, it also provided approximately 160 daily flights between the Hawaiian Islands. The Company operates 
various charter flights. As of December 31, 2016, the Company's fleet consisted of 20 Boeing 717-200 aircraft for 
the Neighbor Island routes, eight Boeing 767-300 aircraft, and 23 Airbus A330-200 aircraft for the North America, 
International, and charter routes. 
About Ryanair Holdings PLC
Ryanair Holdings PLC logo Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited 
(Ryanair). Ryanair operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary 
services and engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight 
scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise. Ryanair 
markets accommodation services and travel insurance through its Website. It provides hotel and accommodation 
services. Ryanair provides its own aircraft and passenger handling and ticketing services at Dublin Airport. As of 
June 30, 2016, Ryanair had a principal fleet of over 350 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and offered over 2,000 scheduled 
short-haul flights per day serving approximately 200 airports throughout Europe.

Sales slump asAsia closes gap Our monthly summary of commercial aircraft orders shows modest successes 
in May, when Airbus and Boeing shared the spoils. Meanwhi....
Sales slump asAsia closes gap; Our monthly summary of commercial 
aircraft orders shows modest successes in May, when Airbus and Boeing 
shared the spoils. Meanwhile, North America's market lead is under fire
Flight International
July 4, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS ANALYSIS
Length: 528 words
Body
A total of 72 new commercial aircraft orders during May were offset by 24 cancellations and 30 swaps, according to 
preliminary figures from Flight Fleets Analyzer. The new order total was split between Airbus, with 59 sales, and 
Boeing, with 13.
The net figure of 48 aircraft ordered in May represents a 74% decrease on the same month during 2016, when 
Fleets Analyzer shows a net 184 units ordered.
NARROWBODY FOCUS
Of the new orders received, narrowbody commitments dominated, at 42 aircraft. These were predominantly for 
A320-family jets, with Airbus logging 39 orders for the type, including 34 Neo-model examples.
Customers included Delta Air Lines, which ordered 30 more A321s, increasing its firm on-order total for the aircraft 
to 112. The jets will be powered by CFM International CFM56 engines. Unannounced buyers accounted for an 
additional nine A320-family twinjets, while European low-cost carrier EasyJet switched 30 of its orders for 
A320neos to the larger A321neo, to be delivered from mid-2018.
The remaining three narrowbody orders were for Boeing 737s.
At the end of May, the overall aircraft order backlog stood at 14,363: down 100 on the previous month.
Fleets Analyzer shows that 143 commercial aircraft were delivered in May, down 8% on the same month in 2016. 
This total was split between narrowbody and widebody types at 84 and 33 units, respectively, followed by 
17 regional jet shipments and nine turboprops delivered.
Sales slump asAsia closes gap Our monthly summary of commercial aircraft orders shows modest successes 
in May, when Airbus and Boeing shared the spoils. Meanwhi....
Customers in the Asia-Pacific region and Europe took delivery of 47 and 41 units, respectively, while mainline and 
low-cost operators accounted for 62 and 42 of the shipments, respectively.
Airbus delivered 46 A320-family aircraft – including 13 Neo examples, while Boeing shipped 33 737NGs and the 
first 737 Max.
Ryanair took the most aircraft of any airline during May, receiving seven 737s at a rate which has been sustained 
since the start of this year to support its rapid expansion. American Airlines received four aircraft: two A321s and 
two 737s; while Batik Air, Norwegian and VietJet Air each took delivery of two aircraft.
The figure of 33 widebody shipments matched the total seen in the same month last year, with Boeing having 
delivered 20 and Airbus 13. Saudia was the largest recipient for the month, taking single examples of the A330, 777 
and 787.
In the regional sector, Skywest Airlines took delivery of four Embraer 175s, while Iran Air received the same number 
of ATR 72-600s: the first of 20 that it is taking under a deal sealed in April.
FLEET GROWTH
Meanwhile, Fleets Analyzer shows that the in-service commercial fleet in May totalled more than 25,500 passenger 
aircraft and more than 2,300 used for freight operations.
The in-service narrowbody fleet exceeded 15,150 units, up slightly from April and accounting for more than half of 
all commercial aircraft. The active fleet in the growing Asia-Pacific market is now only 240 units behind the current 
largest market, North America.
74%
May’s net commercial aircraft order total of 48 units marked a major fall from the 184 recorded by Flight Fleets 
Analyzer during the same month one year earlier
Delta was the big buyer for the month, ordering 30 more A321s
Airbus
Load-Date: July 17, 2017

Ryanair sees jump in passenger traffic in June
Ryanair sees jump in passenger traffic in June
Business World (Digest)
July 04, 2017 Tuesday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 138 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Ryanair has today released traffic statistics for the month of June which show that traffic grew 12% to 11.8m 
customers and load factor rose 2% points to 96%.
Ryanair is Europe's largest airline by passenger numbers and has recently seen a jump in passenger numbers on 
the back of lower fares and the continuing success of their “Always Getting Better” customer experience 
programme.
Speaking today, Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, Kenny Jacobs said, "Customers can still avail of great fares for 
low cost summer breaks and make advance bookings for winter 2017, so there’s never been a better time to book a 
low fare flight on Ryanair and we urge all customers who wish to book their holidays to do so now on the 
Ryanair.com website or mobile app, where they can avail of the lowest fares in Europe."
Source: www.businessworld.ie

FTSE 100 Slides On Profit Taking; Worldpay Shares Surge 21%
FTSE 100 Slides On Profit Taking; Worldpay Shares Surge 21%
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
July 4, 2017 Tuesday 12:40 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 199 words
Body
       BRUSSELS/FRANKFURT/PARIS (dpa-AFX) - U.K. shares were slightly lower on Tuesday as oil and mining 
stocks succumbed to profit taking after sharp gains the previous day.    An upbeat sales update from supermarket 
chain J Sainsbury and news of takeover approach from Vantiv for payments processing firm Worldpay helped to 
limit overall losses to some extent.   The benchmark FTSE 100 was down 15 points or 0.20 percent at 7,362 in late 
opening deals after rising 0.9 percent in the previous session.   Anglo American, Antofagasta, BHP Billiton, BP Plc 
and Glencore fell between half a percent and 1.1 percent.   Worldpay shares soared as much as 21 percent after 
the company said it had received preliminary approaches from Vantiv Inc and JPMorgan Chase Bank for a potential 
deal.   Sainsbury rose about 1 percent. The supermarket group reported a 2.3 percent rise in same-store sales for 
the first quarter.   Discount airline Ryanair Holdings rose half a percent on reporting a 12 percent rise in passenger 
traffic in June from a year earlier.   Semiconductor designer Imagination Technologies soared 6 percent after it 
swung to a full-year pretax profit with a clear strategy for growth.

'Tempted' O'Leary haggles over pricing
'Tempted' O'Leary haggles over pricing
Flight International
July 4, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: THIS WEEK
Length: 154 words
Body
Ryanair chief executive Michael O’Leary is “very tempted” to order the Boeing 737 Max 10, but only when the “price 
is right”.
Talks with Boeing over a potential order are under way, “but we haven’t reached an agreement on pricing yet”, he 
says.
Speaking at the Future Travel Experience conference in Dublin on 26 June, O’Leary added that the “obvious 
attraction” of the new variant was its 30 extra seats over the carrier’s ordered 200-seat 737 Max 8 200s.
But he stresses that Ryanair would only buy the type at a price that allows it to continue reducing airfares.
O’Leary sees a risk that the Max 10 could add “complexity” to operations by requiring Ryanair to take on extra crew, 
and extra seats would mean a “big further yield dilution”. He rules out converting any existing Ryanair orders for the 
Max 8. “I get eight seats more per aircraft, 4% more revenue, without any more cabin crew and pilots,” says 
O’Leary of the Max 8.
Load-Date: July 17, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair ponders Brexit buybacks from UK shareholders
Ryanair ponders Brexit buybacks from UK shareholders
AirFinance Journal
July 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 222 words
Byline: Laura Mueller
Body
Ryanair could increase share buybacks to comply with European Union ownership laws when Britain leaves the 
EU, according to the Irish carrier's chief executive officer.
"Ownership post Brexit is a real issue," Michael O'Leary was quoted as saying by London South East at a hearing 
in the European Parliament. "It might help me to accelerate the share buyback if UK shareholders are forced to 
sell."
According to O'Leary about 20% of Ryanair's shareholders are UK-based. The carrier has already been carrying 
out share buybacks to return cash to shareholders.
To qualify as a European carrier airlines have to be majority owned by European investors. Ryanair was 53.6% 
owned by EU nationals, including UK investors in 2016, according to the airline.
O'Leary reiterated that unless a deal is agreed for Brexit then flights between Britain and the remaining European 
Union countries could be grounded.
"There is not a legal mechanism on which airlines can operate in a 'hard Brexit, no deal' outcome. There will simply 
be no flights," he said, adding that Ryanair would start cancelling flights six months before the March 2019 date 
when Britain is due to leave the EU - with or without a deal.
Aviation is not covered by World Trade Organisation rules, which would apply to other industries should Britain fail 
to agree a deal by March 2019.
Load-Date: August 7, 2017
End of Document
Easyjet Europe to be headquartered in Vienna
Easyjet Europe to be headquartered in Vienna
AirFinance Journal
July 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 316 words
Byline: alex.derber
Body
British low-cost carrier (LCC) Easyjet intends to base its European headquarters in Austria in order to avoid any 
disruption to its intra-European Union services when the United Kingdom leaves the European Union.
The LCC has applied to Austro Control for an air operator certificate (AOC) and to Austria's transport ministry for an 
airline operating licence.
Once these are received the company will establish a new airline, Easyjet Europe, and headquarter it in Vienna.
The new arrangement should mean that Easyjet can continue flights between European Union destinations once 
Britain leaves the European Union.
To do so an airline must be majority owned and effectively controlled by European Union shareholders, conditions 
that Easyjet promises to meet.
“The new structure means that easyJet would become a pan European airline group with three airlines based in 
Austria, Switzerland and the UK. All of these will be owned by easyJet plc which itself will be European Union-
owned and controlled,” Easyjet says in a statement.
In June the European Commission published guidance about ownership and control rules, which it said should look 
at an airline’s corporate governance and “where” strategic business decision are taken.
Easyjet says that its Austrian accreditation processes are “well underway” and that its AOC and licence should 
materialise in the “near future”.
However, flights from Easyjet’s main bases in London to Europe still have a cloud hanging over them.
Michael O’Leary, boss of Ryanair, Easyjet’s Dublin-based rival, told the European Parliament this week that Brexit 
could mean a temporary cessation of all flights between the UK and Europe.
“Easyjet will continue to push for the UK and EU to reach an aviation agreement which, at a minimum, will enable 
flights between the UK and EU,” says Easyjet.
Easyjet Europe to be headquartered in Vienna
Load-Date: August 7, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair adds capacity but restates Brexit aircraft warning
Ryanair adds capacity but restates Brexit aircraft warning
AirFinance Journal
July 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 529 words
Byline: Laura Mueller
Body
Ryanair took delivery of 14 new aircraft in the quarter to 30 June and subsequently has agreed several lease 
extensions.
The carrier indicates in a first-quarter earnings release it added 14 new Boeing 737-800 aircraft and continues to 
see “significant growth opportunities” across Europe as legacy airlines restructure and other competitors close 
bases or move capacity.
The low-cost airline ended the quarter with 397 737units.
It topped up its orderbook in June with 10 more 737 Max 200s. Five of these will be delivered in 2019 and five more 
in 2020.
In addition, it recently agreed extensions of 10 operating leases that will provide three additional aircraft in 2018 and 
10 more in 2019.
“This addresses a temporary capacity shortage before our Boeing Max deliveries accelerate in September 2019 
and allows us to maintain consistent growth through FY20,” says Ryanair.
The carrier says it remains “concerned at the uncertainty which surrounds the terms of the UK’s departure from the 
EU” in March 2019.
“While we continue to campaign for the UK to remain in the EU Open Skies agreement, we caution that should the 
UK leave, there may not be sufficient time, or goodwill on both sides, to negotiate a timely replacement bilateral 
which could result in a disruption of flights between the UK and Europe for a period of time from April 2019 
onwards,” it adds.
If there is no certainty about the legal basis for the operation of flights between the UK and the European Union by 
autumn 2018, Ryanair “may be forced to cancel flights and move some, or all, of our UK based aircraft to 
Continental Europe from April 2019 onwards”.
Ryanair’s net profit jumped 55% for the first quarter of its 2018 financial year, with the post-tax figure increasing to 
&euro;397 million ($453 million), compared with &euro;256 million a year ago.
Ryanair adds capacity but restates Brexit aircraft warning
Revenue totalled &euro;1.9 billion, up 13% year over year.
Passenger numbers for the quarter rose 12% to 35 million. Load factor climbed two percentage points to 96%, 
compared with the same period last year.
In May the Ryanair board approved a &euro;600 million ordinary share buyback programme. In the first quarter, it 
spent &euro;165 million under this buyback at an average price of &euro;18.20.
It also purchased &euro;39 million worth of American Depositary Receipts (ADR) under the &euro;150 million 
“Evergreen” ADR buyback programme launched last February. Despite this cumulative spend of over &euro;200 
million on buybacks and capex of almost &euro;400 million in the quarter, it reduced net debt by &euro;150 million 
to &euro;94 million at 30 June, from &euro;244 million at 31 March.
Ryanair is raising its fiscal year 2018 traffic target to 131 million, up one million on its previous guidance. Ex-fuel 
unit costs are on track to deliver a 1% reduction this year, and fuel hedging should deliver savings of approximately 
&euro;70 million, when adjusted for volume growth.
However, the carrier warns that the guidance remains heavily dependent on “close-in summer bookings, the 
absence of any further security events, ATC strikes or negative Brexit developments".
Load-Date: August 14, 2017
End of Document
Hard Brexit will stop UK-EU flights: Ryanair boss
Hard Brexit will stop UK-EU flights: Ryanair boss
AirFinance Journal
July 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 290 words
Byline: alex.derber
Body
Ryanair's chief executive officer Michael O’Leary has told the European Parliament that flights between the UK and 
Europe could halt for a period after Britain leaves the European Union (EU).
For services to continue uninterrupted either Britain would have to remain a member of the single aviation market, 
over which the European Court of Justice (ECJ) has jurisdiction, or agree a new bilateral air treaty with the EU.
A ‘hard brexit’ – in which the UK crashes out of the EU with no deal or with one that sees it lose most of the benefits 
of single market and customs union membership – would probably preclude both of those options, thus halting 
flights.
O’Leary pointed out that current UK Brexit policy, such as one existed, sought the removal of ECJ oversight. He 
also thought it very unlikely that the UK and EU could negotiate a new bilateral treaty before 31 March 2019, when 
Britain is scheduled to officially leave the EU.
“There isn’t a mechanism to do a deal. No-one in the UK government has a clue how to do a deal; they don’t even 
know what it is the hell they want,” O’Leary told MEPs.
As a result, Ryanair will start shifting aircraft from the UK to European regional airports from April 2019.
However, O’Leary also predicted that the UK government would be “forced to come to its senses” and do a deal 
soon after, meaning that any disruption to flights would probably last for about eight weeks.
“After a couple of months the British public will understand that they don’t all want to go on holiday in Scotland or 
Ireland,” he said.
O’Leary described Brexit as “one of the great economic suicide notes in history”.
Load-Date: August 7, 2017
End of Document

European ADRs Move Higher in Wednesday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Wednesday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
June 28, 2017 Wednesday 11:01 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 231 words
Body
 American depository receipts of European stocks were trading 0.43% higher at 134.53 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Wednesday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by radiopharmaceutical company Advanced Accelerator Applications 
(AAAP), and biopharmaceutical company Cellectis (CLLS), which rose 3.5% and 2.8% respectively. They were 
followed by telecommunications provider Telecom Italia (TI), and medical equipment company Edap (EDAP), which 
increased 2.3% and 1.5% each.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by biotechnology company Argenx (ARGX), and cell therapy company 
TiGenix (TIG), which fell 4% and 1.3% each. They were followed by automation company ABB (ABB), and 
telecommunications company Telefonica (TEF), which were down 0.7% and 0.6% each.
In the U.K. and Ireland, the gainers were led by mining companies Rio Tinto (RIO), and BHP Billiton (BBL), which 
climbed 2.3% each. They were followed by telecommunications company BT Group (BT), and pharmaceutical firm 
Amarin (AMRN), which rose  1.9% and 1.7% respectively. 
The decliners in the U.K. and Ireland were led by biopharmaceutical companies Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), and 
Verona Pharma (VRNA), down 3.2%, and 1.7% respectively. Biopharmaceutical firm Midatech Pharma (MTP), and 
airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), dropped 1.2% and 0.6% each.

Ryanair would want majority stake if opts to bid for Alitalia
Ryanair would want majority stake if opts to bid for Alitalia
Business World (Digest)
June 28, 2017 Wednesday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 369 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair would seek a majority stake in Alitalia if it decides to invest in the loss-making Italian airline, its chief 
executive said during a visit to Rome on Tuesday.
Alitalia filed in May to be put under special administration for the second time in less than a decade, starting a 
process that will lead to the airline being overhauled, sold off or wound up.
"In case of an acquisition, we would be interested in a majority stake, not a minority one," Ryanair CEO Michael 
O'Leary told journalists during a news conference in Rome. "We are not interested in a 49% stake."
Ryanair, Europe's largest airline by passenger numbers, had already expressed an interest in Alitalia, but 
previously stressed it was keen on cooperating with the business rather than buying it.
Ryanair had also said it wanted to provide short-haul traffic to feed Alitalia's long-haul network and offered to deploy 
aircraft this summer if the Italian carrier cut capacity significantly.
However, on Tuesday O'Leary said Ryanair would consider a bid for the entire airline once it was restructured by 
the administrators.
More than 30 parties have expressed an interest in Alitalia, although local media said none of the offers were for the 
entire airline but only for specific assets such as planes or airport slots.
The commissioners have now given selected parties access to Alitalia's books, with non-binding offers due by July 
21.
Ryanair would want majority stake if opts to bid for Alitalia
The government has repeatedly said it would prefer to sell the airline in one block, partly to minimize the impact on 
its 12,500 staff. It has ruled out re-nationalizing Alitalia.
Whereas Etihad Airways, which came to Alitalia's rescue in 2014, was bound by European rules that limit 
ownership by groups from outside the EU to 49%, Dublin-based Ryanair would be free to buy a bigger stake.
Without a majority stake, Etihad's influence was limited despite being the largest single investor and the lack of full 
control meant it could not deal with labor and other problems effectively.
Ryanair already has a strong presence in Italy.
The airline expects its Italian passengers to rise to 36 million this year, O'Leary said. Official traffic data put the total 
at 32.6 million last year. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: July 12, 2017
End of Document

E Ryanair could be tempted by Max 10 at 'right price': O'Leary Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary is "very 
tempted" to order the Boeing 737 Max 10, but onl....
 E Ryanair could be tempted by Max 10 at 'right price': O'Leary; Ryanair chief 
executive Michael O'Leary is "very tempted" to order the Boeing 737 Max 10, 
but only when the "price is right", he tells FlightGlobal.
Flight International
June 27, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 237 words
Body
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary is "very tempted" to order the Boeing 737 Max 10, but only when the "price 
is right", he tells FlightGlobal.
Discussions with Boeing over a potential order are under way "but we haven't reached an agreement on pricing 
yet", says O'Leary.
The Ryanair chief, who was speaking to FlightGlobal at the Future Travel Experience conference in Dublin on 26 
June, added that the "obvious attraction" of the new variant – launched at this year's Paris air show – was its 30 
extra seats.
But he stresses that Ryanair would only buy the variant at a price that allows it to continue reducing airfares.
O'Leary sees a risk that the Max 10 could add "complexity" to Ryanair's operations by requiring the budget carrier 
to take on extra crew members, and says the additional seats would mean a "big further yield dilution to what are 
already the lowest airfares in Europe".
He rules out converting any of Ryanair's existing orders for the Max 8, which represents "the ultimate sweet spot" 
for the carrier. "I get eight seats more per aircraft, 4% more revenue, without any more cabin crew and pilots," says 
O'Leary of the Max 8.
Ryanair ordered 10 additional Max 8s during the Paris air show. This, says O'Leary, was a result of Boeing bringing 
production of the type forward, "which is where they got the extra slots from".
Flight Fleets Analyzer shows that Ryanair has 110 Max 8s and 65 737-800s on order.
E Ryanair could be tempted by Max 10 at 'right price': O'Leary Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary is "very 
tempted" to order the Boeing 737 Max 10, but onl....
Load-Date: June 27, 2017
End of Document

Ryanair Holdings PLC ( RYAAY ) Given Average Recommendation of "Hold" by Brokerages
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Given Average Recommendation of "Hold" 
by Brokerages
American Banking and Market News
June 27, 2017 Tuesday
Copyright 2017 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 631 words
Body
Ryanair Holdings PLC logo Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) has received a consensus recommendation 
of "Hold" from the sixteen research firms that are currently  covering the firm,            Marketbeat Ratings  reports. 
Two equities research analysts have rated the stock with a sell recommendation, five have assigned  a hold 
recommendation and nine have issued  a buy recommendation on  the company. The average 1 year price target 
among analysts that have issued ratings on the stock in the last year is $97.75.  
Several analysts recently weighed in on the company. Sanford C. Bernstein assumed coverage on Ryanair 
Holdings PLC in a report on Monday. They set an "underperform" rating and a $83.00 price target on the stock. 
Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. (The) upgraded Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "neutral" rating to a "buy" rating and 
increased their price target for the company from $67.56 to $109.00 in a report on Thursday, June 15th. ValuEngine  
upgraded Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Tuesday, June 6th. Citigroup 
Inc. lowered Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "buy" rating to a "neutral" rating in a report on Wednesday, May 31st. 
Finally,            Zacks Investment Research  upgraded Ryanair Holdings PLC from a "sell" rating to a "buy" rating 
and set a $109.00 price target on the stock in a report on Saturday, May 6th. 
A number of hedge funds have recently added to or reduced their stakes in RYAAY. State Street Corp raised its 
stake in  Ryanair Holdings PLC by 35.0% in the fourth quarter. State Street Corp now owns 324,522 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $27,016,000 after buying an additional 84,140 shares during the last quarter.  
Reliance Trust Co. of Delaware raised its stake in  Ryanair Holdings PLC by 22.5% in the first quarter. Reliance 
Trust Co. of Delaware now owns 9,615 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $798,000 after buying 
an additional 1,764 shares during the last quarter.  Huntington National Bank raised its stake in  Ryanair Holdings 
PLC by 4.3% in the first quarter. Huntington National Bank now owns 2,722 shares of the transportation company's 
stock worth $226,000 after buying an additional 111 shares during the last quarter.  Marshall Wace LLP raised its 
stake in  Ryanair Holdings PLC by 271.3% in the first quarter. Marshall Wace LLP now owns 37,737 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $3,132,000 after buying an additional 27,573 shares during the last quarter.  
Finally, A.R.T. Advisors LLC raised its stake in  Ryanair Holdings PLC by 235.9% in the fourth quarter. A.R.T. 
Advisors LLC now owns 13,100 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $1,090,000 after buying an 
additional 9,200 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors and hedge funds own  39.87% of the 
company's stock.  
Ryanair Holdings PLC ( RYAAY ) Given Average Recommendation of "Hold" by Brokerages
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY ) opened at 108.66 on Tuesday. The firm's 50 day moving average is $103.67 and 
its 200 day moving average is $89.02. The stock has a market capitalization of $26.47 billion, a P/E ratio of 18.54 
and a beta of 0.57. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 1-year low of $66.09 and a 1-year high of $110.82.   
About Ryanair Holdings PLC
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.

on Saturday, May 6th. Two research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, five have assigned  a hold 
rating and nine have given a buy rating to the company. The company  has an average rating of "Hold" and a

Movers &#38; Shakers
Movers &#38; Shakers
Sunday Business Post
June 24, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 238 words
Byline: Post Reporter
Body
■ Chiara Ravara is the new senior sales and marketing manager at Ryanair. Ravara has been the airline’s sales 
and marketing manager for the eastern Mediterranean market for the past 14 months. Previously, she was sales 
and marketing executive for Italy, Greece and Croatia.
[caption id="attachment_391634" align="alignnone" width="300"] John Doherty[/caption]
■ John Doherty has been appointed academic director for the English Studio Group and head of school for Dublin. 
He was previously director of studies at English Studio Dublin, which rebranded as English Studio Dublin, and has 
14 years’ experience in international education, including three years as director of education at Oman’s Ministry of 
Education.
[caption id="attachment_391635" align="alignnone" width="300"] Barry Mulcahy[/caption]
■ MSD has appointed a new site lead for its Brinny facility in Co Cork. Barry Mulcahy has been technology lead for 
MSD in Brinny for the past three years. Before that, he was site strategy and learning director there for six months.
[caption id="attachment_391636" align="alignnone" width="300"] Eddie O’Loughlin[/caption]
■ Eddie O’Loughlin is the new managing director of English Studio Group. O’Loughlin founded ECM College in 
2010 with his two brothers, selling the company last year to The Real Experience Group. He remained with the 
company, as managing director of the Irish operation and now also manages English Studio London.

Fintech entrepreneur aims to be Sweden 's coolest banker Corporate person in the news: Sebastian 
Siemiatkowski, Chief executive, Klarna
Fintech entrepreneur aims to be Sweden's coolest banker; Corporate person 
in the news: Sebastian Siemiatkowski, Chief executive, Klarna
Financial Times (London, England)
June 24, 2017 Saturday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES - WEEK IN REVIEW; Pg. 9
Length: 602 words
Byline: Richard Milne
Body
Swedish business bosses are known for being careful with their words, some might even say dull. Sebastian 
Siemiatkowski is different.
It might be his tech background or his age, he is 35, but the chief executive of Klarna is not afraid to speak his mind. 
Announcing this week that his company had become the biggest fintech in Europe to receive a banking licence , he 
said he wanted Klarna to become the "Ryanair" of the sector and attack the high-voltage incumbents.
"Ryanair has pretty bad customer service," sniffed one senior Swedish banker. But in the next breath, she added: 
"That's to take nothing away from Klarna. What Sebastian has achieved there is remarkable."
Mr Siemiatkowski and two university friends took a deceptively simple idea on invoicing and applied it to the digital 
age. The result is an online payments system that is simpler for customers and better for merchants, with fewer 
dropped transactions caused by people balking at filling in too much information. Instead, customers pay for online 
goods after they receive them, and Klarna takes the credit risk from sellers in return for a cut.
Entered 12 years ago in an entrepreneur competition at Sweden's leading business school, the idea was rejected 
by many of the country's top executives. The desire to prove them wrong still motivates Mr Siemiatkowski. "For me 
Fintech entrepreneur aims to be Sweden 's coolest banker Corporate person in the news: Sebastian 
Siemiatkowski, Chief executive, Klarna
personally, it's a day I've been looking forward to for a long time," he said of Monday's decision by Swedish 
regulators to give Klarna a banking licence.
Mr Siemiatkowski has also long stood out in Sweden as one of the few business people willing to give his opinions 
about politics. After national elections that saw a breakthrough for the anti-immigration Sweden Democrats, he told 
the Financial Times: "We believe that Sweden becomes a much better place because people from all over the 
world are working here. Seeing the Sweden Democrats growing feels like taking the country back 100 years ago."
That impatience with the traditional ways of doing things has led to Klarna becoming one of the most highly valued 
technology groups in Europe. A round of fundraising in 2015 valued it at $2.25bn. And it is solidly profitable, making 
an operating profit of SKr138m ($16m) in the first quarter on revenues of SKr992m.
Klarna's ambitions go way beyond increasing profits. Mr Siemiatkowski talks about how the financial industry is 
unusual for being a sector still dominated by national players, offering a broad range of services. His vision instead 
is of a group of global players offering specialised services.
So Klarna will use its banking licence to offer bank cards and salary accounts to its 60m users. But it will not offer 
mortgages, savings products or share dealing. Instead, Mr Siemiatkowski expects other fintechs to do that, with the 
possibility of several teaming up loosely to provide the full offering.
Its large userbase, mostly in Germany and the Nordics, means he thinks he can get around one big problem for 
fintechs of being largely unknown to the public, who hesitate to trust them. "We are still moving at the speed of a 
fintech, but provide the trust and security of a bank. That makes us a super rare animal."
The big goal for Klarna, however, is trying to crack the US and UK markets. Some wonder whether Mr 
Siemiatkowski has bitten off more than he can chew by becoming a bank.
"Online payments is one thing. But being a bank you end up being heavily regulated. I wonder if they can cope with 
that," says a top Swedish banker.
Mr Siemiatkowski is not worried. He says: "Companies are cool, but banks are cooler. Building a bank is even 
cooler." Richard Milne
Load-Date: June 23, 2017
End of Document
Fintech entrepreneur aims to be Sweden's coolest banker
Fintech entrepreneur aims to be Sweden's coolest banker
Financial Times (London, England)
June 24, 2017 Saturday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 9
Length: 630 words
Body
Corporate person in the news Sebastian Siemiatkowski Chief executive, Klarna Swedish business bosses are 
known for being careful with their words, some might even say dull. Sebastian Siemiatkowski is different.
It might be his tech background or his age, he is 35, but the chief executive of Klarna is not afraid to speak his mind. 
Announcing this week that his company had become the biggest fintech in Europe to receive a banking licence, he 
said he wanted Klarna to become the "Ryanair" of the sector and attack the high-voltage incumbents.
"Ryanair has pretty bad customer service," sniffed one senior Swedish banker. But in the next breath, she added: 
"That's to take nothing away from Klarna. What Sebastian has achieved there is remarkable."
Mr Siemiatkowski and two university friends took a deceptively simple idea on invoicing and applied it to the digital 
age. The result is an online payments system that is simpler for customers and better for merchants, with fewer 
dropped transactions caused by people balking at filling in too much information. Instead, customers pay for online 
goods after they receive them, and Klarna takes the credit risk from sellers in return for a cut.
Entered 12 years ago in an entrepreneur competition at Sweden's leading business school, the idea was rejected 
by many of the country's top executives. The desire to prove them wrong still motivates Mr Siemiatkowski. "For me 
personally, it's a day I've been looking forward to for a long time," he said of Monday's decision by Swedish 
regulators to give Klarna a banking licence.
Mr Siemiatkowski has also long stood out in Sweden as one of the few business people willing to give his opinions 
about politics. After national elections that saw a breakthrough for the anti-immigration Sweden Democrats, he told 
Fintech entrepreneur aims to be Sweden's coolest banker
the Financial Times: "We believe that Sweden becomes a much better place because people from all over the 
world are working here. Seeing the Sweden Democrats growing feels like taking the country back 100 years ago."
That impatience with the traditional ways of doing things has led to Klarna becoming one of the most highly valued 
technology groups in Europe. A round of fundraising in 2015 valued it at $2.25bn. And it is solidly profitable, making 
an operating profit of SKr138m ($16m) in the first quarter on revenues of SKr992m.
Klarna's ambitions go way beyond increasing profits. Mr Siemiatkowski talks about how the financial industry is 
unusual for being a sector still dominated by national players, offering a broad range of services. His vision instead 
is of a group of global players offering specialised services.
So Klarna will use its banking licence to offer bank cards and salary accounts to its 60m users. But it will not offer 
mortgages, savings products or share dealing. Instead, Mr Siemiatkowski expects other fintechs to do that, with the 
possibility of several teaming up loosely to provide the full offering.
Its large userbase, mostly in Germany and the Nordics, means he thinks he can get around one big problem for 
fintechs of being largely unknown to the public, who hesitate to trust them. "We are still moving at the speed of a 
fintech, but provide the trust and security of a bank. That makes us a super rare animal."
The big goal for Klarna, however, is trying to crack the US and UK markets. Some wonder whether Mr 
Siemiatkowski has bitten off more than he can chew by becoming a bank.
"Online payments is one thing. But being a bank you end up being heavily regulated. I wonder if they can cope with 
that," says a top Swedish banker.
Mr Siemiatkowski is not worried. He says: "Companies are cool, but banks are cooler. Building a bank is even 
cooler." Richard Milne
'We are still moving at the speed of a fintech but provide the trust and security of a bank'
Graphic
 
Sebastian Siemiatkowski has maintained a desire to prove wrong the business elite that dismissed his innovative 
payment system - Johan Jeppsson/Bloomberg
Load-Date: March 31, 2020
End of Document

Fintech entrepreneur aims to be Sweden's coolest banker

about politics. After national elections that saw a breakthrough for the anti-immigration Sweden Democrats, he told 
the Financial Times: "We believe that Sweden becomes a much better place because people from all over the

That impatience with the traditional ways of doing things has led to Klarna becoming one of the most highly valued 
technology groups in Europe. A round of fundraising in 2015 valued it at $2.25bn. And it is solidly profitable, making 
an operating profit of SKr138m ($16m) in the first quarter on revenues of SKr992m.
Klarna's ambitions go way beyond increasing profits. Mr Siemiatkowski talks about how the financial industry is 
unusual for being a sector still dominated by national players, offering a broad range of services. His vision instead 
is of a group of global players offering specialised services.
So Klarna will use its banking licence to offer bank cards and salary accounts to its 60m users. But it will not offer

possibility of several teaming up loosely to provide the full offering.
Its large userbase, mostly in Germany and the Nordics, means he thinks he can get around one big problem for 
fintechs of being largely unknown to the public, who hesitate to trust them. "We are still moving at the speed of a 
fintech, but provide the trust and security of a bank. That makes us a super rare animal."
The big goal for Klarna, however, is trying to crack the US and UK markets. Some wonder whether Mr 
Siemiatkowski has bitten off more than he can chew by becoming a bank.
"Online payments is one thing. But being a bank you end up being heavily regulated. I wonder if they can cope with 
that," says a top Swedish banker.
Mr Siemiatkowski is not worried. He says: "Companies are cool, but banks are cooler. Building a bank is even 
cooler." Richard Milne

Belfast betting on a bright future in wake of Brexit
Belfast betting on a bright future in wake of Brexit
Sunday Business Post
June 23, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1017 words
Byline: Graham Clifford
Highlight: A building boom, increased consumer confidence and optimism that the city can benefit from businesses 
relocating after Brexit have all given Belfast the belief that better days are on their way, writes Graham Clifford 
Body
Stand at any elevated vantage point in Belfast city centre, and the sight of cranes dotting the skyline indicates just 
how vibrant the city’s economy has become.
Despite political volatility and economic uncertainty, the city is looking towards a bright, positive and peaceful future. 
It’s on the cusp of something big and consumer confidence remains encouragingly high.
Busy shopping malls, museums, lively pubs, clubs and hotels, active streets full of colour and world class third- 
level institutions create a rich tapestry.
The business sector, and in particular technology, is strengthening as new job announcements become a near-
monthly reality and companies already located in Belfast and across Northern Ireland continue to re-invest.
And technology isn’t the only sector which can claim great success in recent years. Take, for example, the hotel 
sector. It is estimated there are almost 30 new hotel projects in the offing across the North with the bulk of the 
building boom in Belfast. The city will see an unprecedented rise of 38 per cent in room capacity by 2018 if all 
current projects come to fruition. This could grow by a further 35 per cent by 2020. In terms of investment, the 
private sector will spend around £300 million building these new hotels by 2018.
One of the clearest indicators that Belfast is fast developing a reputation as a business, retail and tourist hotspot is 
the fact that the Belfast International to London Gatwick route became the busiest British domestic air route in 2016.
The Belfast to Gatwick service operated by EasyJet and Ryanair overtook the Edinburgh-Heathrow link to become 
Britain’s most popular domestic route, while Belfast International has overtaken Gatwick to become Britain’s fourth 
largest airport for domestic operations.
Belfast betting on a bright future in wake of Brexit
Two new trans-Atlantic services from Belfast to New York and Boston will help boost long-haul passenger numbers 
and attract great numbers of American tourists to the North.
Belfast is just 90 minutes from Dublin by road, and with a new multimillion-pound transport hub in the pipeline, 
connectivity between Belfast and the Republic will be further improved.
All of these factors make Belfast an ideal location for businesses seeking to establish a satellite office within the 
British market, according to Johnny Hanna, partner and head of tax at KPMG in Northern Ireland.
He told The Sunday Business Post: “In Brexit-related discussions with various companies we emphasise the need 
to prepare based on what is known at this stage.
“It makes common sense to consider all scenarios – in particular the British government’s stated intention to leave 
both the single market and the customs union. With that in mind we recommend focusing on the business 
implications and to think about what actions they can take to ensure that their business is prepared. For example, 
what are the supply chain implications? Do you know where your inputs are coming from and what the implications 
might be under various scenarios?”
Hanna continued: “While Brexit has the potential to cause significant disruption to many British and EU supply 
chains, one obvious response from EU companies (including those from Ireland) currently selling into the British 
market may be to simply establish a British base (eg, a manufacturing operation or a warehouse) so as to minimise 
any issues that might arise from a new EU/British customs border. There is undoubtedly a huge opportunity here for 
Belfast (and Northern Ireland generally) to attract some of this business.”
A key asset for businesses in the city is the availability of a rich talent pool fed by Queen’s University and Ulster 
University and a strong network of further education colleges. A cost competitive workforce and low labour turnover 
make the North an attractive location for inward investors.
In March, the US fintech firm Vela said that the North’s rich talent pool of graduates and professionals was a key 
driver for its long-term commitment to the region. “Their knowledge and skill, strong work ethic, and can-do attitude 
have helped us to remain true to our key values of teamwork, technology excellence, efficiency, focus, integrity, and 
reliability,” said chief executive Jen Nayar as she announced an increase in jobs at the company’s Belfast base.
The fact that almost 80 per cent of new inward investors have already reinvested in the North, or are planning to 
invest more, shows the North’s excellent track record as a location for investment.
Meanwhile, projects such as the £175 million Belfast Transport Hub development, which will include new 
commercial, retail and residential space in the city, will add even more vibrancy to an already buzzing city. The new 
hub will include eight railway platforms – allowing an hourly service to and from Dublin while moving the Enterprise 
rail service from Central Station.
The surrounding Weavers Cross neighbourhood offers huge investment potential allowing for over 100,000 sq m of 
commercial space alongside significant residential and amenity space. ‘Regeneration through reconnection’ is a key 
them of the project – bringing together the area’s past, regenerating its present and reimagining its future.
Hanna of KPMG said: “Resilience should not be underestimated, and Belfast has bags of that. The city has 
developed a reputation for getting on with things even when obstacles are placed in its path. It has developed a 
very strong record in attracting foreign direct investment, maintaining a competitive cost base, developing the 
adequate talent and infrastructure and Belfast is now a well-connected city.”
Hanna also emphasised the personal tax environment. “The personal tax regime is attractive and if the corporation 
tax rate is reduced to 12.5 per cent soon that will certainly assist the economy in Northern Ireland. Heads are being 
turned and international investors are looking to Belfast more now than ever before. The city needs to capitalise on 
this great opportunity.”
Belfast betting on a bright future in wake of Brexit
Buoyant, booming and agile, Belfast is well placed to build on the successes of recent years as it strives to expand, 
grow and boost inward investment.
Load-Date: June 24, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Receives Media Impact Rating of 0.05
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Receives Media Impact Rating of 0.05
DailyPolitical
June 23, 2017 Friday 7:24 PM EST
Copyright 2017 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 567 words
Byline: Stacy Sanders
Body
Jun 23, 2017( DailyPolitical: http://www.dailypolitical.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  News articles about Ryanair 
Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have been trending somewhat positive recently, Accern reports. Accern identifies 
positive and negative press coverage by monitoring more than 20 million news and blog sources. Accern ranks 
coverage of companies on a scale of -1 to 1, with scores closest to one being the most favorable. 
Ryanair Holdings PLC earned a media sentiment score of 0.05 on Accern's scale. Accern also assigned news 
stories about the transportation company an impact score of 75 out of 100, meaning that recent press coverage is 
likely to have an effect on the company's share price in the next few days. Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC 
(RYAAY[1]) traded down 0.38% on Friday, hitting $108.87. The stock had a trading volume of 78,136 shares. The 
firm has a 50 day moving average of $103.67 and a 200 day moving average of $89.02. The stock has a market 
cap of $26.52 billion, a P/E ratio of 18.58 and a beta of 0.57. Ryanair Holdings PLC has a 12 month low of $66.09 
and a 12 month high of $110.82.  Several equities research analysts have commented on RYAAY shares. Zacks 
Investment Research[2] upgraded Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'sell' rating to a 'buy' rating and set a $109.00 price 
objective on the stock in a research report on Saturday, May 6th. ValuEngine[3] lowered Ryanair Holdings PLC 
from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research report on Wednesday, May 24th. Citigroup Inc. lowered Ryanair 
Holdings PLC from a 'buy' rating to a 'neutral' rating in a research report on Wednesday, May 31st. Finally, 
Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. (The) upgraded Ryanair Holdings PLC from a 'neutral' rating to a 'buy' rating and 
increased their target price for the company from $67.56 to $109.00 in a research report on Thursday, June 15th. 
One equities research analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, five have issued a hold rating and nine have 
assigned a buy rating to the company. Ryanair Holdings PLC currently has an average rating of 'Buy' and an 
average target price of $102.67. https://www.dailypolitical.com/2017/06/23/ryanair-holdings-plc-ryaay-receives-
media-impact-rating-of-0-05.html.  About Ryanair Holdings PLC Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a 
holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline 
serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and 
Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in other activities connected with its core air 
passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of 
beverages, food and merchandise. Receive News ...tings for Ryanair Holdings PLC Daily - Enter your email

Ryanair launches Midsummer Madness seat sale
Ryanair launches Midsummer Madness seat sale
Business World (Digest)
June 23, 2017 Friday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 136 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Ryanair has today launched a massive "Midsummer Madness" seat sale with up to 20% off two million seats for 
travel between July and November, allowing customers to book a break on the lowest fares.    These seat sale 
fares are available now starting from just €9.99 but must be booked before midnight Sunday (25 June) and can only 
be found on the Ryanair.com website.   Speaking today, Ryanair’s Robin Kiely said, "Summer is here and to 
celebrate we’ve launched a massive "Midsummer Madness" sale with up to 20% off two million seats across the 
Ryanair network. Fares start from just €9.99 for travel between July and November and this amazing offer will end 
at midnight Sunday, June 25th, so customers should put down the sun cream, log on quickly and book these mad 
midsummer fares today."

Wizz Air To Double Fleet Size By 2024 With New Airbus A321 Order
Wizz Air To Double Fleet Size By 2024 With New Airbus A321 Order
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
June 21, 2017 Wednesday 6:04 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 192 words
Body
 Wizz Air Holdings PLC on Wednesday said it has ordered an additional 10 Airbus A321ceo aircraft, to join its fleet 
in 2018 and 2019.
Based on current list prices, the value of the new order is USD1.2 billion, although Wizz Air noted that Airbus has 
granted it "significant" discounts from list prices in the past.
Wizz Air has been operating the Airbus A321 since November 2015 and currently operates 19 of the 230-seat 
aircraft type with another 22 A321 aircraft to join the fleet by 2019. 
Wizz Air said it is achieving 10% unit cost savings with the A321 when compared to the A320.
The airline added that the new order, on top of the 110 A321neo aircraft it has ordered, will more than double the 
size of its fleet by 2024.
Shares in Wizz Air were trading up 0.2% at 2,315.00 pence on Wednesday.
The announcement came after rival budget airline Ryanair Holdings PLC on Tuesday said it has bought a further 10 
Boeing 737 Max 200 aircraft. 
The new order, valued at more than USD1.1 billion, adds to an existing order for 100 of the same aircraft. Ryanair 
said the total 110 aircraft will allow it to grow its traffic to 200 million customers per year by 2024.
Load-Date: June 22, 2017
End of Document
The Latest: Boeing , Airbus compete for orders at air show
The Latest: Boeing, Airbus compete for orders at air show
Associated Press Financial Wire
June 20, 2017 Tuesday 12:55 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 280 words
Dateline: PARIS 
Body
PARIS (AP) - The Latest on the Paris Air Show (all times local):
2:45 p.m.
Boeing has landed a string of new plane deals while Airbus has won lucrative promises at the Paris Air Show, as 
both plane makers stressed the growing importance of digital technology in aviation.
Boeing announced firm orders Tuesday for more than 45 planes worth $5.4 billion at list prices, though customers 
routinely negotiate discounts. Buyers included Ryanair, China's Okay Airways and the Aviation Capital Group 
leasing company.
Boeing also took in tentative orders for a further 83 planes worth as much as $9.3 billion.
Airbus said it had pledges Tuesday for 95 jets worth up to $10.4 billion at list prices.
Most of the orders were for single-aisle jets.
Airbus launched a new digital platform and Boeing forecast big growth in demand for technology and data to guide 
aviation industry decisions.
High-tech hardware is getting attention at this year's Paris Air Show.
___
2:20 p.m.
The head of the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration says the boom in drone popularity is "a huge game changer" 
similar "to powered flight or jet engines."
In an Associated Press interview Tuesday, Michael Huerta said "the growth of this industry and how it's evolving is 
something that all of us in aviation need to pay a lot of attention to."
The Latest: Boeing , Airbus compete for orders at air show
Huerta spoke on the sidelines of the Paris Air Show, where drones of all kinds were being displayed.
For the industry, their popularity begs a vital question: how do you make sure that swarms of new machines don't 
endanger each other, other users of the skies and people on the ground as they do everything from patrolling traffic 
blackspots to, possibly, delivering your burger and fries?
Load-Date: June 21, 2017

Klarna aims to be Ryanair of banking as fintech group wins lender's licence
Klarna aims to be Ryanair of banking as fintech group wins lender's licence
Financial Times (London, England)
June 20, 2017 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 13
Length: 325 words
Byline: RICHARD MILNE
Body
Klarna has become the largest European fintech company to secure a banking licence, with the Swedish group 
saying it wants to become a Ryanair-type low-cost disrupter of the sector, attacking established lenders across the 
continent.
Valued at more than $2bn, Klarna has captured much of the market for online payments in the Nordic countries and 
Germany. Yesterday it received a banking licence from the Swedish Financial Supervisory Authority, 20 months 
after filing for one.
"We want to be part of reshaping the retail banking industry. New regulations ... set the right prerequisites for the 
destruction of that industry, but it needs a Ryanair to come along. We want to be that player," Sebastian 
Siemiatkowski, Klarna's chief executive, told the Financial Times.
Fintech groups in Europe and the US, such as SoFi and Zopa, have been seeking full banking licences, but Klarna - 
with its 60m customers across Europe and (EURO)13bn in transactions processed last year - is one of the largest.
The Swedish group, which is profitable, had revenues of SKr3.6bn ($410m) last year and was valued at $2.25bn in 
a fundraising in 2015. It is looking at offering European customers services such as bank cards and salary 
accounts, as well as eyeing the US for expansion.
Klarna aims to be Ryanair of banking as fintech group wins lender's licence
Mr Siemiatkowski thinks banks offer poor customer service at inflated prices. "Banks are challenged. In the tech 
world, these companies get outcompeted very quickly if they don't deliver. But due to regulation, banks with very old 
technology - and poor customer satisfaction - have been able to prevail," he said.
Chris Ward of Mapa Research, a digital banking consultancy, said that despite Klarna being "quite aggressive" in its 
approach, the big universal banks were likely to resist the challenge.
"Fintechs are not going to break down your big incumbent banks. Those banks are always going to maintain a 
certain size, giving them big economies of scale," he said.
Eyeing global growth page 17
Load-Date: June 19, 2017
End of Document
Klarna aims to be Ryanair of banking as fintech group wins lender's licence
Klarna aims to be Ryanair of banking as fintech group wins lender's licence
Financial Times (London, England)
June 20, 2017 Tuesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: FRONT PAGE - COMPANIES & MARKETS; Pg. 11
Length: 325 words
Byline: Richard Milne, Nordic Correspondent
Body
Klarna has become the largest European fintech company to secure a banking licence, with the Swedish group 
saying it wants to become a Ryanair-type low-cost disrupter of the sector, attacking established lenders across the 
continent.
Valued at more than $2bn, Klarna has captured much of the market for online payments in the Nordic countries and

with its 60m customers across Europe and EUR13bn in transactions processed last year - is one of the largest.
The Swedish group, which is profitable, had revenues of SKr3.6bn ($410m) last year and was valued at $2.25bn in 
a fundraising in 2015. It is looking at offering European customers services such as bank cards and salary

Klarna aims to be Ryanair of banking as fintech group wins lender's licence
Mr Siemiatkowski thinks banks offer poor customer service at inflated prices. "Banks are challenged. In the tech 
world, these companies get outcompeted very quickly if they don't deliver. But due to regulation, banks with very old

"Fintechs are not going to break down your big incumbent banks. Those banks are always going to maintain a 
certain size, giving them big economies of scale," he said.

sides.

proceedings from the bloc in a meeting that both sides hailed as constructive after an early concession 
from London on the sequence of talks.

American technology shares rebounded after a sell-off that began ten days ago. 
•
Financial Times: US tax authorities are intensifying their efforts to find tax evaders and the bankers who 
assist them, deploying agents to examine reams of data collected from the Panama Papers, Swiss banks 
and whistleblowers. 
•
The Guardian: The Co-operative Group’s stake in the Co-op Bank could fall dramatically under a rescue 
plan being drawn up by hedge funds. 
•
Financial Times: Russia on Monday threatened to target US-led coalition aircraft flying over Syria in a sign 
of the mounting tensions in the region after an American fighter jet downed a Syrian government warplane.

•

fill one of the gaps on the Monetary Policy Committee, the panel which sets interest rates at the Bank of 
England. 
•
